projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

WHEREVNTO IS ANEXED A SEVErall treatiÅ¿e, concerning the MaÅ¿Å¿e and AntichriÅ¿t.

q.p: A King that iudgeth the poore in trueth, his Throne Å¿hall be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed for euer.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT EXCELLENT AND MIGHTY PRINCE, IAMES the 6. King of Scotland, &c. Grace and peace be multiplied.
div.p:
I Hope it Å¿hall not be accompted preÅ¿umption, (moÅ¿t noble Prince) to offer to your MaieÅ¿ty, the firÅ¿t fruites of theÅ¿e my Å¿imple and rude labours, Å¿eing the cauÅ¿e is IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿ts, that King of Kings, and Lord of glorie, whilk is heir defended, euen the euerlaÅ¿ting trueth of God, againÅ¿t the venimous Å¿tings of one of the Reu. 9.3. LocuÅ¿ts of that AntichriÅ¿tian Kingdome. The right whereof does moÅ¿t iuÅ¿tly belong to your MaieÅ¿ty, both in reÅ¿pect of theÅ¿e rare and Å¿ingulare gifts of knowledge and vnderÅ¿tanding, whilk the Lord hes vouchÅ¿aued vpon your MaieÅ¿tie, in Å¿ik a plentifull meaÅ¿ure, that your Å¿ubiects does acknowledge it at home, and Å¿trangers does admire it & commend it abroade: whereby you are not only able to 1. Pet. 3.15 rander a reaÅ¿on of that Faith whilk is in you; but alÅ¿o able to Tit. 1.9. Å¿toppe the mouth of the aduerÅ¿ary, and convict the gainÅ¿aier whatÅ¿umeuer, by that 2. Tim. 13.15. worde of trueth wherewith your MaieÅ¿ty hes bene brought vp from your very infancy: Å¿o that all the wiÅ¿e men of Babel, I meane the
Cleargie of that Romane harlote, is not able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the mouth and wiÅ¿edome whilk the Lord hes giuen to your MaieÅ¿tie. And alÅ¿o in reÅ¿pect of that Å¿upereminent power, (as Rom. 13.1 the ApoÅ¿tle calles it) whereby as you are moÅ¿t able, Å¿o are you moÅ¿t obliÅ¿hed to maintain his truth, propagate his kingdome, and nuriÅ¿he his owne Å¿pouÅ¿e, whilk hee hes Act. 20.20 purchaÅ¿ed to himÅ¿elfe by his owne blood, by the breaÅ¿ts of your MaieÅ¿ties gouernement, as it was promiÅ¿ed of olde that his EÅ¿a. 60.16 Å¿pouÅ¿e Å¿houlde Å¿uck the breaÅ¿tes of Kings. So, who is more obliÅ¿hed, then ye, Sir? Who Å¿o Å¿ufficient and able euery way to mantaine it, as ye Sir? Your knowledge bindes you: your profeÅ¿sion bindes you: your Å¿oueraigne authoritie, as yeare a King in IÅ¿rael bindes you. For, as the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t king that euer was hes Å¿aide, and left it in write: or rather that King of Kings in him and by him, Pro. 8.15 Princes raigne by me. Ye holde your kingdome of him, Sir, and muÅ¿t lay down your crowne at his feet, and muÅ¿t Å¿tand vp and giue a reckoning of the gouernement of his Kingdome, of the maintenance of his trueth, and of the nouriÅ¿hing his Å¿pouÅ¿e in that day. Your knowledge, Sir, is able to iuÅ¿tifie it ã in non-Latin alphabet ã : your Å¿oueraigne authoritie able to defend it ã in non-Latin alphabet ã Ye haue receaued that Heb. 4.12 Eph. 6 17, 2. two edged Å¿worde of Gods Spirite in your mouth, able to wound, yea to conÅ¿ume that man of Å¿inne and Å¿onne of perdition: ye haue receaued that Rom. 13.4 Å¿worde of juÅ¿tice and judgement in your hands, able to PÅ¿al 101.8. deÅ¿troy betimes al the wicked of your kingdom and to roote out from the city of the Lorde, all the workers of iniquity. Ye know, Sir, Reu. 17.4.5. the abhomination of Babel, that as it is Å¿aid of the verteous woman Pro. 31 26 Many wemen haue done vertuouÅ¿ly, but thou Å¿urmounts them al: Å¿o the contrary may be Å¿aid of her: many hereticks hes taught erroneouÅ¿ly, & worÅ¿hipped & wrought
abhominably: but the Reu. 17.1. whoore of Babel, the Kirk of Rome, in hereÅ¿ie, in abhomination, in idolatry, hes Å¿urmounted theÌ all, that euer went before her, or euer Å¿hall come after her: Reu. 13.1.3 6. Manye beaÅ¿tes haue Å¿poken blaÅ¿phemouÅ¿ly, but that Reu. 13. & 16.13.14. & 17.3.4.5.6. & 18.24. Å¿econde beaÅ¿te that hes two hornes like the Lambe, Å¿urmounteth them all in blaÅ¿phemy, tyranny, crueltie, and abhominable idolatrie, deÅ¿troying and making marchandiÅ¿e of the Å¿oules of men and wemen. Other hereÅ¿ies did but Å¿ubuert Å¿ome fundamentall pointes of Religion, but the Kirk of Rome hes Å¿ubuerted them all almoÅ¿te. Of other hereÅ¿ies, Å¿ome was but againÅ¿t the God-head of ChriÅ¿t, other Å¿ome againÅ¿t his maÌhood, other Å¿ome againÅ¿t his offices and benefites, or Å¿ome one head or other: but the doctrine of the Kirk of Rome, is againÅ¿t them all. Iniurious to his God-head, in making him, not onely inferiour to the Father, in teaching that he is not ã in non-Latin alphabet ã but alÅ¿o inferior to the very creatures, in praying to Mary to command her Son, Iure Matris impera Redemptori, as I heard your MaieÅ¿ty moÅ¿t Å¿olidely proue, and Å¿o worÅ¿e then the Artians. Iniurious to his man-hood, to all his offices, his benefites, and all the meanes, inward and outward, of the knowing & applying of him. And laÅ¿t of all, iniurious to his Å¿oueraigne glory, in coÌmunicating it to Å¿tocks & Å¿tones, a peece of bread bones & aÅ¿hes, & the skurf skarf of all things, as I hope, I haue made manifest in this my anÅ¿were. So that moÅ¿te iuÅ¿tly it is called Reu. 13.11. 1. Tim. 4. the Å¿peach of the Dragon, and the doctrine of Diuels by the Spirite of God. And if the profeÅ¿sion of Å¿ik a DiueliÅ¿h doctrine be too great an euill, what would the practiÅ¿e thereof be? I meane the idolatrous MaÅ¿se that abhomination of deÅ¿olation. The miÅ¿erie, allace, were too greate, Matth. 9.36. to Å¿ee the people of this countrie Å¿cattered as Å¿heep without Å¿heepheards, dying that Å¿econd & euerlaÅ¿ting
death, for want of the bread of life and goÅ¿pell of Å¿aluation. But this would be the miÅ¿ery of miÅ¿eries, if the Reu. 17.4 golden cupe of Babel, full of all abhominations, Å¿huld be Å¿et to their head againe, to drink the deadly poiÅ¿on of their owne damnation. And certainly, if Amos. 8.11.12. this famine of the worde of God, whereby not onely Amos. 48. two or three citties, as the Prophet Å¿ayes, but twenty or thirty Parochins in Å¿ome places, Å¿hould be compelled to goe to one, if they were deÅ¿irous to drink the waters of life; this I Å¿ay, is a iudgment heauie ynough. But what a iudgement would this be, if they were compelled to byde at home, and it were but in their owne families, by that abhominable MaÅ¿Å¿e, the rounde bread, the Gods of Babell. Surely a great many of the people of this countrie, does not 1. Reg. 18.21. halte nowe betweene theÅ¿e two thoughts, whether God be the Lord, or Baal: but hes forÅ¿aken the Lord and his GoÅ¿pell, and in their heart deÅ¿ires the opportunitie to Å¿ay to their round bread, theÅ¿e are our Gods who hes redeemed vs from hell, and theÅ¿e will wee worÅ¿hip, at leaÅ¿t Å¿ecreitly, til our Å¿trength grow, & our nomber encreaÅ¿e. The reÅ¿te of the iniquities of this land, were too great to prouoke the Lorde of hoaÅ¿tes, Å¿uppoÅ¿e this impietie, (whilk the Lorde forbid for his ChriÅ¿ts Å¿ake) bee not added vnto all the reÅ¿te, and aboue all the reÅ¿te. For what Å¿inne is comparable to idolatry? or what iniquity hes bene euer Å¿o Å¿euearly puniÅ¿hed, as idolatrie? a Å¿inne that is immediatly againÅ¿t God, againÅ¿t ChriÅ¿t, againÅ¿t his glory: a Å¿inne that made Ex. 32.28. Num. 25.9. 2700 of the Lords owne choÅ¿en inheritance to fall in the wilderneÅ¿Å¿e, for the golden Calfe, & Baal-Peor. A Å¿inne that prouoked the Lorde in Å¿ik a high meaÅ¿ure, that it made him delyuer his owne people (whome he had planted in that land of promiÅ¿e, and to whome he had Å¿worne to be their God) Iudg â¢ . 11.12.13 14.25. ouer in the hands of their enemies
round about them, Å¿o that whitherÅ¿oeuer they went, the hande of the Lorde was Å¿ore againÅ¿t them. A Å¿inne that 1. Reg. 11 5.11. rent the kingdome of Dauid aÅ¿under, and made ten parts of it to be giuen to Ieroboam the Son of Nebat, Å¿uppoÅ¿e the perÅ¿on was called 2. Sam. 12 24.25. Iedidiah, the beloued of the Lord, & the promiÅ¿e was made vnto him, that 2. Sam. 7.12.13. his houÅ¿e and throne Å¿houlde Å¿tand for euer. And finally, a Å¿in that firÅ¿t mooued the Lord 2. Reg. 17 18. to put awaye IÅ¿rael from before his face, & cauÅ¿ed their land to vomit them out, without al hope euer to returne againe, and then made 2. Chro. 36.16.17.18 19.20.2. Reg. 25.10. his wrath Å¿o hote againÅ¿te Iuda, till there was no remedye but the Temple, the Kings houÅ¿e, and the houÅ¿es of all the nobles, were brunt with fire, the Kings Å¿onnes firÅ¿te Å¿laine before his eies, then his owne eies put out, himÅ¿elfe bounde with chaines of Å¿teill, and he and his people carried captiues to Babel, wher there they remained for the Å¿pace of 70. yeares. Are not theÅ¿e things falne forth 2. Cor. 10 11. as examples to vs, & ar they not written for our inÅ¿truction, as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayes, vpon whome the ends of the world is fallen: and is not Reu. 17.4 the abhomination of Babel, their idolatrous MaÅ¿Å¿e, as great abhomination in the eyes of the Lord, as 1. Reg. 11.5 Milcom the abhomination of the Ammonites. Is it a leÅ¿Å¿e idolatry to worÅ¿hippe a Ex. 32.4. 1. Reg. 11.5 â¢ Iud. 2.13. golden Calfe, the gods of Egypt, or a grauen Å¿heepe AÅ¿chtaroth, the gods of the Sidonians, then to worÅ¿hip a bit of breade, made of wheate, grouÌd in the mil, baken in the ouen, coniured and erected vp by a Idolatrous PrieÅ¿t, whilk is the God of Babel, the Kirk of Rome. Is there any more Godhead in the one, then in the other? Hes their idole of the MaÅ¿Å¿e any more life, feeling, or mouing, then the idols of Egypt and Sidon had? and does not the Kirk of Rome giue as great, yea rather greater
worÅ¿hip and Religion to their round bread, then Iuda or IÅ¿rael gaue to their golden calfe, or to AÅ¿ttaroth the grauen Å¿heepe. For they worÅ¿hip it as their Creator and redeemer. And as the worÅ¿hip of the golden Calfe, is called Deut. 32.17. the worÅ¿hip of Diuels in MoÅ¿es Å¿ong: Å¿o the Idolatry of the Kirk of Rome, whereof their rounde breade in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, is one of the principall, is called Reu. 9.20. the worÅ¿hip of Diuels, by the voyce that came from the foure hornes of the golden altare. For what Kirk or Kingdome vnder heauen is there to be found, who in the tyme of the blaÅ¿t of the Å¿ext Trumpet, when that fearfull army of the Turkes was looÅ¿ed to ouerrun ChriÅ¿tendome, does worÅ¿hip Idoles of golde and Å¿iluer, of braÅ¿Å¿e, of woode, and of Å¿tone, but the Kirk of Rome? And if the worÅ¿hip of God by Images, as IÅ¿rael did in the golden Galfe, whilk is but the breake of the Å¿econd command, be called the worÅ¿hip of Diuels, Å¿hall not the worÅ¿hip of a falÅ¿e Creator and Redeemer, as they doe in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk is not only the breake of the firÅ¿t command, but alÅ¿o the Å¿tramping vnder foote of the Å¿onne of God in the goÅ¿pel, be moÅ¿t iuÅ¿tly called the worÅ¿hip of Diuels? And is not the Lord as iealous of his glory now, as he was then? and hes hee not Å¿worne EÅ¿ai. 42.8 that hee will not giue it to another? and hes hee not Reu. 13.14 15.16. & 14 8.9.10.11.12. & 16.1.2.10.19. & 17.1.2. & 18.2.3.3.5.6.21. & 19.19.20.21. & 21.21. threatned as Å¿euere iudgements againÅ¿t the whoore of Babel, and the worÅ¿hippers of the beaÅ¿te and his image, and them that receaues his marke, openly or priuately, as euer he did againÅ¿t Iuda or IÅ¿rael? Did he not cauÅ¿e it to be proclaimed, by an Angell with an loud voice, that the foundations of the earth might heare it, and tremble, that they Å¿hall drinke of the wine of the wrath of God, yea of that pure wine, powred out in the Cupe of his wrath, and they Å¿hall be tormented day and night before the holy Angels
and before the Lambe: and the Å¿moake of their torment Å¿hall aÅ¿cend for euermore, and they Å¿hall haue no reÅ¿t day nor night, that worÅ¿hips the beaÅ¿t and his Image. And heard not Iohn him that Å¿ate vppon the Throne, the judge of the whole earth, Å¿ay, that Idolaters Å¿hall haue their portion in the lake that burnes with fire and brimÅ¿tone, whilk is the Å¿econd death. And Å¿eing the knowledge of our redemption Å¿urmounteth the knowledge of our creation: and the benefite of our redemption exceides (by many degrees) the benefite of our creation: Å¿hall not the worÅ¿hip of an idole redeemer, and of a falÅ¿e IeÅ¿us, as they doe in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿urmount by many degrees, the worÅ¿hip of an idole creator, as Iuda and IÅ¿rael did? For the greater the light be, and the greater the mercie be that is beÅ¿towed vpon any, their Å¿inne muÅ¿t be the greater. And as the light of the goÅ¿pell is more 2. Cor. 3.6.7.8.9.10.11.12.13. glorious then the light of the law, Å¿o the idolatrie of theÅ¿e that are vnder the GoÅ¿pell, muÅ¿t be more abhominable then the Idolatrie of theÅ¿e that were vnder the Law. Theirs was but Heb. 10.28. the diÅ¿pyÅ¿ing of MoÅ¿es Lawe: but this Idolatrie of their MaÅ¿Å¿e, is Heb. 10.29. the Å¿tramping vnder foote of the bloode of ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿o worthy of Å¿orer puniÅ¿hment (as the ApoÅ¿t. Å¿ayes.) And Å¿upoÅ¿e that the iudgement were to fall but vpon the committers of this Å¿inne onely, it were too great, but it woulde reache further to a whole kingdome wherein it were committed, if by repentance and execution of iuÅ¿tice, it were not preuented. For Å¿hall Gen. 20.9 Abimelech King of Gerar, feare the iudgement of God vpon his whole Kingdome for one adultery only intended, and that in ignorance? And what may a whole land then feare for Å¿ik abhominable Idolatrie in Å¿o cleare a light of the GoÅ¿pell? And Å¿hall the ten tribes feare IoÅ¿h. 2 â¢ 21. the wrath of God to bee kindled againÅ¿te the
whole congregation of IÅ¿raell, For the rebellion of the other two tribes, in Å¿etting vp an altar to Å¿acrifice vpon as they thought? And what Å¿hould wee feare then againÅ¿te this whole land, if there were altars reired vp not to worÅ¿hip God on, but the Idoll of Babell. And if IoÅ¿ua. 7. Achans theft, Å¿uppoÅ¿e both the perÅ¿on & the Å¿inne was vnknowne: yea Å¿uppoÅ¿e there was no Å¿uÅ¿pition, neither of the one nor of the other, Å¿poyled all IÅ¿rael of Gods preÅ¿ence, made them fall before their enemies, and made the Lorde refuÅ¿e to be in the middeÅ¿t of them, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿inne & perÅ¿on was tryed and Å¿earched, and the Anathema taken away? And would not Babels Idolatrie be much more effectual to Å¿poyle all the land, if it were defiled therewith of Gods preÅ¿ence, to make vs fall before our enemies, and to make the Lord to departe from vs: Å¿uppoÅ¿e it were but in one perÅ¿on, Å¿eing the Å¿in is more odious in the Lords eyes, our light greater, and we more obleiÅ¿t nor they were. And Å¿uppoÅ¿e that this abhomination Å¿hould be but in priuat families, yet it is 2. Tin. 2.17. a fretting canker, as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayes, that frait hath infected a member of the bodie, it will inÅ¿ect the reÅ¿t; if it be not preuented by cutting of the feÅ¿tered member. And the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayes, 1. Cor. 5.6. a little leauen leaueneth the whole lumpe, and experience hes taught that by proces of time a little leck, hath Å¿unke a great Å¿hip, & one perÅ¿on infected with the peÅ¿tilence hes infected a whole kingdome. The firÅ¿t Idolatrie of the land of Canaan began with Iug. 17.5.3. Teraphim Iehouae, Å¿iluer Å¿anctified to the Lorde to bee an Image, but afterwarde it grew vp to the worÅ¿hip Iug 2.13. of Baall and AÅ¿chtaroth. It was in the beginning, but in one onlie familie, the familie of Iug. 17.1. Micah. but in proces of time, it paÅ¿Å¿ed from that familie to the tribe of Iug. 18. Dan. and from that tribe to all the reÅ¿t of the
â¢ ug. 2.13.14. Tribes: till at the laÅ¿t all IÅ¿raell Å¿inned & did that
whilk was euil in the Å¿ight of the Lord. So there is no queÅ¿tioÌ, Sir, & your MaieÅ¿tie put not to your hand, as your haue begun to doe it will get foote in this land, & it would paÅ¿Å¿e from families to tribes, from priuate houÅ¿es, to temples: from the worÅ¿hip of the round bread to the worÅ¿hip of Å¿tockes & Å¿tones, and Å¿o by one degree to another, till it haue made all guiltie, what by infecting, what by Communicating with their Å¿innes, and then bring the fearfull vengeance of God vpon all. And Å¿uppoÅ¿e, Sir, that you haue not neede to bee taught of any for that light and vnderÅ¿tanding where-with the Lorde hes annoynted you, in Å¿o greate a meaÅ¿ure beyonde many, doth teach you all things, and your MaieÅ¿tie hes laid Å¿o Å¿ure foundation of maintenance, both of iuÅ¿tice and religion within your land, and hes begun Å¿o Å¿ubÅ¿tantially to proÅ¿ecute the Å¿ame, (for the whilk from our harts we render glory and prayÅ¿e to God.) So that all further exhortation of your MaieÅ¿tie would Å¿eeme to be Å¿uperfluous, yet I muÅ¿t borrow leaue at your MaieÅ¿tie, to be bolde with all humbleneÅ¿Å¿e of mind & reuerence of hart, to God and to your MaieÅ¿tie, to beÅ¿eeke you by the price of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t your Lord, to Å¿tirre vp the bowels of your compaÅ¿sion ouer this deÅ¿olate countrie, for 1. Reg. 1.20. vpon whome are the eyes of all IÅ¿raell but vpon you Sir? And what King is there vnder heauen vnder whoÅ¿e gouernement the goÅ¿pel, hes had Å¿o free a paÅ¿Å¿age, & the kirk of god hes had Å¿ik purity & libertie, in Å¿ik peace for Å¿o long a time in a whole kingdome, without hereÅ¿ie or Å¿chiÅ¿me as vnder your MaieÅ¿ties gouernement. So that wee were both vngrate to God and to you Sir, if with all thankÅ¿giuing we did not acknowledge it. Take therefore for examples theÅ¿e worthie Kinges, who hes receaued a good reporte in the word of the Lord and now reÅ¿ting from their laboures, hes receaued that incorruptible crowne of glory. Put on their affections Sir, and follow their
actions, that your report heir, and crowne heirafter, may be equall, 2 or rather aboue theirs. Let your heart q melt, Sir, with good IoÅ¿ias, not for our fathers tranÅ¿greÅ¿sions, as he did, but for Eze. 9.4. our owne Å¿ins, and the Å¿innes of this land: For God Act. 17.30 31. Rom. 2.16 regarded not the time of their ignorance, when the GoÅ¿pell Å¿hyned not, but now Å¿ince that light is broken foorth, he admoniÅ¿hes all men to repent, becauÅ¿e he lies Å¿et a day (whilk cannot be far of) wherein he will iudge euerie one by the man ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us according to his GoÅ¿pell. And if that great Reu 10.1 2. Angel had not deÅ¿cended vnto vs, with that little booke open in his right haÌd, & the land had not bene once purged of idolatry, we Å¿hould not Ioh. 15.21.24. haue had Å¿inned, but nowe we haue no cloake for our Å¿inne. Stirre vp your anger with MoÅ¿es, Sir, who Å¿uppoÅ¿e he was Num. 12.13. the meekeÅ¿t man vppon the face of the whole earth, yet when he Å¿awe the golden calfe his Ez. 32.19 anger was kindled, that he brake the Tables of Å¿tone, the Lords owne worke and write, brunt the Calfe in the fire, braied it in powder, Å¿cattered it on the waters, and made the people to drinke thereof. Follow the example of good IehoÅ¿aphat, Sir, who 2. Chron. 27.4.20. Å¿ought the Lord his God, walked in his precepts, lifted vp his heart to the wayes of the Lord, purged his lande of Idolatrie: and firÅ¿t Å¿ent Levites with his owne Princes to teache all the citties of his kingdome the law of the Lord: and after being admoniÅ¿hed by the Prophet, for helping of the wicked, and louing them who hated the Lord, (Å¿uppoÅ¿e he was his neighbour king, joined in affinity with him) he Å¿o repented, that he went from the one end of his kingdome to the other, euen from BeerÅ¿heba to mount Ephraim, and brought his people to the Lord their God, and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed
religion, and juÅ¿tice in all the citties of his kingdome, and therefore the Lord was with him, he proÅ¿pered, & had riches and honour in aboundance. What ioy of heart, Sir, brought Ezechias to the hearts of all the godly, aÅ¿well indwellers, as Å¿trangers, when he 2. Chro. 29 & 30.31. purged his land of Idolatry, brake the braÅ¿en Å¿erpent whilk the people had abuÅ¿ed, opened the dores of the TeÌ ple whilk were Å¿hut vp, reÅ¿tored the worÅ¿hip of God, Å¿ent meÅ¿Å¿ingers with letters throughout al IÅ¿rael, to conuert them to the Lorde their God, reÅ¿tored the PrieÅ¿ts and Leuites to their miniÅ¿try, as the Lord had commanded by his Prophetes, Å¿pake to their hearts, Å¿treÌgthened them in their offices, prouided for their maintenance, that they might be encouraged in the Law of the Lord. Followe theÅ¿e examples Sir: Å¿end PaÅ¿tors throughout all the borders of your kingdome, to teache your Å¿ubiects the Law of their Lord, and the GoÅ¿pell of their Å¿aluation, eÅ¿tabliÅ¿he Religion and IuÅ¿tice in all the citties of your Kingdome. CauÅ¿e the Zach. 14 8 9. waters of life to runne froÌ the heart of your countrie, vnto the borders thereof, that publickly and priuately, the Lorde may be but one, and his name one, and he may be a Å¿oueraigne King in all your land, as it was prophecied and promiÅ¿ed. EÅ¿tabliÅ¿he PaÅ¿tors in all your Kingdome, Å¿trengthen them in their offices, and Å¿peake to their hearts. Prouyde for their maintenance, that they be not diÅ¿tracted, but may be encouraged in the Law of their God, and in the execution of their miniÅ¿trie. And when it is reported to your MaieÅ¿ty, or ye heare of any, be they many, or be they fewe, be they man, or be they wife, be it publictly, or be it Å¿ecretly, in any of the citties or parts in your MaieÅ¿ties Kingdome, that they haue gone out to entiÅ¿e others to Idolatry, or hes committed Idolatry themÅ¿elues,
ye try it, Å¿earche it, and Å¿eeke it out moÅ¿t diligently, for Å¿o the Lord hes moÅ¿t Å¿traitly commanded. And if it be true & certaine, that Å¿ik abhomination is done in your kingdom; take euill out of IÅ¿rael, that he may haue mercy on vs, and multiply his bliÅ¿sings to vs. And then may ye Sir, (hauing done all theÅ¿e things) take God to recorde, that you are cleane from the blood of all your people, becauÅ¿e you haue kept no meane back from theÌ, whilk your calling craued, but hes cauÅ¿ed the whole counÅ¿el of God to be Å¿hewed to them: Å¿o that if they periÅ¿he their owne blood may be vpon their owne heades. And then Å¿hall forraine nations and Å¿trangers Å¿ay of you Sir, as Reg. 5 7. Hiram, and the Queene of Sheba Å¿aide of Salomon, BliÅ¿Å¿ed Reg 10.8.9. be the Lord God who hes Å¿et Å¿ik a wiÅ¿e and vnderÅ¿tanding Prince ouer Scotland, to builde his Kirk, and to exerciÅ¿e iuÅ¿tice & iudgement there, it was for the loue the Lord had to his Kirk there, that he Å¿et Å¿ik a wiÅ¿e and vnderÅ¿taÌding Prince ouer them. Yea, PÅ¿al. 78, 4. the generations to come, Å¿hal tell to their children, and their childrens children, the great work of the Lord, whilk he hes done by you, Sir, in this land. I haue heard your MaieÅ¿ty grauely proteÅ¿t, before God, in two generall aÅ¿Å¿emblies, that it was one of your MaieÅ¿ties greateÅ¿t deÅ¿ires, and ye were euen, as it were, ambitious of that worke, to plant euery Parochin within your kingdome, with a PaÅ¿tor: that the poÅ¿terities to come, might Å¿ay, King IAMES the Å¿ext, hes done Å¿ik a notable worke in his dayes. Confirme your Å¿elf, Sir, in that purpoÅ¿e: for ye know, Sir, who hes Å¿aid, 1. Sam. 2.30. I will honour them that honors mee. There is no queÅ¿tion, Sir, and I Å¿peake with confidence, if ye honour him in this kingdome, and be faithfull to him in the gouernement of it, he Å¿hal honour you: not only by making you to raigne in that euerlaÅ¿ting kingdome, but alÅ¿o by lifting you vp to bee
rewler ouer moe Kingdomes heir. The Lord annoynted Dauid King ouer all IÅ¿rael: yet he gaue not the poÅ¿seÅ¿sion of it al at once, after the death of Saul, but firÅ¿t proued him with the gouernement of one Tribe Å¿eauen yeares and a halfe, & then finding him faithfull ouer that, he placed him rewler ouer all the reÅ¿t, & eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed all IÅ¿rael in his hand. So there is no queÅ¿tion, and I am Å¿ure of it, if ye honour the Lorde to the vttermoÅ¿te of your power, in the gouernement of this kingdome, and giue him a proofe of your fidelity therein: that as he hes giuen you the vndoubted right by birth, to bee a King ouer moe Kingdomes then this, Å¿o Å¿hall he make you rewler of them, and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h them in your hands: onely Sir, IoÅ¿ua 1.6.7.8.9. be ye Å¿trong and couragious to do with al diligence as the Lord hes commanded you in his worde, and as ye Å¿ee theÅ¿e faithfull Kings hes done before you. Decline neither to the right hand, nor to the left, & then aÅ¿Å¿uredly I dare promiÅ¿e you in the name of the Lord, hee Å¿hall not leaue you or forÅ¿ake you al your dayes, and none Å¿hall be able to Å¿tand before your face And as he was with IoÅ¿ua and Dauid, Å¿o Å¿hall he be with you. For the Lord is true who hes promiÅ¿ed, and then Å¿halt thou proÅ¿per in all thy waies. And conÅ¿ider vpon the other part who euer proÅ¿pered vnto the end, but theÅ¿e that walked as the Lord had commanded. For true is that whilk the Lorde Å¿pake by his Prophet to AÅ¿a, 2. Chro. 1.4 2. He is with you while ye be with him, and if ye Å¿eeke him, he wil be found but if ye will forÅ¿ake him, he will forÅ¿ake you. Was the Lord any longer with Saule, IoaÅ¿h, Amazia, Vzzia, al Kings of Iuda, then they were with him? No, no: but from time they forÅ¿ooke him, he forÅ¿ooke them. BecauÅ¿e Saule 1. Sam. 15 23. & 16.15. deÅ¿piÅ¿ed the word of the Lorde, in Å¿paring whome he Å¿hould not haue Å¿pared, the Lord deÅ¿piÅ¿ed him from being
King ouer IÅ¿raell, and the Spirite of the Lorde forÅ¿ooke him. BecauÅ¿e IoaÅ¿he forÅ¿ooke the Lord, 2. Chro. 24 20. in permitting Idolatrie at the requeÅ¿t of his princes, the Lord forÅ¿ooke him and his kingdome, and deliuered them into the hands of their enemies. BecauÅ¿e Amatzia did euill, and obeyed 2 Cro. â¢ 5.16. not the councell of the Prophet, when he admoniÅ¿hed him, the Lorde determined to deÅ¿troy him. Vzzia al the 2. Cro. 26.5.16.18. dayes that he Å¿ought the Lord, the Lorde proÅ¿pered him, but froÌ time he lifted vp himÅ¿elfe to corrupt himÅ¿elf, and to treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t the Lord his God, in paÅ¿Å¿ing the limites of his calling, and inuading the PrieÅ¿ts office, he had no honour of the Lord but was Å¿mitten with leaproÅ¿ie. But let all theÅ¿e things be farre from your MaieÅ¿tie, Å¿ince you Å¿ee what euerie one of theÅ¿e hes done to Kings and Kingdomes before you, let your hearte be conÅ¿tant before the Lord your God all the dayes of your life, that priores 2. Cro. 25.26. & poÅ¿teriores, be neuer regiÅ¿trate of your MaieÅ¿tie as it was of them, neither in the bookes of the Lordes coÌmentary before him, neither in the Chronicles of the kings of Scotland, but that both your former & latter may be that whilk is good and right in the eyes of the Lord. That both the Lorde may giue this teÅ¿timonye to your owne conÅ¿cience, and to the conÅ¿cience of all his children, that hee gaue of Dauid, I haue founde you a man according to my owne hart that will doe all my will: and alÅ¿o, that it may be written of your MaeiÅ¿tie in the Chronicles of the Kings of Scotland as it was written of Dauid, Ezechias, IoÅ¿ias, in the Chronicles of the Kings of Iuda, that King IAMES the Å¿ext, his harte was perÅ¿ite toward the Lorde his God all his dayes, and his gouernement was in Å¿ik peace and IuÅ¿tice, that after him there was none like him of al
the Kings of Scotland: neither was there any Å¿ik before him, who did cleaue vnto the Lord his God, with all his heart, and followed all his commandements, and neither declined to the right hand, nor to the left. Nowe the Lord graunt to your MaieÅ¿ty, that yee may finde this fauour in his eies for his ChriÅ¿ts Å¿ake. I haue nowe taken this boldeneÅ¿Å¿e, to offer theÅ¿e my labours vnto your MaieÅ¿tie: as a teÅ¿timony of my moÅ¿te humble, and loyall hart vnto your MaieÅ¿tie, as God the Å¿earcher of the heart knowes. Your MaieÅ¿tie did exceedingly encourage mee, to let it goe forth vnto the light, what by your MaieÅ¿ties moÅ¿te gracious acceptation of my indeuour, and moÅ¿te fauourable cenÅ¿ure, and approbation of my laboures: what by your MaieÅ¿ties humane counÅ¿ell and aduiÅ¿e, confirmed by your MaieÅ¿ties Priuiledge and authoritie to mee to publiÅ¿he the Å¿ame. Sik was your MaieÅ¿ties humanitie to mee, not onely in theÅ¿e, but in all your actions, both publick and priuate, with all your Å¿ubiects, of whatÅ¿omeuer ranke or degree. Ye kyith Å¿ik humanitie and affabilitie, that that Å¿aying of Trajanus the Emperour, that a Prince Å¿huld be haue himÅ¿elf Å¿o to his Å¿ubiects, as he would haue theÌ to doe to him, if he were a priuate man, is verefied in you, Sir, wherein certainelie ye need not to giue place to any of whatÅ¿omeuer ranke: you expres it Å¿o liuelie in al your actions, & I haue found it for my owne parte by experience. So that your MaieÅ¿tie hes often cauÅ¿ed me to remember, that notable Å¿aying of Titus that Romane Emperour, A Å¿ubject Å¿hould neuer goe Å¿ad hearted from the Å¿peach of his Prince: The whilk experience makes me to conceaue hope, that your MaieÅ¿tie will pardon this my boldeneÅ¿Å¿e, will accept in good part this my Å¿mall myte. I therefore moÅ¿t humblie deÅ¿ire your MaieÅ¿tie to accept it, as from your MaieÅ¿ties moÅ¿te humble
obedient Å¿eruant and Å¿ubiect. For whoÅ¿e peace and proÅ¿peritie, I am alwaies earneÅ¿t with the Lorde. Now the God of all peace, euen that King of Kings, powre all light and grace in all aboundance, more and more, vpon your MaieÅ¿tie, and Å¿o roote and ground your heart in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, that ye may honour him more and more in your life and calling heir, that ye may be honoured of him againe, both in this life, and in that day with immortall and euerlaÅ¿ting glorie. Amen. From Aire the 18. of Nouember. 1602.

closer.signed: Your MaieÅ¿ties moÅ¿te humble Å¿ubiect M. IOHN WELSCHE.

div.head: Vnto the godly and ChriÅ¿tian Reader in this land, Grace, mercie and peace, from God the Father, and IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t his Sonne our Lord and onelie Sauiour. Amen.
div.p:
WHen I thinke, ChriÅ¿tian Reader, of the vnÅ¿earchable mercies, (for Å¿o I may call them) whilk the Lord, according to his rich grace, whereby he hes bene aboundant towards vs, (if euer towardes any) hes vouchÅ¿aued vpon vs: and of our great ingratitude and manifold iniquities wherewith we haue recompenÅ¿ed him againe: I cannot but tremble to think of theÅ¿e moÅ¿t fearfull iudgements of God, whilk we haue moÅ¿t iuÅ¿tly deÅ¿erued, and whilk cannot but moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿uredly fall vpon vs, vnleÅ¿Å¿e with moÅ¿te Å¿peedie and earneÅ¿t repentance of al Å¿ortes, they be preuented and auerted. Eph. â¢ .8. For vnto what kingdome or nation vnder heauen, hes God beene more liberall in communicating, the InÅ¿earchable riches of his deare Å¿on in his GoÅ¿pel, as vnto vs in this nation. Nay, vnto what one kingdome vnder heauen hes God beene Å¿o rich and Å¿uperaboundant in mercy, as vnto this? There are but fewe kingdomes vpon whome the Lord hes cauÅ¿ed the glorious light of his GoÅ¿pel to Å¿hine vpon, a groÅ¿Å¿e darkneÅ¿Å¿e couering the moÅ¿te part of the kingdomes of the earth: and yet Scotland hes found this fauour in the eies of the moÅ¿te high God. So that, that may be moÅ¿t truely Å¿aid of vs, whilk is written of the land of Zebulon and Naphtali, Math. 4.1 â¢ . A people that Å¿ate in darkneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿awe great light, and vnto them whilk Å¿ate in the region of death, light is riÅ¿en vp. Many kingdomes vpon whome this light is riÅ¿en, are but in parte deliuered from the bondage of that Reu. 13.11. & 17.4. Å¿econd beaÅ¿t, and from that abhomination of Babel, a part worÅ¿hipping the Lord, and a part worÅ¿hipping Baal, I meane the Idole of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, and their idoles of Å¿tock and Å¿tone. But our deliuerance was full, from that bondage: for that was fulfilled in vs whilk was promiÅ¿ed and prophecied of olde, Zach. 14.9. That the Lord Å¿hould be but one, and his name one And in theÅ¿e kingdomes where the Lord is but one, and his name one, that is, where he only is worÅ¿hipped, Å¿ome of them hes embraced him but as a Prophet, to teach them, and as a PrieÅ¿t to Å¿atisfie for their Å¿innes, and to interceede
for them: but not as a Å¿oueraigne king to rule them, and gouern them by that forme of gouernement, whilk he hes preÅ¿criued in his word, with his owne Lawes, offices, and officers, retayning yet a part of that hierarchie of Babel, with Å¿ome of her Lawes, offices, and officers. But the Lord was riche in mercy towards vs, in beÅ¿towing himÅ¿elf vpon vs, not only as a Prophet to teach vs, & as a PrieÅ¿t to Å¿atisfie for our Å¿innes, and to interceede for vs, but alÅ¿o as a Å¿oueraigne King, to gouerne vs with that Å¿elfe Å¿ame forme of gouernement, whilk he hes commanded in his worde, and vnto the whilk only he hes annexed the promiÅ¿es of his bliÅ¿Å¿in â¢ and preÅ¿ence, with his owne Lawes, offices, and officers. So that as the Prophet Å¿ayes, Zach. 14 â¢
he was not only one in vs, and his name one: but alÅ¿o a Å¿oueraigne King in our land.

O Scotland, what nation was like vnto thee, that had the GoÅ¿pel Å¿o freely preached, his Sacraments Å¿o purely miniÅ¿tred, his cenÅ¿ures and all the priuiledges of his kingdome, in Å¿ik liberty executed, as thou had? for what one nation vnder heauen, hes God done Å¿o great things, as for thee? What one kingdome is to be found in the whole earth, where Idolatry was Å¿o fully rooted out, wherein all the meanes of his glory, and all the priuiledges of his kingdome, was Å¿o fully reÅ¿tored to their owne integrity and perfection, as they were firÅ¿t inÅ¿tituted, wherein all theÅ¿e meanes of the word, Å¿acraments, and diÅ¿cipline, hes continued for Å¿o long a Å¿pace in Å¿ik peace, in Å¿ik purity, in Å¿ik libertie, without hereÅ¿ie or Å¿chiÅ¿me, as in thee, O Scotland. So that thy day hes bene like the day of IoÅ¿hua, IoÅ¿ua 10.12. When the Sunne Å¿toode in Gibeon, & the Moone in Aialon. For I know not if euer nation or kingdome hes had Å¿o long a day of the GoÅ¿pell, in Å¿ik peace, purity, and liberty, as thou hes had? or if euer nation after vs, Å¿hall haue Å¿o long a day, after Å¿ik a manner againe. And it Å¿eemes to me, that as the Lord confirmed EZechiah of his promiÅ¿e, by cauÅ¿ing 2. Reg. 20. the Sunne to returne back againe miraculouÅ¿ly, by the degrees whereby it went downe: So the Lord hes confirmed his Å¿uperaboundant loue towards vs, in cauÅ¿ing the light of the GoÅ¿pell to returne againe, (as it were) oft times and that moÅ¿t wonderfullie and miraculouÅ¿ly by the degrees wherby our iniquities in the righteous iudgment of God did haÅ¿ten it to goe downe vpon vs. Yea the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of Abraham hes commed vpon vs. For hee hes bleÅ¿Å¿ed them that bliÅ¿Å¿ed vs, and hes curÅ¿ed them who hes curÅ¿ed vs, he hes Å¿triuen againÅ¿t them who hes Å¿triuen againÅ¿t vs, and hes made our oppreÅ¿Å¿ors to eate their owne fleÅ¿h and to drinke their owne blood: no inÅ¿trument formed againÅ¿t thee, (O Kirk of Scotland) hes euer proÅ¿pered: and the tongue that hes riÅ¿en againÅ¿t thee, the Lord hes condemned, that all fleÅ¿h might know that God was thy Sauiour, and the Å¿trong God of Iacob thy auenger. And certainly, if euer people might haue ben called EÅ¿ai 62.6 Iephzibas, that is, the lords delite, or their land, and Beula, that is married vnto him, the Kirk and kingdome of Scotland might haue bene Å¿o called. For the Lord had delite in vs, and our land had a husband, euen the Lord our redeemer, he was EÅ¿a 60.1 â¢
a ornament vnto vs, he Å¿et Ezech. 16.14. his bewtie on vs, he EÅ¿ai. 62 crowned vs with glory, and a Diademe by the hand of our God, was Å¿et vpon our heades. And true is that of vs, whilk our Sauiour Å¿pake to his diÅ¿ciples, Luc. 10.24. Many Kings and Prophets hes
deÅ¿ired to Å¿ee the things that we haue Å¿eene, and heare the things that we haue heard, and hes not Å¿eene them, nor heard them. So who are Å¿o ladened with mercy and kindneÅ¿Å¿e as we haue bene? for we haue bene made Deut. 28.13 the head and not the taile, as the Lord promiÅ¿ed. And Å¿urely if euer people Å¿huld haue ben Deut. 32.15 to Å¿hurim, that is, vpright & Å¿treight in the eies of the Lord, we Å¿hould haue bene Å¿o. No, who Å¿hould haue bene Å¿o holy as we, who Å¿o ColoÅ¿. 2.7 Å¿trong in ChriÅ¿t, and rooted and grounded in him, as we? who Å¿o riche in all grace, and frutefull in all good workes, as we? For who had Å¿o manye and Å¿o glorious meanes, to haue made vs to haue abounded in all grace, as we had? What could the Lord EÅ¿ai 5.4 haue done more to vs, then he hes done? For we wanted no meane, that euer the lord coÌmanded in his word, either to haue bred grace in vs, or to haue preÅ¿erued it and encreaÅ¿ed it? But they to whome meikle is giuen, meikle Å¿hall be requyred at their hands againe. For as the Lorde made vs a Å¿pectacle of his mercy, wherein he did demonÅ¿trate the riches of his free grace in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, vnto all the kingdomes of the earth, and aboue them al. So it had bene our part proportionably, to haue met him with thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e againe: and to haue bene examples of all grace, godlineÅ¿Å¿e, righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and of all good works, vnto all others, and aboue all others. EÅ¿ai 1.4 But allace Å¿infull nation laden with iniquit â¢ es, who is Å¿o Å¿infull as thou art? What nation Å¿o polluted with all abhomination and wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, as thou art? thy iniquities are moe then the Å¿and of the Å¿ea, they are grown vp Å¿o high, HoÅ¿ea 9.7. that the top of them teaches vp to the very heaueÌs: & the cry of them is like, yea beyonde the cry of Sodome: there is Å¿ik a burthen of iniquity vpon this lande, that (conÅ¿idering all circumÅ¿tances both of the meanes, and of the time and Å¿pace the Lord hes giuen vs to repent) I know not if euer natioÌ, was Å¿o great in the eies of the Lord, as this land is. Ezechiel 22 For may not that whilk the Prophete Å¿pak of Iuda, be moÅ¿t iuÅ¿tly Å¿aid of thee, O Scotland: For art thou not repleniÅ¿hed with blood, from corner to corner, Å¿o that blood touches blood. Are not thy Nobles in thee, euery one ready to Å¿hed blood? In thee the father and the mother are deÅ¿piÅ¿ed: in the middes of thee, the widowe and the fatherleÅ¿Å¿e are oppreÅ¿Å¿ed: In thee, the very abhominations of the Gentiles ar committed. The diÅ¿couering of the Fathers Å¿hame, and adultery with thy neighbours wife: thou art Å¿o laden with adulteries, inceÅ¿ts, & whoredomes that the land grones vnder thee: thou haÅ¿t prophaned his Sabboths, deÅ¿piÅ¿ed his Lawe, contemned his GoÅ¿pell, withholden from him the fruits of his kingdome, and hes Å¿tramped vnder foote the blood of ChriÅ¿t, and hes grieued that Å¿pirite of grace. Matth. 21.41. So that when I think of the number and greatneÅ¿Å¿e of our Å¿innes, I cannot but wonder that the Lord Å¿hould not haue with drawne his Kingdome long Å¿ince from vs, and haue giuen it vnto others, that would haue brought foorth the frutes thereof. Yea, I wonder, that he hes not cauÅ¿ed the Land to vomite vs out, for the abhominations and Å¿innes wherewith we haue defiled it, in Å¿o great a light. And Å¿urely, when I think of the Å¿eueritie of the juÅ¿tice of God, in puniÅ¿hing other nations and kingdomes, for the contempt of his GoÅ¿pel, & the withholding of the fruits of his kingdome from him, my Å¿oule trembles. For, wherfore did the Lord reject the
naturall branches, that choÅ¿en generation, of whome the Fathers was, and of whome ChriÅ¿t was according to the fleÅ¿he, and gaue them and their poÅ¿terity ouer to the hardneÅ¿Å¿e of their hearts this 1500. Rom. 11.21. & 9.5 yeare and more, to be damned for euer and euer in that euerlaÅ¿ting darkneÅ¿Å¿e? and yet his wrath is not turned back: but becauÅ¿e they would not be gathered, & know not in that their day, the things that belonged to their peace, and woulde not rander to him the frutes of his kingdome in due Å¿eaÅ¿on. Mat. 23.37. Luc. 19.42 43. Mat 21 41. Reu. 2 5 2. TheÅ¿. 2.10.12. Reu 13.11. & 9 1. 2. TheÅ¿. â¢ .12. And wherefore did the Lord remooue his CandleÅ¿tick from a great many of the Kirks, both of the EaÅ¿t and the WeÅ¿t, who was planted by the ApoÅ¿tles, and was once lanterns of light, and hes giuen them ouer to Å¿trong deluÅ¿ions to beleeue lies: the one to the impiety of Mahomet, and the Å¿auadge tyrrant of the Kirk: the other to the bondage of that Å¿econd beaÅ¿t, and fearefull darkneÅ¿Å¿e of that bottomleÅ¿se pit. But becauÅ¿e they receaued not the loue of the trueth, but had pleaÅ¿ure in vnrighteouÅ¿nes as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayes. Now if God Å¿pared not them, but gaue them ouer to a moÅ¿t fearefull bondage both of Å¿oule and body, both Å¿pirituall and corporall, temporall and eternall: how Å¿hould we not feare, as great, or rather greater iudgements?
