â¢ atth. 9, 36 and the deceates of theÅ¿e rauenons wolfes, and their hands Å¿o ful of PapiÅ¿tical bookes, the deadly weapons of their own deÅ¿truction, without any one booke, almoÅ¿t, for ought that I know, wherby either theÅ¿e that are peruerted, may be reuoked froÌ their errors, or theÅ¿e that are aÅ¿Å¿aulted, may be Å¿uÅ¿tained from yeelding to the aduerÅ¿ary, or thoÅ¿e that are weake may be confirmed. Not vnlike the miÅ¿erable eÅ¿tate wherein the Hebrewes were brought vnto, throgh the tyranny of the PhiliÅ¿tims, wanting both Å¿word and Å¿peare in the time of their warfare, hauing no Å¿mithes in their whole land, 1 Sam. 13 19.20.22. whereby they were compelled to go to their enemies to Å¿harpen their Cowter, and Å¿ok, and other inÅ¿truments Now as for the worke it Å¿elf, I Å¿ay nothing of it, but only recommends it to the bliÅ¿Å¿ing of God in all your hearts and conÅ¿ciences. The whilk alÅ¿o hes bene my earneÅ¿t deÅ¿ire to God, from the firÅ¿t time that I put my haÌd to the pen coÌtinually, that his effectual preÅ¿ence might be ioyned therewith, both to convict the contrary minded, & to coÌ firme the godly Read ye it therefore with that affection of heart, wherewith it was written, and deÅ¿ire ye that bliÅ¿Å¿ing in the reading of it, as I did in the writing of it: and then I hope through Gods bliÅ¿Å¿ing, ye Å¿hall reape Å¿ome profite by it. Now the God of all mercy, and the Father of all light, illuminate all our eies more and more: and cauÅ¿e the light of his glorious GoÅ¿pell to Å¿hine in our hearts, and bleÅ¿Å¿e all the meanes thereof, that we may be the children of light heir, and may be partakers of that euerlaÅ¿ting waight of glory heira â¢ ter in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. Amen. From Aire the 18. Decemb. 1602.

closer.signed: Yours in the Lord, M. Iohn We Å¿che Preacher of ChriÅ¿ts GoÅ¿pell.

div.head: TO MAJSTER GJLBERT Browne PrieÅ¿t, defender of the RomiÅ¿h faith.
div.p:
I Receaued a booke of yours Å¿ent to me wherein is contained, partlye an anÅ¿were to a little Å¿crolle Å¿ent be me to a Catholick as ye name him: partlye your exhortation to mee, after the anÅ¿were, together with Å¿ome demands, whereof ye craue to be reÅ¿olued by me and my bretheren. Your anÅ¿were to my writing you haue Å¿ubÅ¿criued, Å¿o I Å¿ee you will Å¿tand by it: The other parte is not Å¿ubÅ¿criued. It is a lamentable and pitifull thing, to Å¿ee the glorious goÅ¿pell of his deare Sonne our Sauiour Å¿o obÅ¿cured and darkned in this country with the Reuel. 9.2 Å¿moke of that kingdome of darkneÅ¿Å¿e of yours, that hes aÅ¿cended & come out of the bottomles pit, to their eternall damnation, who is blinded and deceaued thereby. I haue Å¿orrow in my hart for it, and it is my earneÅ¿t deÅ¿ire to God the Father of our Lord IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, that once in his mercy, the Å¿moke of that fornace maye bee Å¿cattered by the light of his glorious GoÅ¿pell, and the beames thereof maye Å¿hyne in their owne Å¿trength and clearneÅ¿Å¿e in this blinded country, that is drunken with the Reuel, 17.2 2. TheÅ¿. 2.5 abhominations of that harlote of Babell, and deceaued with her Å¿trong deluÅ¿ions whereof ye are vÅ¿ed as the inÅ¿trument in the Lordes IuÅ¿tice: that as the reÅ¿t of the land hes riÅ¿en that firÅ¿t Revel. 20.5 reÅ¿urrection from the death of her darkneÅ¿Å¿e and her abhominations: Å¿o this country may alÅ¿o be partaker of the Å¿ame, that in that great day they may riÅ¿e that Å¿econd reÅ¿urrection to life and glory. I beleeue & therefore I Å¿peak, & that with confidence and aÅ¿Å¿urance knowing by his worde, that Reuel. 14.8. Babel muÅ¿t fall
as the Reuel. 11, 13. tenth parte of it is fallen alreadie. The Reuel. 17.10 whoore muÅ¿t bee made naked and deÅ¿olate, and her fleÅ¿h muÅ¿te be eaten vp. For true is the Lord who hes foretolde it, & that God who condemnes her is a Å¿trong God, therefore Reu. 18, 8.5. her plagues Å¿hal Å¿al vpon her at once, death, famine and Å¿orrow: for her Å¿innes are come vp vnto heauen, Reu. 17.4. Col. 2.23, 2. Tim. 3.5. Reu. 17.4.2. & 18.3.4.24. & God hath remembred her iniquities. And Å¿uppoÅ¿e the cupe wherin Å¿he reached her fornications & abhominations to be drunken out of, be of golde, hauing a Å¿hew of holineÅ¿Å¿e & voluntary religion, yet the drink that is in it, is abhomination and Idolatry, wherewith Å¿he hes corrupted the earth, and made the nations drunken therewith. Let all the children of God therefore, that loues to be Å¿aued, forÅ¿ake her, and goe out of her, leaÅ¿t they be partaker of her iniquities and of her iudgements alÅ¿o: for her iudgement is pierced through to the heauens, and is lifted vp to the vppermoÅ¿te cloudes. In vaine therefore doth anye man goe aboute to cure her with balme, for Å¿he cannot be healed. It is al but in vaine to you MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, or any man elÅ¿e, to diÅ¿play her banner vpon her walles, to Å¿trengthen her keepers, to appoynt her watchmeÌ, to prouid for her Å¿pyes, for the Lord hes both thought it, and will performe that whilk he hes Å¿poken againÅ¿t her. The Lord is to recompence her, all the euil that Å¿he hath done to Sion; and his holy Temple, and the Saintes therein: for their blood is found in her. The Lord hes Å¿worne by him Å¿elf, euen he that made the earth by his vertue, that eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed the world by his wiÅ¿edome, and Å¿tretched out the heauens by his prudencie: and yet man is Å¿o brutiÅ¿he that he will not vnderÅ¿tand, and Å¿o bewitched with her pleaÅ¿ures, that hee will not beleeue it. I beÅ¿eech God who is able to quicken the dead, and to open the eyes of the blinde, and to cal the things that are not, to be: to open your eyes that you may vnderÅ¿tand and beleeue theÅ¿e things, and to glorifie his owne name in your conuerÅ¿ion vnto the trueth, and if it be poÅ¿sible, for ye haue cauÅ¿ed many to erre: and as Ieroboam cauÅ¿ed the people to Å¿inne, becauÅ¿e he Å¿tayed them from coÌ ming vp to IeruÅ¿alem, to haue worÅ¿hipped God aright, and made them to worÅ¿hip Idoles in their owne lande: So haue you done great iniquitie, and hes Å¿taied Å¿undry of the Lords
people to come to mount Sion, the Kirk of God: where there they might haue learned his wayes, Reuel. 17 â¢â¢
â¢ 8. and walked in the Å¿ame yea, whilk is worÅ¿e, yee are the cauÅ¿e that many doe worÅ¿hip the abhomination of Babell, your rounde breade in your abhominable MaÅ¿Å¿e: & your woodden & Å¿tonie Idoles: and by the deceite of that golden cupe, ye make them drinke of the deadly poyÅ¿on of the Å¿pirituall fornications, and abhominations of that harlote. And as the Lord put an impure Å¿pirit of errour in the mouth of Achabs falÅ¿e Prophets, to entiÅ¿e him to goe vp to Ramoch Giliad, that he might periÅ¿h thereby, becauÅ¿e the Lord had Å¿poken euill againÅ¿t him, who entiÅ¿ed and preuailed alÅ¿o. So hes the Lord put an impure Å¿pirit, and a Å¿pirite of error in your mouth, 2. TheÅ¿. 2. and in the mouthes of the reÅ¿t of her falÅ¿e Prophets, to entiÅ¿e Å¿o many, as loues not the trueth in this Å¿infull country to beleeue your lyes, and to be deceaued with your Å¿trong deluÅ¿ions: that all theÅ¿e might be damned whilk had pleaÅ¿ure in vnrighteouÅ¿nes, as the Lorde foretolde in the 2 TheÅ¿. 2. O that ye had an harte to turne to God, that as ye haue beene a Å¿tumbling blocke to many, to cauÅ¿e many to fal with you to the damnation of their Å¿oules; So ye may be by your conuerÅ¿ion to the trueth of God, the inÅ¿trument of the ryÅ¿ing of many againe. O that treaÅ¿ure of wrath that yee haue hoorded vp againÅ¿te your Å¿elfe in that greate day: for Sathan hes wrought effectually by you, if euer by any in this land, with all power, & in all deceaueablenes of vnrighteouÅ¿nes amongÅ¿t them that periÅ¿h. For curÅ¿ed is he, and the Lord commanded to proclaime it in mount Heball, that cauÅ¿es the blinde to turne out of the way, and let all the people Å¿ay, Amen. Deut. 27. What curÅ¿e of the Lorde is then abyding you, who thinkes it good Å¿eruice to God to cauÅ¿e the blinde to wander, and turne away from the lighte of the GoÅ¿pell; whilk is the words of eternall life to all them that beleeues. Oh remember, and lay it to your hart, the eternity of damnation. It is hard for you to kick againÅ¿t the pricke: the Å¿tone of the trueth that ye Å¿tumble at, will cruÅ¿he you all in peeces at the laÅ¿t. Shut not your eyes at the clear light of life and grace, & harden not your hearte while it is called the day. And while yee are in the waye with your aduerÅ¿ary
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
be reconciled to him: for the Lorde and his trueth againÅ¿te whome you fight is aduerÅ¿aries vnto you, or and euer yee enter in at the portes and gates of hell, and be caÅ¿ten in that priÅ¿on and giuen ouer to that iayler, you will neuer come out againe whill you haue payed the vttermoÅ¿t farthing, and that will be neuer, for it is eternitye of paines. Allace you deceaue others being deceaued your Å¿elf, as the holy ghoÅ¿t foretolde it. 2. T m. 3.13. That euill men Å¿hould waxe worÅ¿e and worÅ¿e, deceauing and being deceaued. The Lorde take away the vaile that is hung ouer your harte, that yee maye bee turned to the eternall weill of your owne Å¿oule, and the Å¿aluation of many that is blindlings led by you to the bottomleÅ¿Å¿e pit of condemnation. BecauÅ¿e I haue compaÅ¿sion on you, & on this miÅ¿erable country, therfore this writ I vnto you. Fot allace who can bide it to be baniÅ¿hed for euermore from Å¿uch a wonderfull and euerlaÅ¿ting weight of glory, from the fellowÅ¿hipe of the Lambe, and of all his glorified creaturs, man and Angell? who can compaÅ¿Å¿e the eternitie of damnation in that vtter darkneÅ¿Å¿e, where there Å¿hall be weeping and gnaÅ¿hing of teeth for euermore? who can tell their terrors? who can nomber their Å¿orrowes, who can reckon and count the eternal woes of the damned. Be not cruell to your own Å¿oule and the Å¿oules of your owne country men, loue not yours and their eternall damnation. Beleeue the Scripture & be not incredulous. Without that citie of God, that new IeruÅ¿alem, Å¿hal be dogges, inchanters, murtherers, and idolaters: and whoÅ¿oeuer loueth & maketh lyes. Reuel. 22. Yea, their portion Å¿hall bee in that lake that burneth with fire and brimÅ¿tone, whilk is the Å¿econde death. Either wonderous blinded and indured muÅ¿t you be, or elÅ¿e in your owne conÅ¿cience you know your Kirk & your Å¿elues to be murtherers of Å¿oules, Idolaters, luiffers and makers of lyes. For the vphold of the credite of your religion, and that not be the writtings of your enemies, but of your freinds men of your owne profeÅ¿sion: yea, by your owne latine Å¿eruice Å¿et out in your owne bookes, for yee worÅ¿hip not the one true God in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t through his Å¿pirite, but as Ieremie Å¿ayes of the Idolaters in his time, according to the nomber of your
cities ye haue increaÅ¿ed the nomber of your God â¢ , and hes turned the glory of the incorruptible God, in the Å¿imilitude and Image of corruptible creatures, & paÅ¿sing by the creator, whilk is bliÅ¿Å¿ed for euer, worÅ¿hips the creatures, Saints and Angels, Å¿tockes and Å¿tones and a peece of bread, oyle, and water, bones, and relickes, the skurfe skarfe of all things: yea and your head the man of Å¿inne and Å¿onne of perdition, (who is called God in your canon law, DiÅ¿t. 96. Satis euidenter and whome your canoniÅ¿ts calles, the Lorde God) the Pope, and to whome is giuen theÅ¿e thinges, that is peculiar & proper onely to IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t: whilk by the grace of God Å¿hall appeare clearely, in our diÅ¿putatioÌ following. For there is as direct oppoÅ¿ition betwixt your heade & IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, betwixt your religion and his, as is betwixt light and darknes, ChriÅ¿t and Beliall, the doctrine of diuels & the doctrine of Å¿aluation. But the Lords iudgements are vnÅ¿earchable and his wayes paÅ¿t finding out: he hardens whome hee will and hes mercy on whome he will. I thought it Å¿urely the Lordes good prouidence, that he hes broght you out into the campe now, and that nowe by write ye haue Å¿et your foote into the battle, who hes beene Å¿ik a Å¿ore enemie to the goÅ¿pell of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t in this country, and hes reÅ¿iÅ¿ted the preaching of it vehemently, that it may be Å¿eene that darkneÅ¿Å¿e was but your Å¿trength, and lyes the foundation of your religion. But I leaue you to the Lord. Now as for that Å¿crowe of mine, as ye call it, if it was Å¿o as you Å¿et it downe heir, there hes beene Å¿ome little eÅ¿capes in Å¿cribendo, in the writting. In the laÅ¿te Å¿ection (as I haue marked in yours heir and there, as may be Å¿eene in Å¿undry places) whilk I haue corrected in this my anÅ¿wer as 1258. for 1158. next 129. for 1290. & Iames Gyles a threatning Friar, for to Iohn Geillis: and the Kirk of Grecia whilk with the reÅ¿te of the Greeke and EaÅ¿terne Kirks was moe nor the Kirks of Europe. And heereby are your marginall notes whilk was aboue theÅ¿e places anÅ¿wered. Nowe as for the firÅ¿t parte of your booke wherein ye anÅ¿were to that whilk I write, I haue anÅ¿wered it heir, and as for your exhortation, and demands of me and my brethren, Å¿uppoÅ¿e it bee Å¿o fooliÅ¿h and friuolous (as euery one that hes but a Å¿parke
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
of iudgement may Å¿ee) that it is worthie no anÅ¿were at al, for a more bairnely, fooliÅ¿h, and friuolous writting, red I neuer, yet you Å¿hall haue it by gods grace: but I waite firÅ¿te to Å¿ee if you will anÅ¿were ought to this my reply. I haue Å¿et downe your anÅ¿were fullie, and hes anÅ¿wered to euery poynt & argument Å¿euerally: the like now MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert I deÅ¿ire of you that if euer you can be able to put to your hand to make an anÅ¿were, that you Å¿et down mine word for word, & anÅ¿were euerie head and poynt thereof Å¿euerally, as I haue Å¿et them downe heir, and Å¿hew what you graunt, and what you denie in euerie head, and argument as I haue done in yours: otherwaies, I wil take it for no anÅ¿were, but for a manifeÅ¿t demonÅ¿tration that ye are convicted in your conÅ¿cience of the truth of our doctrine and of the falÅ¿et of your owne religion. The two heades concerning the MaÅ¿Å¿e and AntichriÅ¿t, I haue put them in a Å¿euerall treatiÅ¿e, whilk I haue annexed to this: and that both becauÅ¿e they are the corner Å¿tones and fundamentall poynts of your religion, and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e vvhen I offered to diÅ¿proue them in word, whilk you Å¿hifted of vnder this pretence onely, becauÅ¿e there vvas a brother of the miniÅ¿terie vvith me, vvhome ye vvould not Å¿uffer to be preÅ¿ent; to be a vvitneÅ¿Å¿e and penner of our diÅ¿putation only: but would haue him remoued from the hearing of it altogether: notvvithÅ¿tanding that it vvas promiÅ¿ed faithfullie, both by him and mee, and al the gentlemen that vvas preÅ¿ent, offered as caution, that he Å¿hould not Å¿peake a Å¿illabe, neither Å¿ecreitlie nor openly, during all the time of our diÅ¿putation; but only be a witnes and penner of our conference vpon my part, ye hauing alÅ¿o both MaiÅ¿ter George Ker, & another to haue written for your part, and nothing to be vvritten, but that whilk Å¿hould be Å¿ubÅ¿criued by both parties. You not daring face your own cauÅ¿e, vpon Å¿o equal conditions, you deÅ¿ired to Å¿et them dovvne in vvrite, the vvhilk I haue done heir. Novve the Lord open your eyes to Å¿ee the truth for ChriÅ¿ts Å¿ake. Amen. From Kirkcudbright the 6. of AuguÅ¿t. 1599.

closer.signed: M. Iohn WelÅ¿che preacher of ChriÅ¿ts goÅ¿pell at AIRE.

div.head: The principall points handled in this firÅ¿t part, are theÅ¿e
div.p: 1. THat the Kirk of Rome is not the Catholick Kirk, in no reÅ¿pect, as they vaunt of themÅ¿elues, but a particular Kirk: and that impure, rotten, dead, & AntichriÅ¿tian.

2. That the Kirk of ChriÅ¿t both may erre, and hes erred in al ages, before the law vnder the law, in the time of ChriÅ¿t, after his aÅ¿cenÅ¿ion, in all ages, aÅ¿well Å¿everallie, as iointly, in councels both Prouinciall, and generall: and that the Kirk of Rome, and their heades the Popes of Rome, hes moÅ¿t foullie erred.

3. That the falÅ¿et of the Religion of the Kirk of Rome may be Å¿ufficientlie made manifeÅ¿t by comparing the doctrine of the Kirk of Rome, with the doctrine of ChriÅ¿t and his ApoÅ¿tles, Å¿et downe in the Scripture, Å¿uppoÅ¿e all the reÅ¿t of the circumÅ¿tances of changes and mutations, as the firÅ¿t perÅ¿on, time place and Å¿o forth be not diÅ¿tinctly Å¿et down in hiÅ¿tories.

4. The authour, time, place, and Å¿o forth of the reÅ¿te of the circumÅ¿tances of the change of the doctrine of the Kirk of Rome, is Å¿et downe diÅ¿tinctlieâª firÅ¿t, as the Scripture foretolde it, and alÅ¿o Å¿ome of the auncients and hiÅ¿toriographers, in Å¿ome particular heades, hes noted out theÅ¿e circumÅ¿tances.

5. That our Religion was neither firÅ¿t invented by Martine Luther, nor yet firÅ¿t preached by him, but was inÅ¿t tuted by ChriÅ¿t in his Scripture, and was profeÅ¿Å¿ed by his ApoÅ¿tles, and the Primitiue Kirk, and the true Kirk of ChriÅ¿t in all ages. And that hee departed not from the true Kirk, but from the Å¿ocietie of Babel, and the peÅ¿t of that AntichriÅ¿tian kingdome: & that he had the Lord IeÅ¿us, his ApoÅ¿tles, and all the primitiue Kirk, and all theÅ¿e that profeÅ¿Å¿ed the true Religion, to be his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors.

6. Who Å¿hould be Å¿upreeme iudge in all controverÅ¿ies of religion: to wit, the Lord IeÅ¿us in his word, and not the Pope and his councell, as they Å¿ay: and the true cauÅ¿e wherfore they decline the Lord, both to be Iudge in his word, & witneÅ¿Å¿e in his authentick Å¿cripture the Hebrew and Greeke fountaines, and will haue none to be iudges, but themÅ¿elues, their owne Popes, the fathers and forgers of their owne religion, becauÅ¿e they both knowe in their conÅ¿cience that the principall points of their doctrine is not written, or warranted in the Scriptures of God. And alÅ¿o Å¿ome of themÅ¿elues through the forcible conviction of the trueth, hes bene compelled to grant, and to Å¿et it downe in write, that the principall pointes and foundaments of their Religion, hes not their authour, origen, nor beginning in the Å¿cripture, nor cannot be warranted and defended by the Å¿ame: and therefore they knowe aÅ¿Å¿uredlie, that if the Popes be not admitted to be iudge in their owne cauÅ¿e, their Religion will be gone.

7. That the whole certaintie of all their doctrine and religion, and of the doctrine of the Scriptures, by their owne confeÅ¿Å¿ion, depends vpon the teÅ¿timonie of the preÅ¿ent Kirk: that is, the preÅ¿ent Popes, and his Cleargie: and that the certaintie both of our doctrine, that it is of God, and alÅ¿o of the diuinitie of the Scriptures, depends not vpon the teÅ¿timonie of the Kirk of Rome, for that were a weake threed, nor of the teÅ¿timonie of anie Kirk only or principallie, but vpon other moÅ¿t infallible grounds.

8. Sundry points of doctrine controuerted amongÅ¿t vs, whilk were caÅ¿ten in as examples by M. Gilbert, to proue that his religion was warranted in the Scripture, and ours not warranted by the Å¿ame As 1. the abÅ¿olute neceÅ¿Å¿itie of BaptiÅ¿me. 2. Freewill, and the poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie to keepe the commandements of God abÅ¿olutelie and perfitely. 3. TranÅ¿ubÅ¿tantiation. 4. The authority of PrieÅ¿ts to forgiue Å¿innes. 5. The Sacraments of extreame vnction, impoÅ¿ition of hands, and of marriage. 6. That the band of marriage is d Å¿Å¿oluble for the cauÅ¿e of adulterie. 7. Merites of workes. 8, Works of Å¿upererogation. 9 ChriÅ¿ts locall deÅ¿cenÅ¿ion to Hell. 10. IuÅ¿tification by works. All whilks are moÅ¿t euidentlie convicted and confuted by the teÅ¿timonies of the Scripture: and manie of them alÅ¿o by the teÅ¿timonies of the auncient Fathers, and Å¿ome of their owne teÅ¿timonies of Popes, Cardinals, Doctors, and others.

9. That Fathers cannot be iudges of the controuerÅ¿ies of Religion, not yet the expoÅ¿ition
of the Scriptures Å¿hould be tried by them: but onlie the Scripture to be exponed by Scripture: and their expoÅ¿itions in Å¿o far forth to be embraced, as they aggree with them. And that both becauÅ¿e they may erre, hes erred, and alÅ¿o their expoÅ¿itions diÅ¿Å¿ents one from another: and this is proued both by the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿ome of the Fathers and Å¿ome of the moÅ¿te learned PapiÅ¿ts
10. That the Apocrypha is not Canonicall Scripture, whilk is alÅ¿o prooued by the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿ome of their owne Popes, Cardinalles, and Doctors.
11. That the defection foretolde in the Scripture in the â¢ ime of the AntichriÅ¿t, Å¿hould be a vniuerÅ¿all defection of all Å¿orts, except the elect.

12. That the Kirk of ChriÅ¿t in the time of the AntichriÅ¿ts defection and tyrannie, Å¿houlde be redacted to a Å¿mall handfull, and Å¿hould be latent, & lurke, for to eÅ¿cape his cruelty and tyrannie.

13. That the Å¿pace of 1260. daies wherein the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hould raigne, and the nomber of the true WitneÅ¿Å¿es of God that Å¿hould preach the truth all that time, the Å¿pace of their preaching, their cloathing, the place of the ignominious handling of their carcaÅ¿es, and their reviving and aÅ¿cending vp to heauen, as they are Å¿et downe in the Reuelation, is to be vnderÅ¿tood not literallie, as MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert does, but figuratiuelie after the cuÅ¿tome of theÅ¿e prophecies in this Revelation.

14. That the Popes are not the head of the Kirk, nor acknowledged by the Kirks in al ages to be the head thereof: but his Monarchie is condemned by ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, and his ApoÅ¿tles in his word, by the Fathers of the Primitiue Kirk, by fiue Å¿undry Prouinciall councels, and by nine generall Councels, and by fiue VniuerÅ¿ities, and by the Kirks of Grecia, AÅ¿ia, MoÅ¿couia, Aethiopia, Boeme, Piemont, and all the reformed Kirks throughout Europe, Å¿o that if it were but put to an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of theÅ¿e, his Monarchie would be condemned.

15. That the Catholick Kirk is inviÅ¿ible, and in what reÅ¿pects we affirme Å¿he is inviÅ¿ible, & that the particular viÅ¿ible Kirks heir, may be obÅ¿cured, rare, and brought to Å¿ik a few handfull, that they are not openlie knowne and Å¿eene to all: but onlie Å¿ome of them amongeÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, and Å¿ome of them to their perÅ¿ecuters, as it was foretolde in the Scriptures of God in the time of the AntichriÅ¿t, and as it hes bene accompliÅ¿hed in the time of Popery.

16. That our Religion was preached and profeÅ¿Å¿ed in all ages, by ChriÅ¿t, his ApoÅ¿tles, the primitiue Kirk, the auncient Fathers, and by Å¿undrie in the middes of Poperie, who were condemned and perÅ¿ecuted, and put to death manie of them, for Å¿peaking againÅ¿t their doctrine, and that manie hundreth yeares before Ma â¢ tine Luther, & Å¿ome immediatlie before him.

17. That we haue renued no old condemned hereÅ¿ies, but theÅ¿e that he aÅ¿criues to vs, either are not hereÅ¿ies in deid, but warranted by the Scripture, or elÅ¿e we doe condemne them as hereÅ¿ies, and deteÅ¿ts them more then they: wherof Å¿ome of them doth alÅ¿o better aggree to themÅ¿elues.
18. That they are they in verie truth, who hes renewed the old hereÅ¿ies, of old hereticks whilk are condemned in the word of God, and that to the number of 40 and moe.

div.head: A replie againÅ¿t MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert Browne prieÅ¿t.

div.p: Ane anÅ¿were to ane certaine Libell or Writing, Å¿ent by M. IOHN WELSCHE to ane Catholicke, Tytle. as ane anÅ¿were to ane obiection of the Romane Kirk. &c.

I receaued ane little skroll, whilk was Å¿ent to you by M. Iohn WelÅ¿che MiniÅ¿ter at Kirkeudbricht, in the whilk, there is meikle promiÅ¿ed, and little done. And becauÅ¿e it may appeare to Å¿ome to be Å¿omething, I will (God willing) anÅ¿were the Å¿ame in particular.

AS to your iudgement and cenÅ¿ure of this my anÅ¿were to your obiection, wherein ye think there is meikle promiÅ¿ed and little done: I doe not regard it, for Å¿o long as your harte is bewitched with the pleaÅ¿ures of Babell, your light is but darknes: Å¿o while the Lorde annoynt your eyes, with that eye-Å¿alue promiÅ¿ed in the Reuelation. 3. and purge your harte by faith, ye cannot diÅ¿cerne of thinges different, and giue vpright iudgement. What I promiÅ¿ed, I am now by the grace of God readie to performe. And whether it was Å¿ome-thing or nothing, meikle or little, that I did, let work beare witnes, and let them that loues the trueth iudge.
FirÅ¿t he titles his libell, Ane anÅ¿were to ane obiection of the Romane Kirk, whereby they go about to deface the veritie of that onely true Religion whilk we profeÅ¿Å¿e.

God forbid that we Ye teach not the doctrine of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, therefore ye are not true Cath â¢
lick â¢ . Catholicks, whom he calles the Romane Kirk, Å¿eing
that we are the onlie defenders The overthrowers of it & Impugners of it. of the trueth, as our predeceÅ¿Å¿ors the paÅ¿tors of the true Kirk was before vs, Å¿uld go about to deface the trueth. But we go about to impugne all falÅ¿e doctrine repugnant to the trueth, as FalÅ¿e for ye do not as they did. the halie fathers of the primitiue Kirk did before vs, againÅ¿t the heretickes in their dayes, as Irenaus, Cypriane, AmbroÅ¿e, Augustine, Hierome, BaÅ¿ile, Gregorie, ChryÅ¿oÅ¿tome, with the reÅ¿t of the true paÅ¿tors of the Kirk. And Å¿eing that the MiniÅ¿ters We preach that Å¿ame Euangell that is written in the Scriptures. of this newe Evangell hes not onelie inuented Å¿um hereÅ¿ies themÅ¿elues, but alÅ¿o hes renewed many auld condemned hereÅ¿ies confuted by them before (as they You Å¿peake heere againÅ¿t your conÅ¿cience. can not deny) as I fall giue Å¿um examples afterward, as the hereÅ¿ie of Simon Magus, of Manichaeus, Pelagius, Aerius, Iouinianus, Vigilantius, with many vthers, what le â¢ can wee doe nor impugne the Å¿ame, as our predeceÅ¿Å¿ors did before.

As to your anÅ¿were: firÅ¿te ye denye it and deteÅ¿tes it as a blaÅ¿phemie: Nixt ye goe aboute to cleare your Å¿elues from the Å¿uÅ¿pition of it: Thirdly ye challenge vs and our doctrine with the crymes of noveltie and hereÅ¿ie: And Å¿o ye conclude yee could doe no leÅ¿Å¿e nor impugne it.

As to your denying of your defacing of the trueth of God, Å¿o doth the hooriÅ¿h woman after Å¿he hes eaten, Pro. 30.20 Å¿he wypes her mouth and Å¿ayes, Å¿he hes not Å¿inned, whilk is true as well in Å¿piritual as in bodilie fornication: So not-withÅ¿tanding your Kirk hes buried the trueth of God in the graues of darknes, and did ouercure it with their traditions and gloÅ¿Å¿es thir many yeares bygane, yet you wype your mouthes, and Å¿ayes you haue not Å¿inned. But look to it in time, for ignorance, and zeil without knawledge will not excuÅ¿e you in the day of the Lorde. Matth. 26.65. That you deteÅ¿t it as a blaÅ¿phemie, Å¿o did the hie prieÅ¿t rent his cloathes and Å¿aid ChriÅ¿t blaÅ¿phemed, when he Å¿pake but the trueth. As for your golden Å¿tyles whilk you take to your Å¿elues of Catholicks, defenders of the trueth, Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors to the paÅ¿tors of the true Kirk and impugners of all falÅ¿e doctrine. Your doctrine indeede could not deceaue Å¿o many, if it were not couered with thir Å¿tyles; your poyÅ¿one and abhomination would not be drunken Å¿o vniuerÅ¿allie, Apoc. 17.4. if it were not in Å¿ick a golden cuppe as this. So theÅ¿e are the byÅ¿Å¿ope wherewith ye would waÅ¿h you from this iniquity, and clenge you from this Å¿inne. Matth. 7.15. But may not falÅ¿e prophets come in Å¿heeps clothing? And the ministers of SataÌ can they not tranÅ¿forme
themÅ¿elues as though they were the MiniÅ¿ters of ChriÅ¿t? 2. Cor. 11.13 14 Apoc. 24 & 8 Ioh. 8.37. Mat. 23.7 The Scriptures hes foretold it: & did not the falÅ¿e ApoÅ¿tles in EpheÅ¿us, call themÅ¿elues the ApoÅ¿tles of ChriÅ¿t, and yet they were found lyars? And did not the Å¿ynagogue of Satan call her Å¿elfe the Å¿ynagogue of the Iewes, (that is, the Kirk of God) and yet they were not Å¿o, but the Å¿ynagogue of the deuill? yea and did not Abrahams Å¿eede, and they that Å¿ate in MoÅ¿es chaire, Mat. 7.16. Ioh. 10.11 and was the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ours of Aaron, condemned the Sauiour of the worlde? Therefore not by your Å¿tyles, but by your fruites ye muÅ¿t be tryed. For if ye bee catholicks &c, ye will teach the doctrine of that good paÅ¿tour, and chiefe Å¿heepheard the Lord IeÅ¿us. So it is your doctrine and not your Å¿tyles that muÅ¿t defend you.

And becauÅ¿e (ChriÅ¿tian Reader) by this Å¿tyle of Catholicke, whilk they aÅ¿criue only to their Kirk, they cauÅ¿e the Å¿imple to erre, and leades many blindlings to damnation, therefore I wil take this viÅ¿ard froÌ them. Ye are not the Catholick Kirk, as ye Å¿tyle your Å¿elf, and thus I proue it. Pope Pius the fift, who write a CatechiÅ¿me according to the decree of the councill of Trent. He there Å¿ayes that the Kirk whilk is called the bodie of ChriÅ¿t, CatechiÅ¿m. conc. Trident in expoÅ¿itione Å¿ymbol. whereof he is the head, is called Catholick, becauÅ¿e it is Å¿pread in the light of ane faith froÌ the eaÅ¿t to the weÅ¿t, receauing men of al Å¿ortes, containing all the faithfull whilk haue beene from Adam, euen vntill this day, The Kirk of Rome is not the Catholick Kirk or Å¿hall be hereafter to the end of the world profeÅ¿Å¿ing the true faith, &c.

Now I reaÅ¿on thus. The Catholicke Kirk comprehends all the faithfull from Adam till now, and that Å¿hall be hereafter to the end of the world, or elÅ¿e Pope Pius, and the fathers of Trent erres. But the Romane Kirk comprehends not all the faithfull from Adam till now, and that Å¿hall be hereafter: Therefore the Romane Kirk is not the Catholicke Kirk. ChooÅ¿e you now whilk of theÅ¿e ye will denye. The propoÅ¿ition I trowe ye will not: for then ye Å¿hould bring twa incoÌueniences, the ane vpon Pope Pius and the fathers of Trent, that they haue erred in defyning the Catholick Kirk, and Å¿o the Kirk & the Pope may erre. The vther is vppon your Å¿elfe, who Å¿aide that your Kirk hes not erred. And Å¿o ye loÅ¿e your Å¿tile of a defender of the Catholick faith: for this is a chief poynt of their faith, that the Kirk cannot erre. I hope therefore that theÅ¿e are Labyrinths
whilk yee will not wittinglie caÅ¿t your Å¿elfe vnto, and Å¿o you muÅ¿t hold faÅ¿t the propoÅ¿ition. All the queÅ¿tion is then of the aÅ¿Å¿umption. Whether the Romane Kirk comprehends all the faithfull from Adam till now, and whilk Å¿hall be to the end of the world, or not. FirÅ¿t I Å¿ay, a particular Kirk comprehendes not all the faithfull from Adam &c. But the Romane Kirk is a particular Kirk, or elÅ¿e the fathers of the counÅ¿ell of BaÅ¿ile,
â¢ a â¢â¢ ien concil. epiÅ¿t. Å¿ynod 3. Verratus, diÅ¿putationum contra Lutheranos tom â¢ de authoritate a â¢ poteÅ¿t. vniuerÅ¿. â¢ ccleÅ¿. cap. 1. and Verratus a papiÅ¿t erres, for they call the Romane Kirk a particular Kirk. We grant (Å¿ay they) that the Romane Kirk is a principall Kirk among vthers, but while you commend a parte forget not the haill. And they Å¿ay, the vniuerÅ¿all Kirk coÌpreheÌds the Romane Kirk. ChuÅ¿e you then whether will you contradict the fathers of the counÅ¿ell of BaÅ¿ile and a PapiÅ¿t Verratus, and be Å¿o abÅ¿urd as to call the arme of the bodie the haill bodie, ane arme of the Oceane Å¿ey the haill Oceane Å¿ey, or to goe from your title that the Romane Kirk is not the Catholicke kirk. Secundlie, the Catholicke Kirk comprehendes them that were before ChriÅ¿t: But the Kirk of Rome comprehendes not them, for there was a Kirk, or euer there was a Kirk at Rome, and the Romane Kirk comprehends nane but them that acknowledges the Pope to bee the head of the Kirk. But thoÅ¿e that were before ChriÅ¿t neuer did that: Therefore the Romane Kirk is not the Catholicke Kirk. Thirdlie, the Catholicke Kirk is inviÅ¿ible: for at the leaÅ¿t, neither are they that ar glorified, neither are they that are to bee borne, viÅ¿ible. But ye wil not haue the Romane Kirk, but alwayes viÅ¿ible, therefore the Romane Kirk is not the Catholicke Kirk. Fourthlie, if the Romane Kirk be the Catholicke Kirk, then either it Å¿hall follow, that the Pope is the heade of the Catholicke Kirk, or elÅ¿e that the Romane Kirk wants a viÅ¿ible heade. ChooÅ¿e you whether of theÅ¿e ye will, for the ane ye muÅ¿t, if ye will haue the Romane Kirk to be the Catholicke Kirk. But to Å¿ay that the Pope is the head of the Catholicke Kirk, I trowe ye dare not be Å¿o blaÅ¿phemous: for the gloryfied Saints, & Peter himÅ¿elfe are of the Catholicke Kirk, or elÅ¿e (as I Å¿aid before) Pope Pius and the fathers of Trent erres. And Å¿o then if ye will make him heade of the Catholicke Kirk, ye muÅ¿te make him heade
of the gloryfied Saints and of Peter alÅ¿o. So then chooÅ¿e you whether will ye leaue the Å¿tyle of Catholicke, whilk ye claime as proper to your Kirk, or will ye haue the Pope the heade of the triumphant Kirk in heauen: or laÅ¿t of all, will yee haue your Romane Kirk to want a viÅ¿ible heade: ane of theÅ¿e ye muÅ¿t chooÅ¿e. So to ende this poynte, this Å¿tyle of Catholicke it is like the numbering of the people by Dauid: for as it brought him in a wonderfull Å¿traite, 2. Sam. 14. when he Å¿awe it behoued him to chooÅ¿e, either Å¿eauen yeares famine, or foure moneths flying before his enemies, or three daies peÅ¿tileÌce. So this title of yours if you will bide by it, brings you in a woÌderful Å¿trait: for yee haue not the choiÅ¿e of ane of three euils, but theÅ¿e three things muÅ¿t ye either chooÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e let this Å¿tyle of Catholicke goe; ane of you fighting againÅ¿t ane vther, the Kirk inviÅ¿ible, and the Pope not to bee the heade of the Kirk. Of the whilk, the leaÅ¿t of theÅ¿e is more able to overthrow your Kingdome, then they all were able to haue ouerthrowne the Kingdome of Dauid, for they are the maine pillers of your Kingdome, your vnitie, your viÅ¿ibilitie, your Popes Å¿upremacie, all whilk you muÅ¿t either loÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e let your Å¿tyle of Catholicke goe from your Kirk. But howe will ye wreÅ¿tle your Å¿elfe out of this? For if ye will beleeue the fathers of Trent, and Pope Pius, in defyning the Catholick Kirk, ye cannot eÅ¿chew thir inconveniences. And if you wil not beleeue theÌ, that they Å¿pake trulie in that poynte, ye muÅ¿t accuÅ¿e them of error. And Å¿o the Kirk hes erred, the Pope hes erred, and your Å¿elfe hes erred that Å¿aid your Kirk hes the trueth in all thinges. Iohn. 11.50 And Å¿urelie as Caiaphas being hie prieÅ¿t that yeare, Å¿pake the truth when he Å¿aid that ane muÅ¿te die for the people, and not the the haill nation periÅ¿h, Å¿uppoÅ¿e in ãâã euill Å¿enÅ¿e. So hes the fathers of Trent and Pope Pius here Å¿poken trulie, Heb. 12, 23. Gal. 4, 26, both acording to the Scriptures, for the Kirk is called the aÅ¿Å¿emblie of the firÅ¿t borne, whoÅ¿e names is written in heauen. And that new IeruÅ¿alem whilk is from aboue, whilk is the mother of vs al. And alÅ¿o according to the fathers, Clem Ale â¢ . Å¿trom. li. 7. & Bernard. cantic. 78. & AuguÅ¿t d â¢ catechiÅ¿. â¢ nd. cap 20. & Gregorie & moral. in Ioh. li. 28. c. 9. who affirmeth that the Kirk is the companie of the predeÅ¿tinate, and all the elect are within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of it, and are citizens of it. So as Mat. 1 â¢ .17. ChriÅ¿t Å¿aid to the Iewes. If I caÅ¿t out deuils
by the prince of deuils, by whome then caÅ¿tes your children them out? So if we Å¿peake now by ane erroneous Å¿pirit, that Å¿ayes the Catholicke Kirk comprehendes all the elect, that was, is, and Å¿hall bee, and the Kirk of Rome can not bee the Catholicke Kirk. By what Spirit hes your councill and Pope and thir fathers Å¿poken the Å¿ame? So not your children but your fathers Å¿hall be your iudges.

Ye did mark Å¿ome contradiction as ye thought betweene me and Å¿ome vthers, vnto the whilk I will anÅ¿were in the owne time. Let me therefore marke this ane now, and marke it (Reader). Ye haue heard now howe that all theÅ¿e with ane voice hes Å¿aide, that the Catholicke Kirk comprehends all the elect, that was, is, and Å¿hall bee: Is it any hereÅ¿ie then to holde this poynte? I think you will not, nor dare not Å¿ay it. What will you Å¿ay then to your generall councill of ConÅ¿tance SeÅ¿Å¿. 15, art. 1. 6. who condemned Iohn Hus for the Å¿ame Doctrine, the firÅ¿t, and Å¿ixt article, for Å¿aying that there is ane vniuerÅ¿all Kirk, whilk is the company of the predeÅ¿tinate, and as it is taken in this Å¿enÅ¿e, it is ane article of our faith. For theÅ¿e amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, was this pure innocent condemned and burnt as ane hereticke, and his doctrine as hereÅ¿y: whilk of thir wil ye Å¿ay now hes erred? whether the generall councill of ConÅ¿tance? or the fathers of Trent, Pope Pius, Gregorie, AuÅ¿tine, Clement, and Bernard? For Å¿urelie if the latter erred not, then not onelie did the councill of ConÅ¿tance erre, but alÅ¿o hes broght vpoÌ them Å¿elues innoceÌt blood, in condemning the innocent & ye trueth in him. And if the council of ConÅ¿tance erred not, in condemning thir articles of Iohn Hus, then haue they condemned the doctrine of the fathers of Trent, Pope Pius, Gregorie, AuÅ¿tine, &c. and their perÅ¿ones, in the perÅ¿on of Iohn Hus. ChooÅ¿e whilk of them ye will. I Å¿peak the trueth to thee in ChriÅ¿t (Reader) be not deceaued. But open thy eyes and beholde the veritie it Å¿elfe condemned by a generall councill, & the profeÅ¿Å¿or of it burnt for ane heretick: But his Reuel. 17. â¢ & 18.24 blood & the blood of the reÅ¿t of the martyres of God is found in this whoore of Babell, and therefore ane day Å¿he Å¿hall be recompenÅ¿ed for all her iniquitie. Goe out of her therefore and Å¿aue thy Å¿oule, Reuel. 18.45 that thou bee not tormented in the
lake that burnes with fire and brimÅ¿tone, with her for euermore. VtherwiÅ¿e I call heauen and earth to witneÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿te thee, that thou Å¿all die in her Å¿in, and the Reuel. 14. â¢â¢
Å¿moke of thy torment Å¿hall aÅ¿cend for euermore. What now will you Å¿ay to theÅ¿e things, that your Kirk is not the Catholicke Kirk, but a parte of it onlie. And is onlie Catholick, becauÅ¿e of the Catholicke doctrine that Å¿he profeÅ¿Å¿es? But if this be true, wherefore then did your generall councill condemne it in Iohn Hus, and burne him for that doctrine, whilk both your Å¿elf muÅ¿te confeÅ¿Å¿e to bee true, and is aggreable to Scripture, fathers, and your owne Popes. Next I Å¿ay, Å¿uppoÅ¿e when ye are brought to this Å¿trait, ye muÅ¿te Å¿ay Å¿o: yet for al this, not onlie call ye your Kirk Catholicke, becauÅ¿e of the Å¿oundnes of doctrine whilk yee Å¿uppoÅ¿e Å¿he profeÅ¿Å¿es, but As appeareth by the epiÅ¿t. of Cardinal CuÅ¿anus writing to the Bohemians. Cochlaeus hiÅ¿tor HuÅ¿sitar. lib. 12 alÅ¿o & Å¿peciallie to make the Å¿imple beleeue, that there is no Å¿aluation out of her. Therefore ye call it the onlie true Kirk, & ye Catholicke Kirk: for out of the particular Kirk there is Saluation, but out of the Catholicke Kirk there is no Å¿aluation. Thirdlie I Å¿aye, as the epiÅ¿tles of Peter, Iohn, Iames, and Iudas are intituled Catholick, not becauÅ¿e of the Å¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e of their doctrine, whilk is common to the epiÅ¿tles of Paul alÅ¿o, and al the reÅ¿t of the Scripture, whilk in that reÅ¿pect may alÅ¿o be called Catholicke, but becauÅ¿e they are written generallie to all: So the Kirk is called Catholick properly, not becauÅ¿e of the Å¿oundnes of doctrine, for that is common to all the particular Kirks, that hes the puritie of Religion, but becauÅ¿e it comprehends all the particular Kirks and all the elect. And alÅ¿o to put a difference betweene the Kirk of the Iewes, whilk did comprehend but ane certaine people, & the ChriÅ¿tian Kirk Å¿ince the comming of ChriÅ¿t, whilk is not bound to any certaine place or nation, or people, but indifferently receaues al, both Iew and gentile that beleeues. & therfore is it called Catholick: & therfore in our beleef we Å¿ay not, I beleeue the Catholick doctrine, but the Catholick Kirk. So by this Å¿he is properlie diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from particular kirks, as the Mother from ye daughters, & the hail body from ye particular members. So theÌ if you would Å¿peak properlie of your Kirk, & not make your Å¿tyles Å¿nares, to catch ye Å¿oules of
the Å¿imple, call her but a particular Kirk, and a member of the Catholicke Kirk, but yet dead and rotten, as Å¿hall bee Å¿hewen afterward by the grace of God. VtherwiÅ¿e, if you will but call her the Catholicke Kirk, you firÅ¿t rob the mother, for Å¿he is properlie Catholicke, and alÅ¿o iniures the reÅ¿te of the daughters: For in reÅ¿pect of the Å¿oundnes of faith, they maye alÅ¿o challenge the Å¿ame to them. And thirdly, ye deceaue the Å¿oules of the Å¿imple thereby, by making them beleeue there is not ane vther Kirk but yours. And laÅ¿t of all, you are Å¿acrilegious in decking ane adultereÅ¿Å¿e with the Å¿tyles of the Å¿pouÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿t.

As to the thirde poynte, wherein ye calumniate the trueth of God whilk we profeÅ¿Å¿e, in calling it ane new Euangell, and olde renewed, and new invented hereÅ¿ies of our owne. TheÅ¿e are indeede heauie words wherewith ye Act. 18.6. & 19.9. blaÅ¿pheame the word of the Lord, and Å¿peakes euill of it to the people of this couÌtrie. And therfore as the ApoÅ¿t. Å¿aith of them that blaÅ¿phemed his doctrine. Rom. 3.8 Your damnation is iuÅ¿te. For a woe by Gods owne mouth is pronounced againÅ¿t them that calles good euill, IÅ¿ay. 5.20. Iude. 1. â¢ . and euill good, trueth falÅ¿et, and falÅ¿et trueth, and darkneÅ¿Å¿e light, and light darkneÅ¿Å¿e: But as the Archangell when hee Å¿traue with Satan about the bodie of MoÅ¿es, did not blame him with curÅ¿ed Å¿peaking, but Å¿aid, The Lord rebuke thee, Å¿o we wil not blame you with curÅ¿ed Å¿peaking, but the Lord rebuke you. For yee Å¿peake heere the viÅ¿ion of your owne harte, and not from the mouth of the Lord: And ye are not the firÅ¿t that hes blaÅ¿phemed the trueth of God, for Å¿o did the Iewes before you, call the doctrine of the Euangel a Å¿ect, a hereÅ¿ie, and the gentiles called it Å¿trange gods and a new doctrine, Act. 28. Act. 24. Act. 17. and the preachers thereof, a Å¿etter forth of Å¿trange gods, and of new doctrine, and a babler. The Iewes Å¿aid that ChriÅ¿t had a deuill, and yet as our Lorde teÅ¿tifies, Ioh. 8.44. It was they that was the children of the deuill. Ye Å¿ay that we preach ane new Euangel, & olde & new hereÅ¿ies; but this is the Å¿inne and the doctrine of your Kirk: O â¢ liel. de Å¿an â¢â¢ o a more, in his book de pericul. â¢â¢â¢ iÅ¿Å¿. â¢ empo. a l â¢ arned man anno. 1192, â¢

father reigned vnder the law: God the Sonne vnder grace. And the holie ghoÅ¿t was then that yeare to beginne his kingdome and to continue to the end of the worlde. And that IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t was not God, his Sacrament nothing, and his Euangell not a true Euangell. (O horrible blaÅ¿phemie) The whilk if God had not raiÅ¿ed vp Å¿ome men in thoÅ¿e dayes to haue reÅ¿iÅ¿ted it, as the WaldenÅ¿es and vthers whilk ye call heretickes and infamous men, the goÅ¿pell of ChriÅ¿t had beene looÅ¿ed, and in Å¿teede of it, we woulde haue gotten ane new Euangel: The dreggs whereof yet remaines in your Kirk. But I will let this paÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e the wiÅ¿e men of Babell (I meane your clergie of Rome) Å¿awe that that was too plaine ane iniquitie, therefore they cauÅ¿ed it quietlie to be remoued and buried, and yet they not condemned as heretickes that preached it. But by the contrarie, the WaldenÅ¿es and vthers that withÅ¿toode it, was condemned as heretickes and their bookes burned. To let this paÅ¿Å¿e (I Å¿ay) whilk teÅ¿tifieth what the world might haue looked for at your hands, if the Lorde had not prouided better for his poore Kirk. Your haill doctrine is AntichriÅ¿tian as Å¿hall bee proven heereafter, your Kirk Babell, Reu 17 your Kingdome that Å¿econd beaÅ¿t Reuel. 13.11 that hes two hornes like the Lambe & yet Å¿peakes like the dragon, and your head the man of Å¿inne 2. TheÅ¿Å¿al. 2 , and Sonne of perdition. And ye are they that hes renewed old condemned hereÅ¿ies, and hes inuented new of your owne, as Å¿hall be proued afterward, by gods grace.

Say they, our religion is Å¿o ancient that it hes continued euer by a lineall Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of PaÅ¿toures and BiÅ¿hopes, from the dayes of ChriÅ¿t & his ApoÅ¿t. till nowe, neuer interrupted, neuer Å¿poken againÅ¿t, but of late Å¿ince Martine Luthers daies: But yours, Å¿ay they, is newlie forged, and invented, neuer harde tell of but Å¿ince Luther and Caluines dayes. Therefore yours can not be the true Religion, and ours muÅ¿t be the onlie true Religion.

This obiection conÅ¿iÅ¿tes partlie of ane trueth, and partly of an vntrueth. It appeares be this that either M. Iohn knowes not our preeues, or if he dois he
alteres the Å¿ame that he may the better oppugne his owne inuention.
Our obiection, or rather ane of our prooues, whereby we prooue that we Catholickes is the onlie true Kirk of ChriÅ¿t, and hes the onelie truth in all things, is this.

We haue aboundantly Å¿et downe to vs by the Prophets and ApoÅ¿tles in the holy write, that the kingdome and Kirk of ChriÅ¿t Å¿hall neuer faill in this earth and that the gates of hell Å¿hall not prevaile againÅ¿t it. But Å¿hall bee permanent for euer, and Å¿hall haue alwayes the preÅ¿ence and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the father, Å¿onne, and holy ghoÅ¿t, who Å¿hall teach it all trueth, and remaine with it for euer, as may be perceaued be thir places noted here, whilks wereouer longÅ¿ome to be Å¿et downe at length. To the whilks I adioyne Å¿ome of the ancient fathers exponing the Å¿ame.

Mutius Å¿undrie. Let theÅ¿e examples Å¿erue as a taiÅ¿t to the reader.

How Å¿tronglie nowe yee haue manned and fortified your own Kirk & Religion by your proofes, let the reader iudge. Now let vs Å¿ee, how ye diÅ¿proue ours. The queÅ¿tion nowe comes in of the truth of our Kirk and Religion, whether it be from IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, or not. You Å¿ay, it is not from him, but
from others Å¿ince his time. If ye had gone the Å¿traight way to haue proued this and to haue Å¿atisfied the conÅ¿ciences of men, you would at the neareÅ¿t haue runne to the Scripture, and by the Å¿ame haue diÅ¿proued it. But you inÅ¿teede of this goe a farre by-way, and would father our religion on fleÅ¿he and bloode, duÅ¿t and aÅ¿hes: in poynting vs out Martine Luther to be the father and author of the Å¿ame, as though it had not an ancienter pedegre to reckon vnto, nor had not the beginning & foundation of it, from the roote of IeÅ¿Å¿e, the bud of the Lord from whome it hes Å¿prung. And for to get your Å¿elf the better credite you buÅ¿ie your Å¿elf in marking the circumÅ¿tances of his preaching, as time, place, matter, oppoÅ¿ition, &c. Now that ye are Å¿o skilled and acquainted with that hiÅ¿tory of Martine Luther, that you can aÅ¿Å¿igne al theÅ¿e circumÅ¿tances, it is no wonder, for that was the moÅ¿t notable and markable period of the decaying of your Babell, and of the erecting vp againe of the kingdome of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, whilk your head & clergie had Å¿tampt it vnder foote for Å¿o many yeares, whilk Å¿uppoÅ¿e the beginning of it was but like a little leauen, and as a graine of muÅ¿tard-Å¿eed whilk of all Å¿eedes is the leaÅ¿t. Yet now Å¿ince it hes Å¿o Å¿owred almoÅ¿t the whole maÅ¿Å¿e, euen the moÅ¿t part of the kingdomes of Europe, whilk once was vnder your Å¿pirituall bondage, and hes growen vp into Å¿ik a high tree hauing faire and great branches, vnder the whilk the Lords Å¿heepe may get reÅ¿te and warmneÅ¿Å¿e, and in the whilk his Å¿oules that mounts vp-wardes to that kingdome, doth builde their neÅ¿ts, Å¿o that neither can all your purgations, nor yet all your axes of fire and Å¿worde, of buls and pardons of preachings and writtings, Å¿tay the Å¿preading of the oneâª nor cut downe the branches & roote of the other. That M. Luther began at that time, and in that place, and preached againÅ¿t theÅ¿e doctrines, we do not deny, and that is not controuerted: But heere lyes al the queÅ¿tioÌ, whether if that doctrine that he preached againÅ¿t, was antichriÅ¿tian or not, & whether that religion whilk hee neither invented, nor yet firÅ¿t preached (for Å¿undrie before him did preach that Å¿ame doctrine, whoÅ¿e names I Å¿et downe in my anÅ¿were to your
obiection) but only raiÅ¿ed it out of the graue of darknes wherein ye had buried the trueth of God. Heere then (I Å¿ay) is the queÅ¿tion whether that religion whilk he preached hes the warrant from IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t in his TeÅ¿tament or not? the whilk if ye euer diÅ¿proue by the written word of God, then Å¿hall we grant you all that ye Å¿ay, the whilk is as impoÅ¿Å¿ible to you to doe, no not Å¿uppoÅ¿e your King would call all your wiÅ¿emen & cleargie together, Daniel 2 as it was to all the wiÅ¿emen of Babell to tell and interprete Nebuchadnezar his dreame: yea, Å¿uppoÅ¿e your King would reward yow gloriouÅ¿ly with honor and riches yf ye could do it, yet are ye not able to win your wages. Yea, Å¿uppoÅ¿e he would riue you in peices and make your houÅ¿e a iakes vnles ye did it, as the wiÅ¿emen of Babell was, becauÅ¿e they could not tell and interprete the Kings dreame. This is therefore the poynt whilk lies in queÅ¿tion betwixt vs, whilk ye Å¿huld haue proued if ye could. But know ye for a trueth, that Å¿uppoÅ¿e he raiÅ¿ed out of the graue the trueth of God whilk ye had buried, yet was he neither the inuenter nor the firÅ¿t preacher of it, but it hes for ye beginning & author of it, IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t the Son of God, and the foundation of it in the new TeÅ¿tament of his holy Scripture. This for the author, time, and place whilks ye aÅ¿signe.

Now, to the Kirks that Å¿pake againÅ¿t him. I anÅ¿were: they were but Å¿ik as was made drunken with the wine of your fornication, and deluded by your Å¿trong deluÅ¿ions, being deceiued by the golden cup, Reuel. 17.4 wherin you propyned them to be drunken out, as it was prophecied of you. But the meaÅ¿ure of your iniquitie being full, and the time of the lurking of the trueth of God being runn out, God of his infinite mercy by his miniÅ¿try, and the reÅ¿t that followed Å¿ince, hes opened the eyes of a great part of theÅ¿e kingdomes who firÅ¿t Å¿ayd againÅ¿t him, to Å¿e your Kirk to be the whore: Reuel. 17.1. & 13 11.2. TheÅ¿. 2.3.4 11. Reuel. 18.4 your kingdome to be the beaÅ¿t: and your head to be the AntichriÅ¿t: your doctrine to be deluÅ¿ions, and your Rome to be that myÅ¿ticall Babilon. And Å¿o the Lord hes made them beleeue and giue obedience to that commandement of his, goe out of her my people &c.
That ye call theÅ¿e the true Kirk that Å¿pake againÅ¿t him, that lies in the weights and ballance yet betwixt vs, for or ye proue them to be the true Kirk, ye muÅ¿t fi â¢ Å¿t proue your doctrine whilk they then profeÅ¿Å¿ed, to haue the warrant out of the word of God. So, let them haue the name of a Kirk, but of an impure and corrupted Kirk: of a Kirk infected by the peÅ¿t of your doctrine, oppreÅ¿Å¿ed by the tyrannie of your Pope and cleargie, and conÅ¿umed by the rotten humors of your Idolatrie. So then it was not the true Kirk, that is, the called ones by the light of the GoÅ¿pell (for they are the true Kirk) that Å¿pake againÅ¿t him, but only theÅ¿e that were infected and poiÅ¿oned with your abhominations, the whilk I grant did ouer-Å¿pread theÅ¿e nations as it was fore-told of her. Reuel. 17.2. &. â¢â¢ . 3. &. 13.14. And as for theÅ¿e firÅ¿t heads of religion whilk he oppugned: Of your pardons, iuÅ¿tification by works, and the Å¿acrifice of the maÅ¿Å¿e, there condemnation is Å¿et downe in the great regiÅ¿ter and TeÅ¿tament of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t the Lord of life as Å¿hall be proued hereafter. So that he was not the firÅ¿t that oppugned them. Now as to the laÅ¿t the Kirks from whome he departed, he departed not from their bodie, but from the conÅ¿umption of your hereÅ¿ie, that conÅ¿umed the body: not from the Kirk, but from the corruptions of your Idolatrie and abhominations in the Kirk. Not from the common-weale of IÅ¿raell, but from your tyraÌnie & oppreÅ¿Å¿ion of the coÌmon-weale. Not from the citie of God, but from the peÅ¿t of your doctrine, that infected the citie. And laÅ¿t of al not from the Å¿piritual communion & Å¿ocietie of the Saints of God in theÅ¿e partes, but from the coÌmunion with Babel with AntichriÅ¿t, with the beaÅ¿t, & with ye Dragon, & that at the 1. Tim. 6.3 4.5. Matth 7.15. Act. 19. & 8 v. 1. Cor. 10.14. 2. Cor. 5.14.15 16.17.18. HoÅ¿ea 4, 15. Reuel, 18 4, coÌmandemeÌt of the Lord flie from Idolatrie; goe out of Babell my people. Nowe after you haue aÅ¿signed the mutations of our religion Å¿ince ChriÅ¿t and his ApoÅ¿tles (as you think) you gather the whole force of it together & makes the Å¿treame of your argument to runn as Å¿trongly as it can vpon our Kirk and religion, that the face and forme of it might be Å¿o waÅ¿hen away that it be not knowen to be a true Kirk. Your reaÅ¿on then is this. The true Kirk of ChriÅ¿t hes neuerfailed vniuerÅ¿ally for the Å¿pace of one day, becauÅ¿e our Sauiour hes promiÅ¿ed to be with it to the end of the
world. But our Kirk was neuer before Martine Luthers daies, therefore it is not the true Kirk of ChriÅ¿t. As to your propoÅ¿ition, if ye sake failing for erring in matters of doctrine, then I denie your propoÅ¿ition for I hope I haue proued Å¿ufficiently before that the Kirk both may erre and hes erred in all ages. But if you take failling to be vtterly aboliÅ¿hed and rooted out of the face of the earth, then I grant your propoÅ¿ition, that God hes euer a Kirk, the Kirk of his elect, with whom he will be to the end of the world. And as to your aÅ¿Å¿umption, that our Kirk was neuer before Martine Luthers dayes, I deny it. Let vs Å¿ee howe ye proue it. There was none (Å¿ay yee) before his daies neither viÅ¿ible nor inuiÅ¿ible that profeÅ¿Å¿ed his religion. But howe doe ye proue that, for that is Å¿till denied to you? For if our religion hes the olde and new TeÅ¿tament to beare witnes to it, and IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t to be the author of it in euerie poynt, as Å¿hall be made manifeÅ¿t by the grace of God, then I Å¿ay whoÅ¿oeuer they were from the beginning of the world to this day viÅ¿ible or inuiÅ¿ible that profeÅ¿Å¿ed the true IeÅ¿us, the true Sauiour, his true doctrine and Sacraments wherin religion Å¿tands, they are our predeceÅ¿Å¿ors, and are of our profeÅ¿Å¿ion and religion: Å¿o then ye Å¿hould firÅ¿t (if ye had gone Å¿quarely to work) haue diÅ¿proued the heads of our religion not to haue their warrand from the tables of ChriÅ¿ts TeÅ¿tament, or ye had concluded that we had none of our profeÅ¿Å¿ion and Religion before Martine Luther. And this is the point you Å¿hould haue begun at, for it is not the Kirk that makes the religion, but the religion that makes the Kirk. Haue we a warrant out of the word of God for our religion, then are we the true Kirk, and the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors of all them who euer from the beginning of the vvorld hes profeÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame. Haue vve not this vvarrant then I graunt you vve haue no true Kirk. So there is the point of our controuerÅ¿ie, vvhether our doctrine be from God, out of his vvord or not. But hovve proue ye that Martine Luther had none of his profeÅ¿Å¿ioÌ before him? FirÅ¿t you gathered vpon the former things that all the true Kirks Å¿aide againÅ¿t him, and that he departed from them, vnto the vvhilk I anÅ¿vvered
before that theÅ¿e was not the trew Kirk, but only Å¿o many of euery natioÌ who was deceiued by your doctrine, & whereof the Lord did cure a great many by his miniÅ¿try, & by the miniÅ¿trie of others whome the Lord did Å¿tirre vp Å¿ince, Å¿o that neither did the trew Kirk who Å¿aw the trueth, Å¿peak againÅ¿t nor yet did he depart from their Å¿ocietie.
â¢ . Reg 19.10.18 Next as the lord had a true kirk in IÅ¿rael in the time of Elias, euen theÅ¿e 7000. whilk did not bowe their knee to Baal, who was neither known to Elias the Prophet nor yet to the perÅ¿ecuters: Å¿o did the Lord in the midÅ¿t of your darkneÅ¿Å¿e and Idolatry reÅ¿erue to himÅ¿elf a true Kirk, euen theÅ¿e hundreth fortie and foure thouÅ¿and whilk Ihon Å¿aw Å¿tanding with the Lamb on mount Sion, Reuelat. 14.1 who did not defile themÅ¿elues with your Idolatrie and did not worÅ¿hip the beaÅ¿t and receiue his mark: whilk Å¿uppoÅ¿e neither ye nor we had knowen, yet the Lord did reÅ¿erue them as he promiÅ¿ed.
Thirdly, I Å¿ay Martine Luther had Å¿undry who profeÅ¿Å¿ed his religion immediately before him, who was euen knowen to the world, as I Å¿hall proue afterward.

Your next proofe is taken from an teÅ¿timonie of one of our owne writers where ye alledge that it is written of Martine Luther and Zuinglius, that they were the firÅ¿t that came to the knowledge of the GoÅ¿pell. I Å¿ay ye are not faithfull in citing of this teÅ¿timonie, for it Å¿aies not that they were the firÅ¿t that came to the knowledge of the GoÅ¿pell, but theÅ¿e are the wordes that it was an eaÅ¿ie thing to them (meaning of your Kirk) to deuiÅ¿e againÅ¿t vs (meaning the EngliÅ¿h ProteÅ¿tants as yee call them) theÅ¿e curÅ¿ed Å¿peaches, when Martine Luther and Zuinglius firÅ¿t came to the GoÅ¿pell. The Latine wordes are, cum Martinus Luther et Zuinglius primum acceÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿Å¿ent ad Euangelium. So it Å¿aies not that they were the firÅ¿t that came to the GoÅ¿pell, but that it was eaÅ¿ie to you to Å¿pew out curÅ¿ed Å¿peaches when they came firÅ¿t to the GoÅ¿pell. So that this worde primum that is, firÅ¿t, is not in compariÅ¿on with them that knew the GoÅ¿pell before, but in compariÅ¿on with that time in the whilk they themÅ¿elues knew not the GoÅ¿pell. It is an aduerb of time, and you take it for an adiectiue noune. But there
is a vaile ouer your eyes MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert that yee can neither Å¿ee vvhat vve or your Å¿elues writes: So then to conclude, Å¿eing the religion whilk Martine Luther taught, hes the warrant from ChriÅ¿ts TeÅ¿tament; and Å¿eing all that euer profeÅ¿Å¿ed the trew religion, that hes ChriÅ¿t to be the author of it in his Scripture, viÅ¿ible or inuiÅ¿ible, are his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors: Therefore the religion whilk Martine Luther taught was the trew religion. And Å¿eing your religion hes not ChriÅ¿t to be the author of it in his latter TeÅ¿tament, but is that apoÅ¿taÅ¿ie & defection, that AntichriÅ¿tian kingdome that was foreÅ¿poken of in the Scripture: Therefore I conclude that your Kirk and religion whilk he oppugned is not the true Kirk & religion, but that AntichriÅ¿tian kingdome. And this for the firÅ¿t part of your obiection. Nowe we come to the Å¿econd.

As for the other part of the obiection whilk he alledges to be ours: that is, that our religion was neuer Å¿aide againÅ¿t, we Å¿ay not Å¿o: Matth. 13.4 for why all heretickes and others infected with falÅ¿e doctrine hes euer Å¿aide againÅ¿t the Å¿ame, almoÅ¿t at all times. A d therefore wonder not M. Gilbert Å¿uppoÅ¿e your myÅ¿terie of iniquitie Å¿o Å¿one began. For how Å¿oone that ChriÅ¿t our Sauiour planted the trueth: the Diuell immediatly Å¿ewe Popple in the Å¿ame, according to the parable Å¿et down in S. Matthew.

I come now to that part whilk ye Å¿ay is vntruly alledged of you, whilk moued you to Å¿ay that either I knew not your proofes, or if I knew them that I altered the Å¿ame, that I might the better oppugne my owne inuention. Of my knowledge of your proofes I will Å¿peak nothing. But let vs Å¿ee whether this be my inuention or not, or rather your own proofe. You, for the confirmation of the trueth of your Kirk and religion brought in this as a proofe, that I, nor no MiniÅ¿ter in Scotland was able to aÅ¿signe the trewe Kirk that Å¿pake againÅ¿t it. Either then yee proue nothing, or els this muÅ¿t be one of your proofes, becauÅ¿e it was neuer Å¿poken againÅ¿t by a true Kirk. Now compare theÅ¿e words with mine, and Å¿ee whether I Å¿peake ignorantlie or vntrulie of your proofes. I Å¿aid, that ye affirmed your religion to be trew, becauÅ¿e
it was neuer Å¿poken againÅ¿t. Here our words are one, except this that ye ad (be a true Kirk) I vnderÅ¿taÌd the Å¿ame, and therefore I gaue the inÅ¿tances, firÅ¿t of ChriÅ¿t and his ApoÅ¿tles next of the primitiue Kirk, thirdly of theÅ¿e that liued in Poperie whilk Å¿pake againÅ¿t your religion; all whilk I appeale your conÅ¿cience whether think ye that I iudg them a true Kirk or not. Now in that ye expound it otherwiÅ¿e of heretickes, this is neither my words nor meaning, but your owne inuention. So that by this it may appear that either ye haue not vnderÅ¿tood my words alledging your obiection, or els ye haue altered the meaning of the Å¿ame, that ye might the more eaÅ¿ily anÅ¿were to your owne inuentions, & gaine Å¿ay my words.

p.label: MaiÅ¿ter Iohn WelÅ¿che his anÅ¿wer to the obiection.

div.p: Your religion of the Romane Kirk was neuer inÅ¿tituted nor preached neither by ChriÅ¿t nor by his ApoÅ¿tles, as I offer me to proue by their writings: whilk is the only touchÅ¿tone whereby all religion Å¿hould be and muÅ¿t be tried.

I think in this MaiÅ¿ter Iohn takes vpon him an impoÅ¿Å¿ibilitie, for it is Å¿aid that it is impoÅ¿sible to proue a M. Robert Å¿aie you is contrarie to this, that the word except it be preached is but a Å¿laying letter, therefore Å¿ay you t cannot be iudge to the chriÅ¿tian religion. Sermon vpon EÅ¿ai 1 & 6. AnÅ¿we c. You belie M. Robert Bruce, for there is not Å¿ik a word of his in theÅ¿e Å¿ermons: this is twiÅ¿e that you haue falÅ¿elie forged our teÅ¿timonies. Ergo, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to proue your Popes not to be the AntichriÅ¿t by your reÅ¿on negatiue propoÅ¿itioÌ, except it be Å¿et downe in the word of God, whilk is of authoritie: and that I am Å¿ure he cannot finde, becauÅ¿e PapiÅ¿trie by him is not Å¿o olde as the word of God is. But in the mean time MaiÅ¿ter Iohn proues nothing He off rs very faire, and when euer he proues any thing contrary to vs, w th Gods grace he Å¿hall get an anÅ¿wer. And note here that MaiÅ¿ter Iohn can Å¿ay nothing to our argument, for to it he giues no anÅ¿wer.

In your anÅ¿were to this Å¿ection, firÅ¿t ye thinke it impoÅ¿sible becauÅ¿e of the forme of it. Next, ye Å¿ay it is but an offer & I proue nothing. Thirdly that I anÅ¿were nothing to your argumeÌt, nor can anÅ¿were nothing. Now, of al theÅ¿e in order. And firÅ¿t to the forme: ye thinke it impoÅ¿Å¿ible to proue becauÅ¿e
it is a negatiue propoÅ¿ition. Is not this a negatiue propoÅ¿ition that the Popes of Rome are not the AntichriÅ¿t; you can not deny it. Againe, I ask is this Å¿entence to be found in the vvhole Scripture; I trovv ye vvil neuer be able to finde it. Then I Å¿ay if it bee true that ye Å¿ay, Bellarm lib. 3 de Rom. Pontif. Sanders 40 demonÅ¿trations. then ye your Å¿elfe in your booke and this your anÅ¿vver, and Bellarmine and Sanderus and all the reÅ¿t of you that takes in hand to proue the Pope not to be the AntichriÅ¿t, takes in hand in your iudgement an impoÅ¿Å¿ibilitie (and Å¿o doe ye indeede, not becauÅ¿e it is a negatiue propoÅ¿ition, but becauÅ¿e he is the AntichriÅ¿t in verie trueth.) What vvould the Pope your head thinke of you, if he heard you Å¿ay Å¿o? Certainly I think he would not inroll your name among the defenders of his catholick faith vvhereof this is the foundation. Secondly, is there not many formall Å¿yllogiÅ¿mes that hes the propoÅ¿ition or aÅ¿Å¿umption negatiues, and wil you Å¿ay they cannot be proued if the matter be true, becauÅ¿e they are negatiues? What is this but to raiÅ¿e the foundation of Logick and ReaÅ¿on? Logick is not Rhethorick, & PhyÅ¿ick is not Logick: both theÅ¿e are negatiue propoÅ¿itions, & I trow neither of theÌ are Å¿o found in the Scripture, and vvill you Å¿ay that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to proue them, becauÅ¿e they are negatiues? What you meane by this I vnderÅ¿tand not, Tim. 2.14. vnleÅ¿Å¿e you doe ã in non-Latin alphabet ã Å¿triue about words, proue & improue, forbidden by the ApoÅ¿tle. Thirdly, ye except theÅ¿e negatiue propoÅ¿itioÌs, whilk are Å¿et downe in the word of God, whilk hes authoritie as ye Å¿ay, I aÅ¿Å¿ume. But your religion in Å¿ubÅ¿tance is condemned in the word of God: Therefore by your owne confeÅ¿Å¿ion it may be proued, Å¿uppoÅ¿e it be negatiue: For Nazianzene Å¿aies, that theÅ¿e Å¿entences that are collected out of the Scripture by a neceÅ¿Å¿arie conÅ¿equence are of the Å¿ame trueth and authoritie with theÅ¿e Å¿entences that are expreÅ¿ly Å¿et downe in the Scripture. Lib. 5. de Theologia. And wheras ye Å¿ay PapiÅ¿trie by me is not Å¿o olde as the Scripture, I grant that. What then? Therefore it is not condemned in the Scripture; I deny that: for AntichriÅ¿t and his kingdome are not Å¿o olde as the Scripture, and yet the Scripture condemned it. For not only condemns it preÅ¿ent hereÅ¿ies, but alÅ¿o the hereÅ¿ies that was to
come. And Å¿eing PapiÅ¿trie is that AntichriÅ¿tian religion, as Å¿hall be made manifeÅ¿t by Gods grace: therefore it hes the expreÅ¿Å¿e condemnation of it in the word of God. The forme therefore of it, no wayes will make it impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be proued. As for the next thing, that I proue nothing, but offers verie faire. I anÅ¿wer it was not my purpoÅ¿e then, but I hope ye Å¿hall haue a proofe now of that whilk I offered then. As to the third then, that I can Å¿ay nothing to your argument whilk ye would haue the reader to marke: vvhen I red this, I marked this, that ye would earneÅ¿tly haue the reader perÅ¿waded of the inuinciblenes of your argument and my inabilitie to anÅ¿were. But what bring ye with you to perÅ¿wade him of the Å¿ame? Your reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e I haue not anÅ¿wered it. Will this follow, I haue not (Å¿uppoÅ¿e it were Å¿o as yee Å¿ay) therefore I cannot? It will not follow (M. Gilbert) I haue not anÅ¿wered, I cannot anÅ¿were to it. But as ye haue a new Theologie, Å¿o haue ye a newe Logick. But Å¿aid I nothing to your argument? What is not anÅ¿vvered Å¿ufficiently in the Å¿ame? Your argument vvas the antiquitie of your religion and continuance of it from ChriÅ¿t by a lineall Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion neuer interrupted, &c. And the noueltie of ours. My anÅ¿wer vvas: yours vvas not inÅ¿titute by ChriÅ¿t nor his ApoÅ¿tles in his Scripture as ours vvas, and yours vvas gaineÅ¿aide in the cheif poynts by the teÅ¿timonies of the fathers the firÅ¿t 600. yeares, and the principall points of our religion confirmed by Å¿undrie of their teÅ¿timonies. Thirdly yours vvas that AntichriÅ¿tian apoÅ¿tacie that the Scripture fore-tolde Å¿hould come, and in the height of your tyrannie and Idolatrie vvas gainÅ¿ayed by many before Martine Luther, and ours vvas profeÅ¿Å¿ed by Å¿undry before him vvhoÅ¿e names I Å¿et dovvne, all vvhilk I offered to proue, and novve Å¿hall doe by Gods grace. Novv you Å¿ay this is no anÅ¿vvere. But is that no anÅ¿vver that cuts the verie throte of your religion if it be verefied, & hoghs your argument, that it doe neuer Å¿tand vp to vnder-propp your religion againe? For that religion vvhilk is not inÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t in the Scripture, vvhoÅ¿e maine foundations is gainÅ¿aide by the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿undrie of the
fathers of the firÅ¿t 600. yeare whilk is AntichriÅ¿tian, and whilk was gaineÅ¿aid by the Saints that they perÅ¿ecuted and Å¿lew, hes not the continuance from ChriÅ¿t by a lineal Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion neuer interrupted nor Å¿poken againÅ¿t by a true Kirk till Martine Luthers dayes. This I am Å¿ure ye will not deny. But your religion is Å¿ik as I offered then to proue, and now hes in Å¿ome poynts, and Å¿hall in other Å¿ome poynts by Gods grace. The whilk if it be verifyed, then I hope ye will not deny, but that your religion hes neither antiquitie, continuance nor Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion from ChriÅ¿t til Martine Luthers dayes. And that religion cannot be newly forged and inuented Å¿ince Martine Luthers dayes, whilk hes the warrant and inÅ¿titution of it in the Scripture &c. This you cannot deny. But our religion is Å¿ik, as then I offered to proue and now hes done in Å¿ome poynts and Å¿hall doe in other Å¿ome poynts by Gods grace. Therefore our religion cannot be newly forged and inuented &c. but is the only true religion. So that this anÅ¿were if it be proued, doth Å¿ufficiently vindicat our religion froÌ noueltie. Now if this be no anÅ¿were to your argumeÌt, theÌ I Å¿ay no more, but ye will anÅ¿wer it the Å¿ooner. And becauÅ¿e ye formed your owne argument your Å¿elfe in your anÅ¿wer to me, & I haue anÅ¿wered to it els; therefore I wil now inÅ¿iÅ¿t no further vpon it. And as for your lineall Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of BiÅ¿hops it will come in queÅ¿tion afterward, therefore I omit it now.

As for the written word, it is true that it is a moÅ¿t faithfull witnes (& it be not corrupted) to ChriÅ¿t & his Kirk, as our Sauiour teÅ¿tifies him Å¿elfe: Iohn. 5, â¢â¢ , of the whilk opinion there is Å¿undry ProteÅ¿tants, chiefely young MerchiÅ¿ton in his diÅ¿courÅ¿e vpon the Reuelation in the 21 PropoÅ¿ition, and other places. 2, Cor, 3, 6. Iohn. 6, 63, Iohn, 14.15, 16. But that it ought to bee iudge to decide all controuerÅ¿ies in religion, MaiÅ¿ter Iohn hes no Scripture for the Å¿ame. It is the holy GhoÅ¿t that muÅ¿t be iudge, and the holy writ muÅ¿t beare witnes thereto. But That is contrarie to that whilk you Å¿aide before that they were all two hundreth yeare before them. heir it is to be noted alÅ¿o, that MaiÅ¿ter Iohn can finde none before the yeare of ChriÅ¿t 1158. that Å¿aid againÅ¿t the Pope and his religion, & none immediatly before Luther, the Å¿pace of an 100. yeare and more. Whether Valentinus taught Å¿o or not, I contend not: but the queÅ¿tion is of this doctrine, of the reall preÅ¿ence, whether it be contrare to Gods word, or not; the whilk I haue prooued Å¿ufficiently before in the fourth point of doctrine: and Å¿o the denying of it is no hereÅ¿ie. But yet it appeares not by this teÅ¿timonie of Irenaeus, whilk ye cite heir, that he taught Å¿ik doctrine.
As for the 8. hereÅ¿ie, it is a calumnie to aÅ¿criue it to vs, for Melanchton, Caluine, and Beza hes no Å¿ik doctrine. You are not aÅ¿hamed, MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, of impudent lying.

As for the 9. of Nouatus hereÅ¿ie, that is a calumnie to aÅ¿criue it to vs. I or Nouatus denied that there was any place of repentance to theÅ¿e, who after they were baptiÅ¿ed, fel from the faith, by ony infirmitie, or violence of perÅ¿ecution, as Epiphanius teÅ¿tifies of him that hee Å¿aide, No man who hes falne after BaptiÅ¿me can any more obtaine mercie. But our doctrine is
contrare to this: for we teach that there is place to repentaÌce for any Å¿inne, except the Å¿inne againÅ¿t the holy GhoÅ¿t, whilk is euer puniÅ¿hed with finall impenitencie.

As for the 10. of the Manichees hereÅ¿ie, their doctrine was as AuguÅ¿tine Å¿ayes there, that BaptiÅ¿me Å¿erued nothing for Å¿aluation to anye: and that none, who followed their Å¿ect, Å¿hould be baptized. and therefore they broght in a contempt of BaptiÅ¿me, whilk is contrarie our doctrine. For we teache that ChriÅ¿tians and their children is to be baptized: and that the contempt of it is damnable, Å¿uppoÅ¿e not the want of it.

As for the 11. and 12. hereÅ¿ies, we contemne not faÅ¿tings that are appointed by the Kirk, for lawful cauÅ¿es: but we deny that they Å¿hould be tied to certaine and prefixed dayes, as your Kirk does: and we thinke it no hereÅ¿ie to faÅ¿t on the Lords day, more then other dayes: both to Å¿tirre vp our repentance, and to make vs more meet to holy and Å¿pirituall exerciÅ¿es, becauÅ¿e it is not contrary to the word of God. As for Leo his EpiÅ¿tle, it is wrong quoted, for it Å¿hould be EpiÅ¿t. 91. and there faÅ¿ting on the Lords day is not like ours: for they faÅ¿ted on the Lordes day, becauÅ¿e they beleeued not that ChriÅ¿t was a true man, as Leo in that Å¿ame place teÅ¿tifies whilk you will not Å¿ay your Å¿elfe that we do, for we acknowledge him to be a true man.

As for the 13. hereÅ¿ie of the PepuÅ¿ians and Collyridians, their doctrine was that wemen might be BiÅ¿hops, and Elders, & might vÅ¿e theÅ¿e publick functions, as theÅ¿e places whilk ye haue quoted, teÅ¿tifies: whilk is not our doctrine, but rather yours, who permits wemen to baptize, in caÅ¿e of neceÅ¿sity. That they denied orders to be a Sacrament, there is no Å¿ik thing to be found in theÅ¿e places whilk ye quote heir.

As for the 14. hereÅ¿ie of the Pelagians, if they denied that theÅ¿e who were accuÅ¿ed of any Å¿candalous offence, & guilty thereof; Å¿hould make their confeÅ¿sion of it to God, his MiniÅ¿ters, & the Congregation, for to take away the offence of it, then they erred, and our doctrine and practiÅ¿e condemnes this: but if they denied the abÅ¿olute neceÅ¿sity of your auricular confeÅ¿sions, then is it no errour, becauÅ¿e there is na Å¿ik
thing commanded in the whole Scriptures of God. Nowe as for the teÅ¿timonie of Boetius, I haue not Å¿eene it. As for their Å¿econd hereÅ¿ie concerning BaptiÅ¿me, they taught, as AuguÅ¿tine reportes in that place, that BaptiÅ¿me was not needfull to children, becauÅ¿e they were borne without original Å¿inne, as they taught whilk is an hereÅ¿ie indeede: but this is a calumnie to aÅ¿criue it to vs, for we teach that children are borne in originall Å¿in, and Å¿o Å¿houlde be baptized. And Å¿urelie this hereÅ¿ie rather aggrees to you, who teaches that Marie was not borne in originall Å¿inne, and therefore Å¿he needed not to be baptized.

As for the laÅ¿t of the DonatiÅ¿ts, denying the order of Monks. I anÅ¿were: firÅ¿t, your PapiÅ¿ticall and Idolatrous Monkes, Bellari 2. de indulgentus are farre different from theÅ¿e whilk AuguÅ¿tine and ChryÅ¿oÅ¿tome defended, and theÅ¿e of the Primitiue Kirk. For firÅ¿t they were bound to no preÅ¿cript forme of diet, apparell, or any thing elÅ¿e, by Å¿olemne vowes of wilfull pouertie, and perpetual coÌ tinencie, as yours are, next, the former Monks remained in the order of priuate men, and laicks, and had no thing to do with EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall charges, whilk was afterward broken by Pope Boniface the 4. anno 606. But yours are not Å¿o: they haue EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall charges, and are more then priuate men. And laÅ¿t of all, Å¿uppoÅ¿e their kinde of life was mixed with Å¿ome Å¿uperÅ¿tition, for the enuious man Å¿one Å¿owed the popple amongÅ¿t the good Å¿eede, and the myÅ¿tery of iniquity began Å¿one to worke: yet their religion was not defiled with Idolatrie, worÅ¿hipping of Images, praiers to Saints, opinion of merite, the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, and other abhominations wherewith your PapiÅ¿ticall Monkes are defiled. Next I Å¿ay, theÅ¿e Monkes and religious orders of yours, hes not their foundation within the foure corners of the Scripture of God.

TheÅ¿e and many the like new renewed hereÅ¿ies by the MiniÅ¿ters, was old condemned hereÅ¿ies in the primitiue Kirk of the former heretickes, as teÅ¿tifies the ancient Fathers: and therefore this is a true argument. What euer was hereÅ¿ie in old times is hereÅ¿ie yet, and the defenders thereof hereticks, as they were of olde: but theÅ¿e former heades that I haue Å¿et downe, with many the like was hereÅ¿ies in olde times, and the defenders thereof heretickes,
as teÅ¿tifies the auncient Fathers: Therefore they are hereÅ¿ies yet, & the defenders thereof heretickes.

Now heere was all the cauÅ¿e (ChriÅ¿tian reader) that made (MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert) Å¿o oft to cry out of vs, that wee renued old condemned hereÅ¿ies, whereof Å¿ome are Å¿ik as wee our Å¿elues condemne, and Å¿ome are Å¿ik whilk doe better aggree vnto themÅ¿elues, nor vnto vs: & Å¿ome hereÅ¿ies he forceth vpon vs whilk wee neuer taught nor maintayned: and Å¿ome are Å¿ik whilk are not hereÅ¿ies indeede, but aggreable to the Scriptures of God. So that if we erre in theÅ¿e, Å¿uffer vs to erre with IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t and his ApoÅ¿tles. Now to anÅ¿wer to your argument whilk ye bring. What euer was hereÅ¿ie in olde times, is hereÅ¿ie yet, and the defenders thereof heretickes. I anÅ¿wer, if ye define hereÅ¿ie to be an error obÅ¿tinately maintained againÅ¿t the Scriptures of God: I graunt your propoÅ¿ition. But if ye define hereÅ¿ies in generall, to be whatÅ¿omeuer any one Father or Doctor, or Å¿ome more hes rebuked as an hereÅ¿ie; then I deny it, for Å¿undrie of the fathers hes maintained errors themÅ¿elues againÅ¿t the Scripture, and hes accuÅ¿ed Å¿ome doctrine to bee hereÅ¿ies, whilk hes bene aggreeable to the trueth of God, whilk you will not deny, I hope. For if you would, I could proue it both of the Fathers, Councels, and your owne Popes. Now to your aÅ¿Å¿umption. But theÅ¿e former heads, Å¿ay ye, whilk ye haue Å¿et downe with manye the like was hereÅ¿ies in olde tymes, and the defenders thereof hereticks, as teÅ¿tifieth the auncieÌt Fathers. I anÅ¿were that Å¿ome of theÅ¿e are hereÅ¿ies indeede, and we abhorre and condemne them more nor yee, and Å¿ome of theÅ¿e as falÅ¿lie laide to our charge, and Å¿ome of theÅ¿e are not hereÅ¿ies indeede, but aggreable to the Scripture. And therefore, your concluÅ¿ion fals not vpon vs, who hes renewed no olde condemned hereÅ¿ie, and therefore is not heretickes. And where you Å¿aye many other like. I anÅ¿were: It is true they are like, for they are both calumnies and horrible vntruths, and lyes as theÅ¿e hes bene, whereof one day ye Å¿hall make anÅ¿wer to the great
God that Iudgeth the quick and the dead. But the pit whilk you â¢â¢ gged for others you haue fallen in it your Å¿elfe: for certainly in this you doe as theeues does, who the better to eÅ¿chew the crime of theft whilk is iuÅ¿tly laide to their charge, and that they may the more eaÅ¿ily eÅ¿cape in a fraye, doth cry out and Å¿hout out vpon others, common theeues, common theeues. Euen Å¿o do you: for theÅ¿e crimes whereof yee are guiltie your Å¿elues you falÅ¿ly charge vs with. Therefore that all men may Å¿e that you are the men who hes renewed the olde condemned hereÅ¿ies, I will not do, as yee haue done to vs, that is eyther to lay to your charge Å¿ik hereÅ¿ies as yee maintaine not, or Å¿ik thinges to be hereÅ¿ies whilk are not hereÅ¿ies indeede, whilk ye did to vs. But in this I will deale Å¿incearelye with you, faining nothing neither of them nor of you.

Siklike contrar the Å¿econd command they vniuerÅ¿ally teach, that the worÅ¿hip of Images is no break of it. And they call the Croce their only hope. What horrible blaÅ¿phemie is this? And In his booke de reÅ¿identia cont. Cathar. What euer was hereÅ¿ie in old times, is hereÅ¿ie yet, and the defenders thereof heretickes: this you cannot deny, becauÅ¿e it is your owne propoÅ¿ition: but theÅ¿e former heades whilk I haue Å¿et downe (wherein I haue vÅ¿ed no calumny as ye haue done) was hereÅ¿ies in olde times, and the defenders
