One thing whilk I hope will cut off all controuerÅ¿ie, I offer to prooue, the Pope to be the AntichriÅ¿t. And if this be true, then all men that profeÅ¿Å¿es him, Å¿ecretly or openly, as it is Å¿aid in the Reuel. 14. Å¿hall drinke of the wine of the wrath of God.

p.hi: MaiÅ¿ter Iohn WelÅ¿che, preacher of ChriÅ¿ts GoÅ¿pell, at Kirkcudbright.

div.p: If this controuerÅ¿ie of ours Å¿hal not be cut away whil MaiÅ¿ter Iohn proue the Pope to be the AntichriÅ¿t, certainly it will indure ten hundreth thouÅ¿and yeare after the Laird of MarchiÅ¿touns doomeÅ¿day. Then it muÅ¿t follow (Å¿eing that is a thing impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be done) that all they that wil not opeÌ lie and priuatlie obey the Pope, and reuerence him as the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e he is choÅ¿en by God to rule his Kirk heir on earth, that they muÅ¿te drinke of the wine of the wrath of God.
div.q:
Our mercifull Lord illuminate MaiÅ¿ter Iohn with his haly Å¿pirit & grace, that he may vnderÅ¿tand the truth, and receaue the Å¿ame, and Å¿o become one member of his true Kirk, whereby he may be partaker of the merites of ChriÅ¿t, that his Å¿oule may be Å¿afe, Amen.
MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert Browne PrieÅ¿t, and defender of the Catholicke Faith.
div.p:
It is not impoÅ¿sible to proue your Popes to be the AntichriÅ¿t. It hes beene prooued alreadie by the learned on our Å¿ide: to the whilk you, and all your Cleargie of Rome is not able to anÅ¿were. It hes bene taught & Å¿ealed with the blood of infinite nombers of ChriÅ¿tians: and I haue not taken Å¿o long a tearme as you haue Å¿et downe heir, and yet, I hope, I haue proued it Å¿ufficiently. Put all your might to diÅ¿proue it if you can. And as to that threatning of yours, MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, wherein ye Å¿ay that all theÅ¿e, who will not openly and priuatelie obey the Pope, &c, muÅ¿t drinke of the wine of the
wrath of God. If it may be beleeued, then howe doth this Å¿tand firÅ¿t with your Popes pardons, whereby he giues men pardon or licence to profeÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ubÅ¿criue, and Å¿weare to our religion: as it is reported that Å¿ome of your owne religion hes confeÅ¿Å¿ed it? Next, howe Å¿tands it with the diÅ¿simulation of your IeÅ¿uites, and Å¿eminarie PrieÅ¿ts when they come to any place where our religion is openlie profeÅ¿Å¿ed? Thirdly, what comfort is this whilk ye haue pronounced to your own poor countriemen, who doe not openly avow PapiÅ¿trie, but hes Å¿ubÅ¿criued and communicate with vs? Is this an open profeÅ¿Å¿ion, or not? And if it be not, if ye be a true Prophet, then muÅ¿t they drinke of the wine of the wrath of God, then muÅ¿t they be condemned in Hel by your iudgemeÌt, becauÅ¿e they profeÅ¿Å¿e him not openlie. And laÅ¿t of all, if this threatning of yours be true, then beÅ¿ide the many infinite thouÅ¿ands who profeÅ¿Å¿es him to be the AntichriÅ¿t, you condemne to Hell all the Greeke and EaÅ¿tern Kirks, who in nomber far exceedes them who obeyes you, and all the Kirks that hes bene 600. yeere and more after ChriÅ¿t: for they obeyed not the Pope openlie nor priuatlie as ChriÅ¿ts Vicare ouer them, as I haue prooued before. And alÅ¿o you condemne a nomber of your Anti-Popes to Hell, with their Cardinals, BiÅ¿hops, & Kirks who followed them: for they gaue out themÅ¿elues to bee Popes, and did not obey the other. As alÅ¿o a nomber of the Fathers of your owne religion, who in two general councels the one of ConÅ¿tance, where there was almoÅ¿t 1000. Fathers: the other of BaÅ¿ile, did not obey the pope, in defining general councels to be aboue the Pope. So, if ye Å¿peak trueth, infinite millions of ChriÅ¿tians in all ages, and innumerable Kirks, & thouÅ¿ands of your owne religion are condemned to hell. But this is falÅ¿e, MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, and who will beleeue you? And to the end nowe my concluÅ¿ion yet holdes Å¿ure, that Å¿eeing his kingdome is that Å¿econd beaÅ¿t that hes two hornes like the Lamb and Å¿peakes like the Dragon: and himÅ¿elf is that man of Å¿inne, Reuel. 23. â¢ . TheÅ¿. 2. and Å¿onne of perdition, that aduerÅ¿ary and AntichriÅ¿t that was to come: Reuel. â¢â¢ . & his doctrine is that ApoÅ¿taÅ¿ie and abhomination foretolde in the Scripture: and his Å¿eat that Harlote and myÅ¿ticall Babylon, that
mother of hoordomes, who is drunken with the blood of the Martyres of IeÅ¿us, whoÅ¿oeuer receaues his mark on his forehead or hand, that is, openly or priuatlye profeÅ¿Å¿es obedience vnto him, Å¿hall, as the Angell proclaimed, drinke of the wyne of the wrath of God, yea of that pure wyne in the cup of his wrath, and he Å¿hall bee tormented with fyre and brimÅ¿tone before the holy Angels, and before the Lambe. And the Å¿moake of his torment Å¿hall aÅ¿cend for euer more: and they Å¿hall haue no reÅ¿t daye nor night whilk worÅ¿hip the beaÅ¿t or his image. And as for your praier, I beÅ¿eech God (MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert) that he may open my eies, and inlarge my harte to vnderÅ¿tande and imbrace his trueth more and more, and to make me to growe vp in that Å¿pirituall communion with ChriÅ¿t and his members more and more. But that whilk ye call trueth is hereÅ¿ie, and that whilk yee call the true Kirk is Babell: and therefore that doctrine and Kirk of yours is that Å¿trong deluÅ¿ion and whore of Babell, with the whilk whoÅ¿oeuer Å¿hall communicate is excluded from the merites of ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿hall be pertakers of her plagues, and finallie Å¿hall bee damned.
THE SECOND PART OF THE REPLY AGAINST MAISTER GILBERT BROWNE PRIEST, CONCERNING THE MASSE AND ANTICHRIST.

Wherein the abhominations of the one is moÅ¿t largely and fully Å¿et downe: and the Popes of Rome are prooued in the other to be the moÅ¿t vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, whilk the Scripture foretold Å¿hould come.
By MAISTER IOHN WELSCHE Preacher of ChriÅ¿ts GoÅ¿pell.
PRINTED BY ROBERT WALDE-GRAVE Printer to the Kings MaieÅ¿tie 1602.
Cum Priuilegio Regio.

div.head: The Å¿euerall things that are handled in the firÅ¿t part concerning the MaÅ¿Å¿e are theÅ¿e.
div.p: 1. COncerning the name it Å¿elfe, the variety of their opinions concerning the deriuation of it, and the cauÅ¿e wherefore they giue it this Å¿tile of MaÅ¿Å¿e is Å¿hewed: and that neither in proper termes, nor in Å¿ubÅ¿tance it is to be fouÌd in the Scriptures of God, & therfore to be reiected
2. That the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e is neither figured nor foretolde in the olde TeÅ¿tament, nor yet inÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t in the new TeÅ¿tament, in the latter Supper.

3. Is Å¿hewed the difference betwixt the MaÅ¿Å¿e, and the latter Supper, whilk ChriÅ¿t inÅ¿tituted: & it is proued that the PrieÅ¿ts in the MaÅ¿Å¿e does not the Å¿ame whilk our Sauiour either did, or commanded to bee done in the latter Supper.
4. It is proued by the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿undry learned PapiÅ¿ts, and great defenders of their Religion, that the MaÅ¿Å¿e is not Å¿et downe in the Scripture, and inÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t in the Å¿ame.
5. That we haue all theÅ¿e things whilk our Sauiour compriÅ¿ed in the inÅ¿titution of the Supper, and they haue them not.

6. Solide, moÅ¿t cleare, and euident proofes out of the Scripture, againÅ¿t the abhominable Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whereby it is Å¿ufficiently confuted, amplified alÅ¿o by their doctrine and teÅ¿timonies.
7. By the teÅ¿timonies of the auncient Fathers euen vntill the 1000 yeare after ChriÅ¿t, it is confuted.

8. That it may bee knowne howe this abhominable Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e crap in. FirÅ¿t, the eÅ¿tate of the publik worÅ¿hip of God in the celebratioÌ of the Å¿acrameÌt of the Supper the firÅ¿t 300. or 400. year after ChriÅ¿t is Å¿et downe: next the manifolde meanes and degrees, wherby it crap in peece and peece: how it was firÅ¿t conceaued, formed, brought forth into the world, and then nouriÅ¿hed, Å¿trengthened, and rooted in the hearts of all men, and vniuerÅ¿ally imbraced. And thirdly, the authors of the ceremonies of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, who put to euery point of it, and in what yeare of God is Å¿et downe. So that betwixt the firÅ¿t that put to the firÅ¿te peece, to the laÅ¿t that clamped to the laÅ¿t cloute, is a thouÅ¿and yeare and more.

9. Is Å¿et downe the manifolde abÅ¿urdities, abhominations, idolatries blaÅ¿phemies, vaine, idle, Å¿uperÅ¿titions, IewiÅ¿h and Ethnick ceremonies of their abhominable MaÅ¿Å¿e, as in a table, a great nomber: whereby it is made euident and plaine to all thoÅ¿e who are not blinded, that of all worÅ¿hips and Å¿eruices that euer was deuiÅ¿ed by man, it is the moÅ¿t abÅ¿urde, blaÅ¿phemous, and idolatrous.

10. The manifolde oppoÅ¿itions and contradictions amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, concerning this their MaÅ¿Å¿e, both in the matter, forme, effect, Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and circumÅ¿tances of the Å¿ame: whereby it is euident, that it is Babel a towne of confuÅ¿ion: and that they and their kingdome cannot Å¿tand, Å¿eing they are Å¿o deuided amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues in this point.

div.head: IN THE SECOND PART CONCERNING the AntichriÅ¿t, theÅ¿e heades are handled
div.p: 1. The reaÅ¿ons that M. Gilbert brings for to defend his Popes froÌ being AntichriÅ¿t are anÅ¿wered. Wherin it is Å¿hewed: firÅ¿t, that AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hould not be a Iewe, and repaire to the temple of IeruÅ¿alem, and the Iewes Å¿houlde not receaue the AntichriÅ¿t, as their MeÅ¿Å¿ias: next, that the Pope. Å¿uppoÅ¿e he pretends that he come in the name of ChriÅ¿t, & that he is the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, and the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands: yet he is nothing leÅ¿Å¿e. He hes neyther his calling of God in his worde, nor is left in the roome of ChriÅ¿t: but hes entered in, not by the doore into the Å¿heepefolde, but another way, as a thief and briggane, to Å¿teale and deuoure, and does no true Å¿eruice to ChriÅ¿t, but tyrannizes ouer his pure flock, and ouer the princes of the earth. Thirdly, that the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hould not bee one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on, but a Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of manie, in the Å¿elf Å¿ame, ApoÅ¿tate kingdome and tyrannie. Fourthly, that for all his pretenÅ¿es of humility and piety, yet he is an aduerÅ¿ary to God, and lifted vp aboue all that is called God.

Secondlye, it is proued by all the markes whereby the AntichriÅ¿t is diÅ¿criued in the Scriptures of God. in the 2. TheÅ¿. 2. Apoc. 13. & 17. that the Popes of Rome are the vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e to him only aggrees all theÅ¿e markes, and to none other. And firÅ¿t they are prooued to be the men of Å¿inne, and Å¿onnes of perdition, by their moÅ¿te monÅ¿trous and abhominable liues, as their owne friends and flatteters, and HiÅ¿toriographers of the time, hes deÅ¿criued them: a few are brought
forth as examples to proue this. Secondly, it is proued that he is an aduerÅ¿ary to God, by comparing of his doctrine with the doctrine of ChriÅ¿t how it ouerthrowes his perÅ¿on, offices, Propheticall, PrieÅ¿tly and Kingly, and all his benefites, and all the meanes, outwarde and inwarde, of the knowing and applying of them: and that it depriues the Lord of his Å¿oueraigne glorie, in communicating to Å¿tockes and Å¿tones, oyle and water a peece of bread, Angell and man, bones and aÅ¿hes, and the moÅ¿te vyle things that can be. And alÅ¿o howe it ouerthrowes the Sacramentes of ChriÅ¿t, and puts to others whilk he neuer inÅ¿tituted: & the whole frame of his DiÅ¿cipline and gouernment, whilk he hes commanded in his word His officers, his offices, his Lawes. And hes put himÅ¿elf in ChriÅ¿ts roome and hes made newe offices, officers, & lawes, whilk the Scripture knows not of. Thirdly, that he hes lifted vp himÅ¿elf aboue al that is called God, or that is worÅ¿hipped. FirÅ¿t, aboue the whole Kirk, and all general couÌ cels: next, aboue al Kings, Magistrates, and powers: And thirdly, aboue the Angels in heauen, and aboue them in Purgatorie and Hell: & hes equalled himÅ¿elf with God himÅ¿elf, in his Å¿tyles, and properties, and workes, and equalled himÅ¿elfe to ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. And hes alÅ¿o lifted vp himÅ¿elf aboue the God of heauen and his Å¿onne ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. Fourthly, that he Å¿ittes in the Temple of God as God, and Å¿o forth of the reÅ¿t in the 2. TheÅ¿Å¿al. 2. chap. and in the Reuelation. Whereby it is Å¿hewen, that euery thing that is foretolde of the AntichriÅ¿t, is fully filled & accompliÅ¿hed in them: and that Babylon that harlote, that is Å¿et downe in the Reuelation, is by their owne confeÅ¿Å¿ion, Rome. Further, it is alÅ¿o prooued by the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿undry of themÅ¿elues, and others, that the Popes of Rome is the vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, and Rome is that Babel.

div.head: The Å¿econd part of the Reply againÅ¿t MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert Browne

div.p: WE haue onelie in our Kirk that heauenly action and Sacrifice, (whilk we call the bliÅ¿Å¿ed MaÅ¿Å¿e) that our Sauiour did at his latter Supper, and was Leuit. 2. per totum. Leuit. 6.20. prefigured by the Law of MoÅ¿es, & foreÅ¿poken by the Mala. 1.10. 1 â¢ EÅ¿a. 19 19.21, EÅ¿a. 56.7 Prophetes. For ChriÅ¿t beeing the chiefe PrieÅ¿t of all PrieÅ¿ts (according to the order of GeneÅ¿. 14.18. PÅ¿al 109.4 Heb. 73.17 MelchiÅ¿edech in this action, & according to the order of Heb 9.12.13 14 Aaron vpon the Croce) tooke Mat. 26 26.27 bread and wine, and hauing giuen Luc. 22.19 thankes to his Father of heuin, Mar. 14.22 bliÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame, by the whilk 1. Cor. 10.16 bliÅ¿Å¿ing, and heauenly words he made them his bodie and blood, [as I Å¿aide before] and Luc. 22 29. gaue, or offered himÅ¿elfe then for them, (that is) for his. And laÅ¿t of all gaue the Å¿ame body and blood to his ApoÅ¿tles to be eaten, whilk we call to 1. Cor. 0 16. communicate. And when he had done the Å¿ame, he commanded his ApoÅ¿tles, (and by them the lawfull PaÅ¿tors of the Kirk till the worldes end) to doe the Å¿ame, for the Luke 22.19. remembrance of him. And Å¿eing that our PrieÅ¿ts does the Å¿ame, as our Sauiour did, how can MaiÅ¿ter Iohn Å¿ay that our religion (in this) was not inÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t?

I Come to the 10. point of your doctrine concerning the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e: whilk Å¿uppoÅ¿e ye call bliÅ¿Å¿ed, yet is it moÅ¿t abhominable idolatrie, as (by the grace of God) Å¿hall be made manifeÅ¿t. And firÅ¿te concerning the word it Å¿elfe MASSE, you are of Å¿ik variety of opinions amongÅ¿t your Å¿elues concerning it, that As doctor Bellarmine in his anÅ¿were to PleÅ¿Å¿is de Mornay. de EuchariÅ¿t. lib. 11. cap. 1. & Genebrard. in Liturg. S, Denis from the word MESSAH Deut. 16.10. that properlie Å¿ignifieth Å¿ufficiencie, but Bellarm. refutes this, lib. 1. de MiÅ¿Å¿a, cap. 1 Å¿ome of you Å¿ayes it is taken from the Hebrew: Å¿ome Bull â¢ nger ibidem from ã in non-Latin alphabet ã that Å¿ignifies a Å¿ecret Å¿anctification, from the whi â¢ k comes myÅ¿terie. from the Greeke, Å¿ome As Bellarmine ibidem, and Å¿undrie others from mitto, miÅ¿Å¿io, or dimiÅ¿Å¿io. from the Latine: and Some becauÅ¿e the Å¿acrifice and praiers is Å¿ent to God in the Å¿ame, as Hugo de S Vict de Å¿acram. lib. 2. part. â¢ cap. vlt. Å¿ome Å¿ayes it is called the MaÅ¿Å¿e for one cauÅ¿e, and Some becauÅ¿e an Angell as they Å¿ay is Å¿ent vnto the Å¿ame, as Lombardus in 4. Å¿ent. diÅ¿t. 13 & Thomas part 3. queÅ¿t. 83. And Å¿ome becauÅ¿e the people is diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed, ond Å¿end forth, as Bellar. lib. 1. de MiÅ¿Å¿a, cap, 1. Å¿ome for another.
I will only Å¿peake this of it, that it is vÅ¿ually taken by the auncient writers, for the dimiÅ¿sion, or skailling (as we cal it) of the Kirk, after the publict Å¿eruice was done to God, as Bellarmine graunts, in the firÅ¿t acception of this word MaÅ¿Å¿e. And therefore in the end of your MaÅ¿Å¿e, the Deacon cries, Ite miÅ¿Å¿a eÅ¿t, that is, Goe your way, the CongregatioÌ is diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed. But now the PapiÅ¿ts takes not the word in this Å¿enÅ¿e, for the skailling of the Kirk, or dimiÅ¿sion of the people, after the Å¿eruice of preaching, prayer, & Å¿o forth: but for that abhominable Å¿acrifice of theirs, wherin, as they Å¿uppone, they offer vp ChriÅ¿t his very bodie and blood, in a Å¿acrifice for the quick and the dead as MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert does heir. And for this cauÅ¿e they as Durandus li. 4. rational. diuin. call this Å¿acrifice, the MaÅ¿Å¿e, that is, firÅ¿t Å¿ent from the Father to vs, that ChriÅ¿t his bodie and blood might be with vs: next, Å¿ent from vs to the Father, that he may interceede, and may be for vs with the Father. But how can he be Å¿ent from them to heauen? Å¿eing he deÅ¿cends in the mouth, Å¿tomack, and bellie of the PrieÅ¿t? for to be Å¿ent downe to the bellie of the PrieÅ¿t, and to be Å¿ent vp to heauen, are things contrarie. So by this Å¿tile of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, as they take it, it is plaine, that either ChriÅ¿t deÅ¿cends from heauen in the earth dailie in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk Turrian. 1. tract cap, 11. fol 59 Å¿ome of theÌ graunts alÅ¿o) whilk is contrary to an article of our faith, that he Å¿its at the right haÌd of his Father, whom the Act. 3.21 heauens muÅ¿t contain vntil the time that al things be reÅ¿tored: or elÅ¿e their MaÅ¿Å¿e-prieÅ¿ts, duÅ¿t and aÅ¿hes, are the creators of their creator, whilk is a blaÅ¿phemie.

This mekle now for the name of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk al chriÅ¿tians Å¿hould abhorre, according to that of PÅ¿al. 16.4 Dauid, that he would not take the name of falÅ¿e Gods in his mouth. For that word, whilk is proponed by men for an article of our faith, whilk is not found in the Scripture, neither in proper termes, nor yet in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and by neceÅ¿Å¿ary conÅ¿equence out of the Å¿ame, Å¿hould be reiected by the kirk of God, as a profane, and a baÅ¿tard worde. But the MaÅ¿Å¿e is Å¿ik: for it is proponed by the Kirk of Rome, as an article of our faith: and yet it is neither found in proper termes, nor in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, nor by any neceÅ¿Å¿ary conÅ¿equence out of the Scripture: Therefore it Å¿houlde
be reiected; as prophane & idolatrous, by the Kirk of God.

This for the name: nowe to the matter. This is one of the greateÅ¿t controuerÅ¿ies betwixt you and vs, concerning your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e: whilk, as ye account it moÅ¿t heauenly, Å¿o we account it moÅ¿t abhominable, as that whilk iniures the Å¿onne of God, whilk derogates from his death and paÅ¿sion, whilk is iniurious to his euerlaÅ¿ting PrieÅ¿t-hoode, whilk is idolatrous, vaine, neidleÅ¿Å¿e, and fruteleÅ¿Å¿e, whilk hinders and ouerthrowes the true Å¿eruice of God: all whilk Å¿halbe made plaine of it, by Gods grace. The matter of our controuerÅ¿ie therefore is: Whether IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, God and man, his bodie and blood be perÅ¿onally and corporally offered vp, in your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, (as ye call it) and whether this your Å¿acrifice be a propitiatorie Å¿acrifice, for the Å¿innes of the quicke and the deade: this your Kirk affirmes and holdes, and this we deny. Now let vs Å¿ee your reaÅ¿ons firÅ¿t, and then we will Å¿et downe what reaÅ¿ons we haue for vs out of the worde of God, to the contrary. As to yours. FirÅ¿t, ye Å¿ay it was prefigured by the Law of MoÅ¿es: next, forÅ¿poken by the Prophets and thirdly, done and inÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t our Sauiour, and commanded by him to be done to the end of the world. As to the firÅ¿te, This Å¿acrifice was prefigured by the Å¿acrifices of the olde TeÅ¿tament, for the whilk purpoÅ¿e ye quote Leuit. 2. and 6.20. Vnto the whilk I anÅ¿were: that the Å¿acrifices of the olde TeÅ¿tament were figures and Å¿hadowes, of that great & bloody Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, once offered vp, vpon the croce, neuer to be offered vp againe, as Heb. 9.25.26.27.28. the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿aies: and of our Å¿pirituall Å¿acrifices, and Å¿eruice to God, whereof the Rom. 12.1. Heb. 13.15.16. ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peakes in theÅ¿e places cited on the margent. The whilk alÅ¿o were fulfilled in that one, and only Å¿acrifice of him Å¿elfe vpon the croce, for the Å¿innes of the world: and are fulfilled in our Å¿pirituall Å¿acrifices of our Å¿elues, & of the calues of our lips continuallie. But that theÅ¿e were figures of your abhominable Å¿acrifice in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, there is not a Å¿illabe in the whole Scripture, to proue the Å¿ame: for that whilk was prefigured in the olde TeÅ¿tament, was, and is fulfilled in the new TeÅ¿tament. But the new TeÅ¿tament hes not Å¿o mekle as one
Å¿illabe of your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e: therefore it could not be prefigured in the olde TeÅ¿tament. For if it were prefigured by the Å¿acrifices of the olde TeÅ¿tament, it behooued either to be one with the Å¿pirituall Å¿acrifice of all ChriÅ¿tians, or elÅ¿e one with the bloodie Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿t vpon the Croce: for only theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Å¿acrifices are prefigured in the old TeÅ¿tament, and recorded to bee fulfilled in the new TeÅ¿tament: but your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, is one with neither of them: for it is not one with the firÅ¿t Å¿ort, for they are Å¿pirituall, and you will haue it externall: neither is it one with the other of ChriÅ¿ts Å¿acrifice vpon the Croce, for there he died, & there he Å¿hed his blood, and there he Å¿uffered the tormentes of Gods wrath, and indignation for our Å¿innes: and there he Å¿atisfied the iuÅ¿tice of God, and merited an euerlaÅ¿ting redemption to vs. But in your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, your Ballarm. lib. 2. de miÅ¿Å¿a. cap. 4. Å¿elues graunts, that neither is he crucified, nor is his blood Å¿hed, nor Å¿uffers he the wrath of God for our Å¿innes, nor Å¿atiÅ¿fies properly the iuÅ¿tice of God for the Å¿ame, nor properly merites remiÅ¿Å¿ion of our Å¿innes in the MaÅ¿Å¿e: therefore it is not one with that Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿t vpon the Croce. For two Å¿euerall actions whilk hes two different formes, & are done in diuers times, and places, for diuerÅ¿e ends, cannot be one only, and the Å¿elf Å¿ame Å¿acrifice: for it is the forme that giues a thing to be, and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hes it from all other things. But ChriÅ¿t his offering vp of himÅ¿elf vpon the croce, and your Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e hes different formes, are done in diuerÅ¿e places and times & for diuerÅ¿e ends, therefore they cannot be both one. Further, if they were both one, then it Å¿hould follow, that as the Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿t vpon the Croce is of an infinite valure, Å¿o the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould be of the Å¿ame valure. But Bellarm. Å¿ayes, lib. 2. de miÅ¿Å¿a. cap. 4. fol. 740. That the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿se, is but of a finite valour, and the Å¿acrifice of the Croce of an infinite valour. Therefore they cannot be both one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame Å¿acrifice: Therefore this Å¿acrifice of your MaÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿eeing it is not one with neither of theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Å¿acrifices, is not prefigured in the olde TeÅ¿tament.

As for the Å¿econd: that it was foretolde by the Prophets:
It is as true as the former: for all the Å¿acrifices whilk were fore-tolde by the Prophetes in the olde teÅ¿taments, are fulfilled in the newe TeÅ¿tament. But the newe TeÅ¿tament, (as hes bene Å¿aide) makes only mention of theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Å¿acrifices, ChriÅ¿ts on the Croce, and our Å¿piritual Å¿acrifices: and not a Å¿illabe of the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e: Therefore it is not fore-tolde by the Prophetes in the olde TeÅ¿tament. As for theÅ¿e Malac. 1.10.11 1 â¢ EÅ¿a. 19.19.21 â¢ Å¿a. 56.7 Scriptures whilk ye quote, they Å¿peake of the Å¿pirituall worÅ¿hip of God, and of the Å¿pirituall Å¿acrifices, whilk the Gentiles being called, Å¿hould offer vp vnto God, vnder the GoÅ¿pel, whereof mention is made in theÅ¿e Heb 13.15 16 1. Pet. 2.5. Rom. 12.1. Rom. 15.16. places. For either they Å¿peake properlie and literally, or elÅ¿e figuratiuelie. But if you Å¿ay they Å¿peake properly of externall Å¿acrifices then they Å¿peake heir of that legal, and ceremonial worÅ¿hip of the Iewes, and Å¿o theÅ¿e places does not appertaine to the new TeÅ¿tament. Or, if you will Å¿ay they Å¿peak figuratiuely, then, I Å¿ay, they make nothing for your externall Å¿acrifice in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk you will haue to be a Å¿acrifice, not figuratiuely, but properly. So howÅ¿oeuer ye expone them, they caÌ no waies make for your externall Å¿acrifice in the MaÅ¿Å¿e. And therefore

Iul â¢ anum & ad Hebraeos homil. 11. AmbroÅ¿ius ad Heb. cap. 10. & ad Theod. epiÅ¿t. 28. & in epiÅ¿t. ad Rom. cap 12. Hieronymus in EÅ¿aiam, cap. 1. & in PÅ¿al. 26. & 49. & 50. AuguÅ¿tinus de fide ad Petrum Diacon. cap. 2. & de Trinitat â¢ lib. 4. cap. 1. & 14. & in PÅ¿al. 49. & de ciuitate Dei, lib. 10. cap. 4. & 6. Idem de tempore. BaÅ¿ile. And he Å¿aies further, There is no more queÅ¿tion of a continuall Å¿acrifice: for there is but one Å¿acrifice whilk is ChriÅ¿t, and the mortification of his Saints. BecauÅ¿e it were ouer longÅ¿ome to Å¿et downe the Å¿entences of the reÅ¿t, therefore I will only quote them on the margent: & I would deÅ¿ire MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert to reade the Å¿ame. And if hee will beleeue them, I am Å¿ure he will leaue off to be a MaÅ¿Å¿e-PrieÅ¿t any longer: for they all aggree in this, that the Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿t vpon the croce, hes accompliÅ¿hed all the Å¿acrifices of the old Lawe: and that the vertue of it is euerlaÅ¿ting and therefore Å¿hould not be reiterate: and that the Å¿acrifice of ChriÅ¿tians are not propitiatorie, but only Å¿pirituall.

Seing therefore the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e was Å¿o long vnknowne to the Kirk of ChriÅ¿t, it remaines now that we Å¿how by what degrees it crap in: for as after the going downe of the Sun, darkenes commes not in immediatly, but there is a twi-light before the darkenes come: euen Å¿o after the bright
Å¿tarres of the primitiue Kirk had ended their courÅ¿e, in proceÅ¿Å¿e of time, and peece and peece: firÅ¿t, the third part of the Sunne, Moone, and Å¿tarres were darkened: till at the laÅ¿t the bottomles pit was opened, & that great darkenes came vp, as the Å¿moake of a great fornace, that darkened both the Sunne and the aire. Out of the whilk this great abhomination of the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e did proceede. For Bertram. de corpore & Å¿ang. Domi. in Heb. 7. Bertrame who liued betweene the 800. and 900. yeare after ChriÅ¿t, Å¿ayes, Our Sauiour hes done it once in offering vp himÅ¿elfe: for he hes once offered vp himÅ¿elf for the Å¿innes of the people: and this oblation is alwaies celebrate eueryday, but in a myÅ¿terie: and he Å¿ayes, that once oblation of ChriÅ¿t is handled euery day by the celebration of theÅ¿e myÅ¿teries or Å¿acraments, in the remembrance of his paÅ¿sion. There he oppones a real Å¿acrifice to a myÅ¿tery, & ChriÅ¿ts Å¿acrifice once made, to a daily commemoration or remembrance of his Å¿uffering. Haymo in cap. 5. OÅ¿e. & in cap. 2 Abac. & Malac. 1. Haymo Å¿iklike, reckoning out the Å¿acrifices of ChriÅ¿tians, he calles there, the praiÅ¿es of the beleeuers, the penitence of Å¿inners, the teares of Å¿upplications, their praiers, and almes. Theophilact in Ioan. cap. 8. & ad Heb. cap, 10 Theophilact, who liued in the 900. yeare after ChriÅ¿t, he Å¿ayes, That there is but one Å¿acrifice, and not many: becauÅ¿e ChriÅ¿t hes offered vp himÅ¿elf once. And he Å¿ayes in an other place: ChriÅ¿t hes offered vp himÅ¿elfe once, a Å¿ufficient Å¿acrifice for euer, and we haue neede of no other Å¿acrifice: to wit, propitiatorie. And AnÅ¿elm, in ep. ad Heb. cap. 10. AnÅ¿elm who liued in the 1000. yeare of God and after, he Å¿ayes, That whilk we offer euery day is the remembrance of the death of ChriÅ¿t, and that there is but one Å¿acrifice, not many: for it hes bene once only offered vp. And again, Our Lord, Å¿ayes he, bade take eate, not Å¿acrifice and offer vp to God. So this was the doctrine of the moÅ¿te learned, who liued 1000. yeares after ChriÅ¿t, that ChriÅ¿t offers vp himÅ¿elf but once, and that Å¿acrifice, was Å¿ufficient and euerlaÅ¿ting, and the Å¿acrifices of ChriÅ¿tians are Å¿pirituall: and the Å¿acrament (whilk they called Å¿ometimes a Å¿acrifice) was a commemoration of ChriÅ¿ts one Å¿acrifice, once offered vp vpon the Croce. But from thence vnto this time, this abuÅ¿e and Å¿acrifice of their MaÅ¿Å¿e crap in, but by diuerÅ¿e degrees, and by the concurrence of many cauÅ¿es.

argument.p: The degrees and meanes wherby the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e crap in. FirÅ¿t, I will Å¿et downe the eÅ¿tate of the publick worÅ¿hip of God in the Primitiue Kirk, the firÅ¿t 300. or 400. yeares after ChriÅ¿t, and then the meanes and degrees whereby this abhominable Å¿acrifice crap in.

div.p:
FIrÅ¿t, it is manifeÅ¿t, that in the primitiue Kirk, the communion or Å¿acrament of the Lords Supper, IuÅ¿tin. Martyr in apolog, 2. & Tertul, apolog. Aug, de conÅ¿ecrat diÅ¿t 2 cap, Quotidie AmbroÅ¿, lib, 5, ca, 4, de Å¿acramen was miniÅ¿tred euery weeke once, vpon the Lords day: and in Å¿ome place it was miniÅ¿tred euery day, as appeares by theÅ¿e places. And therefore AmbroÅ¿e who liued in the three hundreth age, exhorteth to a dayly receauing of it. Next, from the Communion was excluded, firÅ¿t theÅ¿e who were not Å¿ufficiently inÅ¿tructed in the grounds of chriÅ¿tianity, who were called Catechumeni, that is, catechiÅ¿ed and inÅ¿tructed by queÅ¿tions and anÅ¿weres. Next, theÅ¿e who had not ended out their repentance, and Å¿atisfaction to the Kirk who were called Poenitentes, that is, penitents. And thirdly, theÅ¿e who were poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with an euill Å¿pirite, who were called ã in non-Latin alphabet ã All theÅ¿e, after that the firÅ¿t praier, the reading of the Scripture, the Å¿ermon, and the rehearÅ¿ing of the Creede (at the whilk they were preÅ¿ent) were ended, they were commanded by the Deacon to retire themÅ¿elues, and to depart out of the aÅ¿Å¿embly or congregation, that place might be giuen to the faithfull, who was to communicate, in theÅ¿e words: Ite, miÅ¿Å¿a eÅ¿t: The origen of the word MaÅ¿Å¿e Lib, 1, de MiÅ¿Å¿a, cap. 1 that is, Goe your way, depart. And from this firÅ¿t came the word MaÅ¿Å¿e in the Kirk of God: and this Bellarmine confeÅ¿Å¿es, whilk in Latine is called miÅ¿sio, or dimiÅ¿sio, or miÅ¿Å¿a: and in the Greeke ã in non-Latin alphabet ã For the Pagans vÅ¿ed that Å¿ame word after their Å¿acrifice was ended. In Apule, lib, 11 de metamorph. And the abuÅ¿e eaÅ¿ily growing in the frequent vÅ¿ing of this word, it came to paÅ¿Å¿e by time, that all the worÅ¿hip of God, as the firÅ¿t praiers, the Å¿inging of the PÅ¿almes, the reading of the Scripture, the preaching of the word, the rehearÅ¿ing of the Å¿imbolo, whilk was performed in
the aÅ¿Å¿embly before the dimiÅ¿sion of theÅ¿e who were catechiÅ¿ed,
As Bellarm. confeÅ¿Å¿es lib. 1. de miÅ¿Å¿a cap. 1. Conc. Valent. ca. 1
Bellarm. ibidem. Alcuinus a PapiÅ¿t de officiis EccleÅ¿ cap de celebratione MiÅ¿Å¿ae was called MiÅ¿Å¿a Catechumenorum. And the reÅ¿t of the worÅ¿hip of God whilk was done after their departure, to the dimiÅ¿sion of the faithfull, as the celebration of the Supper, &c. was called MiÅ¿sa Fidelium. So then this word MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk the Kirk of Rome aÅ¿criues nowe vnto their pretended Å¿acrifice, came firÅ¿t from the dimiÅ¿sion, or skailling of the people (as they call it) from the Lords Å¿eruice, and was neuer heard of in the Kirk of ChriÅ¿t, nor read of in any authour, Hebrewe, Greeke, or Latine, for the Å¿pace of 400. yeare almoÅ¿te after ChriÅ¿t. And Ierome who liued in the yeare 422. and was an Elder in Rome, who write Å¿o many volumes, made no mention of this word MaÅ¿Å¿e, at all. For that commentary of the Prouerbes whilk is aÅ¿criued vnto him, where mention is made of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, See Marianus Victorius Reat. in praefat. in 8. tom. operum Hier. * is not his: for beÅ¿ide other things there, mention is made of Gregorie, who liued almoÅ¿te 200, yeare after him. And AmbroÅ¿e makes mention of it only once, and Saint AuguÅ¿tine twiÅ¿e or thriÅ¿e, for al the volumes whilk they write if theÅ¿e books be theirs. For EraÅ¿mus in his cenÅ¿ures vpon the Å¿ermons de Tempore, Å¿aies that many of them are found vnder the names of other authours, and Å¿auours little either of AuguÅ¿tines learning, or phraÅ¿e. See Iames Gillotius in praefat. ad AmbroÅ¿. And that neither of them in the exponing of the matter of the Sacrament, whilk they handled moÅ¿t largely: the one in Å¿exe bookes, and the other moÅ¿t largely and frequently, and in the foreÅ¿aide places: they vÅ¿ed it in a far other Å¿enÅ¿e, then it is taken nowe in the Kirk of Rome: for by this worde they neither vnderÅ¿tood a Å¿acrament, nor a Å¿acrifice, as the Kirk of Rome does. For Lib, 5. epiÅ¿t. 33. AmbroÅ¿e takes it for the whole Å¿eruice whilk was proper to the faithfull. And AuguÅ¿tine in In Å¿erm. 237. de tempor. one place, for the dimiÅ¿sion of theÅ¿e who were catechiÅ¿ed: and in the In Å¿ermone de tempo. 251 & 91 other two places, for the whole Å¿eruice, aÅ¿wel of the Catechumeni, as of the faithfull. So rarely was it vÅ¿ed by the lights of that age, and in a far other Å¿enÅ¿e, then the Kirk of Rome takes it now. But what a Å¿trange change hes falne in this word MaÅ¿Å¿e, the abuÅ¿e growing by time more & more? FirÅ¿t, from a commandement to the people to depart, Ite,
miÅ¿sa est, and that in euill latine, for Ite, miÅ¿sio or dimiÅ¿sio est, it paÅ¿Å¿ed to Å¿ignify the Å¿eruice of God, and from thence to Å¿ignify a Å¿acrifice, and from thence to Å¿ignify that opus operatum, that work wroght of that abhominable Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e for the quick and the dead: Å¿o that now in end it holdes that place in the Romane Kirk, that Mineruas image, whilk (as was Å¿uppoÅ¿ed fell out of heauen in a temple, in the cietye of Troy) did holde amongÅ¿t them: Å¿o that, as they thought it was their onely protection and fortreÅ¿Å¿e, and as long as they kept it, they were in no danger to haue beene ouercome by the Grecians their enemies. So doth the PapiÅ¿tical kirk think of this their MaÅ¿Å¿e: and this for the 2. point, of the forme of the publick worÅ¿hip of God in the primitiue Kirk. Thirdly, after the dimiÅ¿sion of the Catechumeni, the faithfull who was commanded to remaine and communicate, they did offer vp of their goodes, and firÅ¿t fruits vnto God, before they did communicate: whilk (for the moÅ¿t prrt) was of breade and wine: or of their firÅ¿t fruits of cornes & raÅ¿ings, whereof Å¿o much was taken, as did Å¿erue for breade and wine to the communicants. And the reÅ¿t that remained, was eyther eaten in common amongÅ¿t the faithfull, whereof alÅ¿o Å¿ome was Å¿ent vnto them who were Å¿icke, or abÅ¿ent, in a teÅ¿timonie of their communion with them: (from whence Å¿prung that abuÅ¿e and idolatry in the Kirk of Rome, The origen of the Å¿ending of the Sacrament to the Å¿icke. in carrying of the Å¿acrament, whilk they call the Lord God, to the Å¿icke) or elÅ¿e was diÅ¿tributed vnto the poore. And when the Kirk waxed riche, as it did after the time of ConÅ¿tantine, the oblations abounded: and apart thereof was alÅ¿o imploied vnto the maintenance of the miniÅ¿trie, as Ierome witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿aying, Clerici de altari viuunt: altari Å¿ervientes, altaris oblatione Å¿uÅ¿tentantur. The Cleargie liues of the altar, and are Å¿uÅ¿tained by the oblations therof: The whilk begat auarice in them: & their auarice brought in the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, as we Å¿hall Å¿ee afterward. Nowe theÅ¿e oblations whilk were giuen by the faithfull, for the Å¿uÅ¿tentation of the miniÅ¿terie, for the reliefe of the poore, & furniÅ¿hing materials to the communion, was called after the cuÅ¿tome of the olde law Phil. 4. Heb. 1 â¢ Iren. lib. 4. cap. 32 Cypr. de Bleemo Å¿ina. Å¿acrifices.
So the ApoÅ¿t. Paule, Irenaeus, & Cyprian calles them. And Paulinus epiÅ¿t. de gazophyla. pag. 349. calles the place where theÅ¿e offerings was preÅ¿eÌted, a Table. And theÅ¿e was preÅ¿eÌted vnto the IuÅ¿tin. Matt, apolog. 2 MiniÅ¿ter, who by praier did conÅ¿ecrate them vnto God, as is manifeÅ¿t by the praiers Å¿et down in the Liturgies. Tua ex tuis tibi offerimus: that is, Of thy owne, wee offer thy owne things vnto thee. And, Has oblationes famulorum, famularumque tuarum benignus aÅ¿sume, quas Å¿inguli obtulerunt: that is, Mercifully receaue theÅ¿e oblations of thy Å¿eruands whilk euery one of them hes offered vp to thee: and Å¿undry other praiers of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk can no waies be Å¿poken of the Å¿acrifice of the Å¿onne of God, The meanes and degrees wherby this â¢ bhominable Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e crap in and was conceaued, fo â¢ med brought foorth, Å¿trengthened, & embraced of all. without blaÅ¿phemie, as Å¿hall be Å¿eene afterward. And this was the eÅ¿tate of the Kirk three or foure hundreth yeare after ChriÅ¿t. But the loue of God decaying, and the hearts of men and wemen waxing colde in the worÅ¿hip of God, the people did not communicate Å¿o oft. And therefore we reade of the complaints of the AmbroÅ¿, lib, 5, c 4, de Å¿acram: ChryÅ¿oÅ¿t, in epiÅ¿t a â¢ EpheÅ¿, AuguÅ¿t epiÅ¿t, 119 Fathers, of the rarity of the communicants, and of their vehement exhortations to the people to coÌmunicate euery day: or at the leaÅ¿t, euery Saboth. But theÅ¿e exhortations did not profite, and therefore there was De conÅ¿ecratione diÅ¿tinct, 1, cap EpiÅ¿copus, & diÅ¿t â¢ , cap, Peracta, & cap. Hi qui intrant Canons and lawes made, to bind the people to communicate, at the leaÅ¿t, euery Saboth: otherwiÅ¿e, to be thruÅ¿t out at the Kirk dores. And alÅ¿o Carol, magnus lib, 1, cap, 138, 182, 167 Ciuill lawes for that Å¿ame effect. But theÅ¿e lawes did gaine but little: for whether it was the obÅ¿tinacy of the people, or that they were not preaÅ¿ed vnto it by their PaÅ¿tors, they did waxe more and more negligent in communicating. And therefore DiÅ¿tinct, 2, cap Saeculares, & cap Si non. & cap, Scis homo Ciuil lawes, lib. 2 cap, 45, ad 3, 38 Lawes were made, that if not oftner, at the leaÅ¿t thriÅ¿e in the yeare the people Å¿hould communicate: to wit, at PaÅ¿che, at ChriÅ¿tiÅ¿time, & at PentecoÅ¿t, otherwiÅ¿e not to bee reputed as ChriÅ¿tians. But for all this the people did not communicate, for the moÅ¿t part: Å¿o that in end a Extra, de penit & remiÅ¿, cap, Omnis law was made, that at the leaÅ¿t once in the yeare, they Å¿hould communicate: to wit, at PaÅ¿che. The whilk cuÅ¿tome is yet kept in the Kirk of Rome. So by theÅ¿e degrees the Communion was loÅ¿te in the celebration of the Supper amongÅ¿t the people: firÅ¿t, from a dayly communion in Å¿ome places, to once in the weeke, and from
thence to thriÅ¿e in the yeare, and from thence to once in the yeare: Å¿o that ordinarily there did none communicate but the MiniÅ¿tery and Cleargie. But in proceÅ¿Å¿e of time this corruption ouertooke them alÅ¿o: and therefore De conÅ¿ec. diÅ¿t 1. cap. Hoc quoque. & cap. Omnes fideles. Lawes, both Ciuill and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall was made, to conÅ¿traine them to coÌmunicate: & that at the leaÅ¿t two or three Å¿hould coÌmunicate with the PrieÅ¿t: the foot-Å¿teps whereof yet remaynes in the abbacy of Clugme, where the Deacon and Å¿ub-deacon coÌmunicats yet with the PrieÅ¿t. And of this came the diÅ¿tribution of the bread of the Å¿acrament in three peeces, according to the nomber of the communicants, whilk is yet vÅ¿ed in the Kirk of Rome, Å¿uppoÅ¿e they haue drawn it now to Å¿ignify a myÅ¿terie: and theÅ¿e three at the laÅ¿t was brought to one, and this one to the Clarke that rang the Bell. And at the laÅ¿t, Å¿ome of the PrieÅ¿ts themÅ¿elues did abÅ¿tain from coÌ municating: and therefore lawes was made, aÅ¿well De conÅ¿ec diÅ¿t. 2 cap. Velatum eÅ¿t. EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, as Carol. magn. lib 5. cap, 93. & lib, 6 cap. 118. & addi. 2 cap. 7 Ciuill, to conÅ¿traine them to communicate at all times, after the conÅ¿ecration. So that by theÅ¿e degrees the communion in the Å¿acrament, was loÅ¿t alÅ¿o amongÅ¿t the miniÅ¿try: firÅ¿t, from an ordinary communion whilk they vÅ¿ed it paÅ¿Å¿ed to three or foure, & froÌ the three to one, & froÌ this one to the Clark that rang the bell: The firÅ¿t Å¿tep was the loÅ¿ing of the communion in the celebration of the Supper, firÅ¿t amongÅ¿t the people, and then amongÅ¿t the Cleargie, & ofttimes to the PrieÅ¿t himÅ¿elf alone. And this loÅ¿ing of the coÌmunioÌ in the celebratioÌ of the Supper, firÅ¿t amongÅ¿t the people, next amongÅ¿t the Cleargie, was the firÅ¿t Å¿tep to their pretended Å¿acrifice. Now when the people did communicat, there was Å¿o much bread and wine, in a great quantity brought to the Table, to bee conÅ¿ecrate by praier, as might Å¿erue them. Then as the noÌ ber of the communicants decaied, The Å¿econd degree or Å¿tep was the diminiÅ¿hing of the materials of the communion. Å¿o was the bread & wine proportionably diminiÅ¿hed. And as it came to this at the laÅ¿t, that none did communicate but the PrieÅ¿t & his Clark, and oftentimes none but the PrieÅ¿t only: Å¿o no more bread & wine was brought to the table, to be conÅ¿ecrate, but that that Å¿erued him. And Å¿o from many breades it came to one: and from a great breade to Å¿o Å¿mal a bread, that it might be parted in three: and in end it is come to the quantity of a denier, as Durandus a PapiÅ¿t Å¿ayes. And Å¿ik like of the wyne, froÌ many great veÅ¿hels, to Å¿mall pottels, from many Cupes, to
one: and from a great Cupe to a Å¿mall. And this was the Å¿econd Å¿tep to their pretended Å¿acrifice. The third Å¿tep, the auarice of the PrieÅ¿ts. Thirdly, from the peoples negligence in communicating, proceeded their negligence in bringing their oblations: for theÅ¿e two were ioyned together, their communicating and their offerings, a part whereof was taken for the maintenance of the Cleargy But the PrieÅ¿ts they would not want their offerings, & therfore they procured ciuill lawes to be made, to conÅ¿traine the people to bring their offerings. Therefore Charles the great made a law, Ciuill lawes. Carolus magnus lib, 7. cap. 94. & lib. 6. That the people might be admoniÅ¿hed to communicate, & to bring their offering euery Sabboth: for the one ceaÅ¿ing, the other ceaÅ¿ed alÅ¿o: and the PrieÅ¿t did demand the one, vnder the pretext of the other. And heir was the third Å¿tep, the auarice of the PrieÅ¿ts. But while as neither ciuill nor EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall lawes could preuaile with the people to make them to communicate, and to bring their offerings: they deuyÅ¿ed this damnable doctrine, and taught it to the people, That not only the Lords Supper was a Å¿acrament, The fourt Å¿tep of their damnable doctrine, that the Å¿acrament was a meritorious Å¿acrifice aÅ¿well for the preÅ¿ent as abÅ¿ent, for the communicants as beholders, for the dead as for the liuing and Å¿o was profitable onely to them that did communicate, but alÅ¿o it was a Å¿acrifice to God, and therfore was profitable for all them that were beholders of it, & by the merite thereof they might obtaine mercie and grace: yea, that it was not only meritorious to the beholders, but alÅ¿o to all theÅ¿e for whome the PrieÅ¿t Å¿aide it, aÅ¿well dead as liuing, abÅ¿ent, as preÅ¿ent, not only for the Å¿oule, but alÅ¿o for all other neceÅ¿sities, aÅ¿well of beaÅ¿tes as of men, Å¿o being they brought their offerings alÅ¿o to the PrieÅ¿t, the whilk they taught to be meritorious both for them and theirs. For to keepe the people therefore in Å¿ome deuotion, The cauÅ¿es wherfore the PrieÅ¿tes taught Å¿ik damnable doctrine Å¿o diligentlie to their people, was their owne gaine, for they were nouriÅ¿hed by Å¿ik doctrine as we Å¿ay, and for to mooue them to bring their offerings vnto the PrieÅ¿ts, this doctrine of ChriÅ¿ts Å¿acrament, that it was a moÅ¿te meritorious Å¿acrifice, and of the peoples oblations, that they were profitable for them & theirs, was firÅ¿t invented by the auaritious cleargie, and taught to the people. And therfore Charles the great in his Lawes, inioyned to the PrieÅ¿ts to make the people to vnderÅ¿tand diÅ¿tinctly the force of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, how far it was profitable both for them and theirs, both for the liuing & the dead: and to the people that they Å¿hould bring their offerings coÌtinually vnto the PrieÅ¿t and that becauÅ¿e their offerings to the PrieÅ¿t, was profitable both to theÌ
Å¿elues, and alÅ¿o to theÅ¿e that appertained to them. Nowe as for the PrieÅ¿ts part, they needed not lawes to vrge them to teache this doctrine: for they were carried, as it were, with the charriots of their auarice to the performance of the Å¿ame, for otherwiÅ¿e their MaÅ¿Å¿es would haue beene left deÅ¿olate. And from thence came this their doctrine, that the MaÅ¿Å¿e Å¿erued Gabriel Biel lect. 85. in expoÅ¿. canon. & in 4. Å¿ent. diÅ¿t. 12. q. 3. to appeaÅ¿e Gods wrath, to obtaine remiÅ¿sion of Å¿ins, MiÅ¿Å¿ale in canone, & Pap â¢ Innocent. 3. tract. de MiÅ¿Å¿a. & Thomas de Aquine & Eckius de MiÅ¿Å¿a. lib. 1. cap. 10. Concil. Trident. Å¿eÅ¿ 6 can 2 redemption of Å¿oules, & al Å¿piritual grace & Å¿aluation: & that it Å¿erued for al other neceÅ¿sities, aÅ¿well of man, as of beaÅ¿t, aÅ¿well for the dead, as for the liuing, aÅ¿wel for the abÅ¿ent, as for the preÅ¿ent. And from heÌce come this three-folde force Gabriel Biel lect. 26. whilk they aÅ¿criue vnto their MaÅ¿Å¿e: the one moÅ¿t generall for all, another more Å¿peciall for him that Å¿ayes it: and the third after a mid way, whilk was in the hands of the PrieÅ¿t to apply it to what perÅ¿on, or perÅ¿ons, dead or liuing, it pleaÅ¿es him, equally or vnequally: and that God the Father diÅ¿penÅ¿es the fruits therof according to the determination of the PrieÅ¿t. And from this did Å¿pring their treaÅ¿ures and riches, throgh the aboundance of the peoples oblations: and from this came alÅ¿o the riche donations, prebends, Colledges, and lands, as may be Å¿eene by the common forme of their donations in their Charters: I offer to God all the things whilk are contained in this Charter, for the remiÅ¿son of my owne Å¿innes, and of my Parents, to maintaine the Å¿eruice of God in Å¿acrifices and MaÅ¿Å¿es. Matth. 15.5.6. As the Scribes and PhariÅ¿ies therefore taught the people, that by offring a gift, albeit they honored not their father and mother, yet they Å¿hould be free, & haue profite, abrogating the commandements of God through their traditions: Å¿o did the PrieÅ¿ts teach the people, that Å¿uppoÅ¿e they neglected the commandement of God in communicating in the Å¿acrament: yet by their preÅ¿ence at the Å¿acrifice, and by their giftes that they offered vnto them, they Å¿hould be free from that Å¿inne, and Å¿houlde haue profite not onelie to themÅ¿elues, but alÅ¿o to all that appertained vnto them. And to content the people that they Å¿hould not be offended that they were depriued of the communion, and receaued nothing for their offerings, but a bare Å¿ight and hearing of the PrieÅ¿t, eating and drinking all himÅ¿elfe allone: they inuented their holy bread, whilk they diÅ¿tributed vnto
the people euery Sabboth: and the kiÅ¿sing of the Pax, that is the couering of the Challice, to Å¿upply the want of the communion, whereby they might thinke that they were not altogether fruÅ¿trate of the Å¿ame.

And as for the people, becauÅ¿e they receaued not the loue of the trueth,
