Elleuenthly, is their MaÅ¿Å¿es for the peÅ¿t, tempeÅ¿t furie, fire, and all afflictions, and maladies, aÅ¿well of man, MaÅ¿Å¿es for the peÅ¿t, tempeÅ¿t, &c as of beaÅ¿t, whilk containeth intollerable and vile idolatry: for euery MaÅ¿Å¿e hes his owne Saint to be a patrone, according to the Å¿ubiect thereof, and euery Saint hes his owne office. AgainÅ¿t the peÅ¿t, the PrieÅ¿t Å¿ayes the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. SebaÅ¿tiane, & S. Roch, for they are the patrons and defenders againÅ¿t it: after the cuÅ¿tome of the Pagans, who honored Apollo & AeÅ¿culapius by feaÅ¿tes and Å¿acrifices for to be Å¿aued from the contagion of the Å¿ame. AgainÅ¿t the tempeÅ¿t, they Å¿ay the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Bernard, S. Graith, S. Barbe, and others, in Å¿tead of Iupiter whilk the Pagans worÅ¿hipped. AgainÅ¿t the rage or furie, they Å¿ay the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Hubert, who is the patrone of hunters and dogs, as the goddes Diana was the patrone amoÌgÅ¿t the Pagans. AgainÅ¿t the fire they Å¿ay the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Anton, for they make him the patrone of it: and they Å¿ay it is a greater oath to Å¿weare vpon the arme of S. Anton, then when one Å¿weares by the name of God. For a woman with child, they Å¿ay the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Margaret, in Å¿tead of Diana and Iuno whilk the Pagans worÅ¿hipped for wemen with child. For a horÅ¿e they Å¿ay the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Eloy, or S. Anton, yea, Alanus de Å¿acri
â¢ ic. euch. cap. 32 for a poor wifes hen, if it be Å¿icke or loÅ¿te. And for their pigs, they haue the MaÅ¿Å¿e of S. Antone. But firÅ¿t what blaÅ¿phemie is this, to haue their recourÅ¿e to Saints, hee or Å¿hee, to obtaine of them, or by their merite, or interceÅ¿sion, health in Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, &c. and Å¿ik like things, whilk are only in Gods hands to beÅ¿towe: for it is he only that Å¿ends health, and Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, faire wether, &
foule wether, & Å¿o forth. Next, the Lordes Supper was not inÅ¿tituted to be a charme for Å¿ik diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of man or beaÅ¿t, or for the fire, peÅ¿t, tempeÅ¿t, &c. but for the remembrance of ChriÅ¿ts death. So that if there were no more abuÅ¿e in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, but theÅ¿e two things, it is Å¿ufficient to make all men to abhorre Å¿ik abhominable idolatry.

The twentie and one abuÅ¿e, is their mixing of parcels of the Scripture, with their abhomination & idolatries in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, after the manner of thoÅ¿e who goes about to impoyÅ¿on anie: who mixes their poiÅ¿on with Å¿ome good food, that it may be the leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿pected: or rather as the Magicians & Charmers does, who mixes with their diueliÅ¿h practiÅ¿es, parcels of the Scriptures of God, and makes thoÅ¿e to Å¿erue for their diueliÅ¿h purpoÅ¿es, whilk was appointed to Gods honor So are all the places of Scripture, whilk are read and Å¿ung in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, they are brought forth, not for the truth, but againÅ¿t the truth for their idolatry and abhomination: & this they haue done, that their idolatry may bee leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿pected by the Å¿imple. Next, what warrand haue they to prefer the GoÅ¿pell, (as they call it) to the EpiÅ¿tles, in Å¿tanding vp at the reading of the GoÅ¿pell, and Å¿itting at the reading of the EpiÅ¿tles, Rom. 1.1. Rom. 2 16. 1. Cor, 4.15. Å¿eing they are both inÅ¿pired of God, and they both containe the GoÅ¿pell of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, as the ApoÅ¿tle teÅ¿tifies. Thirdly, the GoÅ¿pell and EpiÅ¿tles, were appointed not to be Å¿ung and chanted in the Kirk, (as they doe) but to be red & interprete: for the PÅ¿almes and other hymnes in the Scrip
â¢ ure are ordained for that vÅ¿e. Fourthly, Å¿eing the Scripture whilk is read and Å¿ung in your MaÅ¿Å¿e, is read and Å¿ung in an vnknowne language, as all the reÅ¿t of your MaÅ¿Å¿e is done: to what purpoÅ¿e does it Å¿erue? and what is it but a mocking of God, and abuÅ¿ing of the poore people.

The twentie and two abuÅ¿e, is their waxe candles whilk they haue burning in the time of their MaÅ¿Å¿es, in the fair day light, mocking as it were thereby, both God the authour of all light, and the light of the Å¿unne. And to what purpoÅ¿e caÌ they Å¿erue to burne in the day light, when the Å¿unne is Å¿hyning, but to beare witneÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t them in the great day,
that in the middeÅ¿t of the noone day, they groped in darkeneÅ¿Å¿e, & that they haue put out the light of the GoÅ¿pel, that Å¿hould haue Å¿hyned in their hearts? What Å¿hall I Å¿peak of the reÅ¿t of your ceremonies whilk are Å¿uperÅ¿titious, idle, carnall, and IewiÅ¿h? In attire like them: for as their PrieÅ¿tes were cled in an Ephod, a Myter, a broidered coat, a girdle, Exodus 28.4. a breaÅ¿tplate, and a robe. So with you your PrieÅ¿ts muÅ¿t haue an Amice, an Albe, a girdle, a fannell: whereof Å¿ome of them are taken from the faÅ¿hion of the Pagans. For Numa Pompilius when hee vÅ¿ed to worÅ¿hip, Ouid. in FaÅ¿tis. he couered himÅ¿elf with a kerchiffe or vaile: and he ordained that theÅ¿e idolatrous Alex. ab Alex. PrieÅ¿ts Å¿hould haue their Albe, and a painted coloured coat aboue it: as the Exod. 30.20 IewiÅ¿h PrieÅ¿t had a lawer, wherat they muÅ¿t waÅ¿he, before they Å¿acrificed, Å¿o haue yours: as they Exod. 29.27 lifted vp a part of the hoÅ¿te, Å¿o you lift vp the whole hoÅ¿te: as they Å¿ounded the Num. 10.10, trumpets at their Å¿acrifices, Å¿o you ring your belles. And what Å¿hall I Å¿peak of the reÅ¿t of your vaine and Å¿uperÅ¿titious ceremonies? in waÅ¿hing often, in croÅ¿sing and bleÅ¿sing often, in cenÅ¿ing often, in Å¿oft Å¿peach & whiÅ¿pering, in kiÅ¿sing of the Amice, kiÅ¿sing of the fannell, kiÅ¿sing of the Å¿tole, kiÅ¿sing of the altar, kiÅ¿sing of the booke, kiÅ¿sing of the PrieÅ¿ts hand, and kiÅ¿sing of the Pax: in Å¿miting and knocking of the breaÅ¿t, in geÅ¿turing by rule and meaÅ¿ure, in bowing and becking, in Å¿pacing foreward and backward, & turning round about, and trauerÅ¿ing of the ground: his geÅ¿ture Å¿o ridiculous, Å¿o changeable, Å¿o affectate in Å¿aying of his MaÅ¿Å¿e, that a man would think a plaier were comming forth vpon the Å¿tage to play, when the PrieÅ¿t addreÅ¿Å¿eth himÅ¿elf to the MaÅ¿Å¿e: beÅ¿ide the muÅ¿icke of your Organs where it may be had, and your threefold Å¿alutation of the PrieÅ¿t, Dominus vobiÅ¿cum, whilk can haue no vÅ¿e in the priuate MaÅ¿Å¿es, where the PrieÅ¿t is himÅ¿elf allone together with the Clark. So that in truth it is more then IewiÅ¿he: for in ceremonies they are aboue their ceremonies, in orders more exquiÅ¿ite, in cautels more diligent: Å¿o that it Å¿eemes rather to be a Å¿tage play nor the worÅ¿hip of God. But I Å¿ee it is fulfilled in them whilk was foretolde, that God woulde Å¿end them Å¿trong deluÅ¿ions, that they
might beleeue lies, that all theÅ¿e might be damned whilk loued not the trueth. Let the ChriÅ¿tian reader iudge nowe, whether the MaÅ¿Å¿e be an heauenly action, or whether it be not a Å¿ink and cloÅ¿et of all abhomination or idolatry, or not.

As trueth confirmes the Å¿elf, Å¿o falÅ¿et deÅ¿troies the Å¿elfe: A Kingdome deuided againÅ¿t it Å¿elfe (as our Sauiour Å¿aies) cannot Å¿tand: The manifolde contradictions one againÅ¿t another, both in the matter, forme, & effect, Å¿u â¢ Å¿tance, & circumÅ¿tance of their MaÅ¿Å¿e. Therfore their diviÅ¿ions and contradictions amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues concerning this their Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, is an euideÌt token that yt kingdome cannot Å¿tand. Turrian. 1. tract cap. 11 fol. 59 Some of you Å¿ayes, ChriÅ¿t deÅ¿cends daily froÌ the boÅ¿ome of the father to the altar, & aÅ¿cends froÌ theÌce to heaueÌ again: other Å¿ome Scarga artic. 11 fol. 335 Å¿aies the contrary, that he neither deÅ¿cends from heaueÌ in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, nor aÅ¿cends from thence to heauen. 2. Bellarmine Å¿aies in a Lib. 2. de MiÅ¿Å¿a cap. 4 part, that the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e does not Å¿atisfie for our Å¿innes, or merite properly the forgiueneÅ¿Å¿e of them. and yet in another Lib. 2. de MiÅ¿Å¿a fol. 731 place he Å¿aies, that ChriÅ¿t offered in the laÅ¿te Supper a Å¿acrifice for the Å¿innes of the ApoÅ¿tles, and the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e (Å¿aies he) is one with that. And In canone miÅ¿Å¿. their PreiÅ¿ts Å¿ayes in the MaÅ¿Å¿e that he offers it vp for the redemption of Å¿oules: and the counÅ¿ell SeÅ¿. 6. canon 2 & 3 of Trent calles it a true propitiatorie Å¿acrifice for the Å¿innes of the quick and the dead. And Lect. 85. in exp. canon. & in 4. Å¿ent. diÅ¿t, 12. qu. 2. Gabriell Biell a exponer of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ayes that the MaÅ¿Å¿e is one in Å¿ubÅ¿tance with the Å¿acrifice of the Croce, and that it proceedes the Å¿elfe Å¿ame effects; to wit, the appeaÅ¿ing of God his wrath: If it then appeaÅ¿e God his wrath, and be offered for the redemption of Å¿oules, then it muÅ¿t both merite properly, and Å¿atisfy properly. 3. Bellar. lib. 1. de MiÅ¿Å¿a, fol. 6.6. Some of you affirmes that the Å¿acrifice of the Croce, is more excellent then the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, and the V â¢ ga de MiÅ¿Å¿a theÅ¿. 141. vertue of the MaÅ¿Å¿e depends vpon it: and yet Å¿ome of you Vega theÅ¿. 137. Å¿aies, It is but one Å¿acrifice with that of the Croce, the Å¿ame Å¿acrifice & the Å¿ame PrieÅ¿t in both, how then can the one be more excellent then the other? 4. L b. 2. de MiÅ¿Å¿a cap. 4. Bellarmine Å¿aies, that the valour of the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e is finite, and therefore it is oft repeated: but Tract 7 de celebrat MiÅ¿Å¿ae, cap 2. queÅ¿t 1 Caietan a Cardinall Å¿aies, that the vertue, quantity, and effect of it, is infinite, as the Å¿uffering of ChriÅ¿t. 5. PoÅ¿Å¿en â¢â¢ us lib. contra Chy â¢ aeum & Volanum. Some of them Å¿aies, that ChriÅ¿t is offered vp in the MaÅ¿Å¿e by the words of the Kirk, when it is Å¿aide, Tua de tuis offerimus tibi, Å¿ome when the words of the coÌ Å¿ecration are pronounced: but Lib. 2. de MiÅ¿Å¿a cap. 11 Bellarmine aggrees with
neither: he Å¿aies, the Å¿acrifice is offered vp, not Å¿o much by the wordes as by the putting of the Å¿acrifice vppon the altar. 6. Lib. 1. de MiÅ¿Å¿a cap. 27. Bellarmine Å¿aies in a part, That if there be not a real and true Å¿laughter of ChriÅ¿t in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, then the MaÅ¿Å¿e is not a true and reall Å¿acrifice: for Å¿aies he, to a true and reall Å¿acrifice, is required a true and reall Å¿laughter of the thing that is Å¿acrificed: for the eÅ¿Å¿ence, Å¿aies he, of the Å¿acrifice Å¿tands in the Å¿laughter. Vppon the whilk followes, that either ChriÅ¿t is daily truely crucified in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, by their PrieÅ¿ts, or elÅ¿e their MaÅ¿Å¿e is not a true and reall Å¿acrifice. And yet in another Ibidem cap. 25 part, he Å¿aies, that the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e requyres not a true Å¿laughter of the Å¿acrifice. 7. Lib. 1. de Å¿acr. cap. 20 GaÅ¿pa CaÅ¿ilius Å¿ayes, that there are two diuerÅ¿e Å¿acrifices in the EuchariÅ¿t or MaÅ¿Å¿e, the one of the bread and wine, the other of the body and blood of ChriÅ¿t: and yet Lib. 1. de MiÅ¿Å¿a, cap. 27 Bellarmine and Å¿undry others denies it, and Å¿ayes there is but one. 8. Pope Tract. de miÅ¿Å¿a Innocent Å¿ayes, that the Å¿acrifice of the MaÅ¿Å¿e is offered vp for originall, venial, and mortall Å¿innes, & yet the MaiÅ¿ter Lib. 4. Å¿ent. diÅ¿t 12. cap. PoÅ¿th â¢ c of Å¿entences, and In Floret, lib, 4 GerÅ¿on Å¿ayes, that the MaÅ¿Å¿e purges but veniall Å¿innes, & Thomas de Aquina. Thomas of Aquine aggrees with neither of them, for he Å¿ayes, the Å¿acrifice of the Croce was for our originall Å¿inne, but the Å¿acrifice of the altar, is for our ordinary Å¿innes. 9. M. Gilbert Browne Å¿aies, that their PrieÅ¿ts does the Å¿ame in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, whilk ChriÅ¿t did in the Supper: but Lib, 1, de MiÅ¿Å¿a cap, 27. . Bellarmine frankly graunts that ChriÅ¿t did not offer vp the bread by the Å¿ame words, that their PrieÅ¿tes doe now in the MaÅ¿Å¿e, therfore they doe not the Å¿ame thing that ChriÅ¿t did. 10. MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert Browne Å¿ayes that ChriÅ¿t did offer his body and blood to the Father after the conÅ¿ecration, but Ibidem Bellarmine Å¿ayes that neyther ChriÅ¿t nor his ApoÅ¿tles in the beginning did offer vp any oblation after the conÅ¿ecration. I leaue the reÅ¿t of their contradictions, Å¿o that Å¿eeing they haue no concorde amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, neither in the matter, nor in the forme, nor in the effect, nor in the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, nor in the circumÅ¿tances of their pretended Å¿acrifice: but that the Lord (as is Å¿aide in HoÅ¿ea) hes deuyded their heartes: therefore their MaÅ¿Å¿e muÅ¿t periÅ¿he. And Å¿eeing the Lord hes Å¿ent Å¿ik a confuÅ¿ion amongÅ¿t them, that they vnderÅ¿tand not the language one of another: Å¿ome Å¿aying one thing, Å¿ome another: therefore it is Babel the towre of confuÅ¿ion
whilk they are building, and not the houÅ¿e of the Lord.

By their owne doctrine they are conuicted to be worÅ¿hippers of a falÅ¿e God and a â¢ als IeÅ¿us in their MaÅ¿Å¿e. To conclude this, they will haue their Å¿acrifice not a creature, Turian. 1. tract. cap. 17. & Antonius de Padua, ex Bellar. de Eucha. lib. 3. cap. 8. but a Creator of all creatures: and therefore they worÅ¿hip it with the worÅ¿hip of Latriae, whilk by their own doctrine is onely proper to God: therefore they Å¿ing after the conÅ¿ecration, It is not bread but God and man my Sauiour: and yet they Å¿ay that this Scarga artic. 5 fol. 335. Creator both begins to be where he was not before, after the conÅ¿ecration: and ceaÅ¿es to be where he was before: and that he is not Turrian. tract. 1 cap. 21 euery where as God is. And they Å¿ay that the PrieÅ¿t makes ChriÅ¿t his Bellarm lib, 3. de Euch. fol. 399. body of the bread in the Sacrament, & ChriÅ¿t this king Pope Iohn 22. lib. orat, inÅ¿crip. Antidotarius animae. & in Breuiario & miÅ¿Å¿alibus, Qui creauit me Å¿ine me, creatur mediante me that is, he that created me with out mee, (that is the PrieÅ¿t) is created by my moien that is, he makes that God, that made him. is made of bread. Now how can he be the true God, & a true creator, whilk hes a beginning, and ceaÅ¿es to be, whilk is not euery where, as God is, whilk is made of bread and wine by a MaÅ¿Å¿e-PrieÅ¿t, and that by their owne doctrine? Howe therefore Å¿hall their Kirk be cleared from abhominable idolatrie, that worÅ¿hips that whilk they call God, creator and Sauiour: and yet Å¿ik a God, as by their owne doctrine hes a beginning and ending, and is not euery where, and is made of breade and wine by duÅ¿te and aÅ¿hes. O, woe be to their Å¿oules that worÅ¿hips God, whilk made not heauen and earth, and cauÅ¿es others to doe the Å¿ame! And howe Å¿hall their MaÅ¿Å¿e-PrieÅ¿tes be cleared from Å¿acrilegious blaÅ¿phemie, whilk vaunts that in their MaÅ¿Å¿e they daylie creat their Creator, and that of bread and wine: and Å¿o makes themÅ¿elues Gods, and more then Gods, for God created but creatures, but they (as they Å¿uppone) creates the creator. And as they worÅ¿hip a falÅ¿e creator in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o do they worÅ¿hip a falÅ¿e ChriÅ¿t and Sauiour in the Å¿ame. For the Å¿cripture Å¿ayes, That the true ChriÅ¿t is made of the Rom. 1.3. Galat. 4 4 Å¿eede of Dauid, & of the Å¿eede of the woman, and not of any other Å¿ubÅ¿tance. But the ChriÅ¿t whilk they offer vp in their MaÅ¿Å¿e, by their owne doctrine, is made of bread and wine, and that by the PrieÅ¿t. So Ibidem Bellarmine confeÅ¿Å¿es, and Ibidem Pope Iohn 22. For the one Å¿ayes, that it is no abÅ¿urde thing to the PrieÅ¿t to make ChriÅ¿t his bodye of bread, and the other Å¿aies, that ChriÅ¿t the King is made of bread: Therfore they worÅ¿hip not IeÅ¿us the Å¿onne of Mary who was made of the woman, and of the Å¿eede of Dauid: but a falÅ¿e IeÅ¿us
made of bread, and baken in the Ouen, and formed by the PrieÅ¿t: therefore of all idolaters they muÅ¿t be the moÅ¿te blaÅ¿phemous and abhominable. And this meikle for the firÅ¿t head, concerning that idolatrous abhominable MaÅ¿Å¿e. Nowe followes the Å¿econd point concerning the AntichriÅ¿t: that the Popes of Rome are that vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, that the Scripture foretolde Å¿hould come.

div.head: The other part concerning the AntichriÅ¿t. MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert Browne.
div.p: IF the It was not my purpoÅ¿e then, Ioh. 5.43. Tract. 29, vpon Iohn. Pope be the AntichriÅ¿t, what is the cauÅ¿e that MaiÅ¿ter Iohn would not Å¿et downe Å¿ome place out of the word of God that proues the Å¿ame. But good reader, I will let you Å¿ee how far MaiÅ¿ter Iohn is againÅ¿t the word of God in this, and that by Å¿ome examples onely. FirÅ¿te, our Sauiour Å¿hewe vnto the Iewes, that albeit he came in the name of his Father, yet they would not receaue him: This title of Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands will not excuÅ¿e him, being indeid the title of curÅ¿ed Cham, for he is called the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands and Å¿o fit in the Lords iuÅ¿t prouidence for your Popes who is that man of Å¿in. if another (Å¿aies he) Å¿hall come in his owne name, him ye will receaue. This no doubt, as AuguÅ¿tine expones the Å¿ame, is meant of the AntichriÅ¿t, that the Iewes Å¿hall receaue. Nowe it is out of all controuerÅ¿ie that the Iewes neuer receaued the Pope: Therefore the Pope is not the AntichriÅ¿t. Againe, the Pope came neuer in his owne name but in the name of ChriÅ¿t, for he is called the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, and the Å¿eruand of the Å¿eruands of God: therefore he cannot be the AntichriÅ¿t.

I Come nowe to the Å¿econd heade, whilk I offered then to proue: to wit, that your Popes whilk ye will haue to be the head of the Kirk of ChriÅ¿t, are the Å¿elfe Å¿ame AntichriÅ¿t, that the Scripture fore-tolde Å¿houlde come. Thou wouldeÅ¿t knowe (ChriÅ¿tian reader) of what waight this controuerÅ¿ie, is, Whether the Pope be the AntichriÅ¿t or not? For this Å¿upremacy of his vnto them, is the foundation whereupon their religion, and the Å¿afety of their whole Kirk depends: Å¿o that they cal it, the Rock whereupon the Kirk is builded, RhemiÅ¿t. anno â¢ vpon Mat. 16 & Bella â¢â¢
â¢ is praeface before that controuerÅ¿ie of the Popes Å¿upremacie againÅ¿t whilk the yets of Hell Å¿hal not preuaile. And Bellarm. calles him the foundation whilk vpholdes the houÅ¿e of God, the PaÅ¿tor whilk feedes his flock, the Emperour whilk gouernes his hoÅ¿te, the Sunne whilk giues light to the Å¿tarres,
that is, to the MiniÅ¿ters of the Kirk: the head whilk giues life to his bodie. So that remoue his Supremacy the houÅ¿e of God muÅ¿t fall, the flock of ChriÅ¿t muÅ¿t be Å¿cattered, the hoÅ¿te of the Lord muÅ¿t be diÅ¿comfited, the Å¿tarres, that is the MiniÅ¿tery, muÅ¿t be darkened: and the body muÅ¿t ly Å¿till without motion. IÅ¿a 28, 16, & 8, 14.15 And he applyes theÅ¿e (a) prophecies, Å¿poken and fulfilled only in the Å¿onne of God, vnto him: calling him that fundamentall Å¿tone in Sion, vpon the whilk the whole Kirk is builded: and that proued Å¿tone, againÅ¿t the whilk the yets of Hell hes neuer, nor neuer Å¿hall preuaile: and that corner or cunzie Å¿tone, whilk ioynes both Iewe & Gentile, as two walles together in a ChriÅ¿tian Kirk: and that precious Å¿tone wherefrom the infinite treaÅ¿ure of grace is moÅ¿te plenteouÅ¿ly deriued, vnto the whole Kirk: as vnity in doctrine, the bonde of peace, the vnity of faith, whilk is Å¿aluation it Å¿elfe, and the very life of Religion: and he Å¿ayes there is no way to ChriÅ¿t, but by Peter, in whoÅ¿e roome their Popes Å¿ucceedes: Å¿o that in their iudgement there is no way to ChriÅ¿t, but by the Pope. And he calles him that rock of offence, and Å¿tumbling Å¿tone Å¿poken of in EÅ¿ay chap. 8. Vpon the whilk whoÅ¿oeuer Å¿hall fall, Å¿hall bee broken: and on whome it Å¿hall fall, it Å¿hall daÅ¿he him in peeces. O blaÅ¿phemous mouth! Let the heauens be confounded at this. And therefore this is of Å¿ik a waight, that Boniface the 8. hes made it an article of our faith: whoÅ¿e wordes are theÅ¿e. We declare, Extra, de minoritate & obedientia, cap. Vnam Å¿anctam we affirme, we define and pronounce that it is altogether needfull to Å¿aluation to all creatures to be vnder the Pope of Rome. So that Bellarmine Å¿aies, when the Popes Å¿upremacy is called in controuerÅ¿ie, the Å¿umme of all ChriÅ¿tianity is called in queÅ¿tion: and when that is controuerted, then it is controuerted whether the kirk Å¿hould Å¿tand any longer or not, or fall & diÅ¿Å¿olue. Vnto them therefore it is an article of faith, whilk muÅ¿t be beleeued and practiÅ¿ed vnder the paine of the loÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿aluation. And vnto vs he is that Å¿elfe Å¿ame AntichriÅ¿t whilk the Scripture hes foretolde, time hes made manifeÅ¿t, & the Kirk hes Å¿uffered. Vnto them he is the heade of the body of ChriÅ¿t, the PaÅ¿tor of his flock, the Å¿unne that giues light to the Å¿tarres, the foundatioÌ of the houÅ¿e of God, and a mortall God amongÅ¿t men: Vnto vs he is Gods enemy, the Å¿onne of perditioÌ, the Å¿econd beaÅ¿t,
and falÅ¿e prophet, the aduerÅ¿ary of true Religion, 2, TheÅ¿, 2. apo, 13 a peÅ¿t in the bodie, a tyrant in the commonwealth, and AntichriÅ¿t in the Kirk. So thou Å¿ees (ChriÅ¿tian reader) of what wayght this controuerÅ¿ie is.

Let vs Å¿ee then how he defends him from being the AntichriÅ¿t, and then you Å¿hall heare our reaÅ¿ons to the contrary. You aske wherefore I Å¿et not down Å¿ome places of Scripture to proue the Pope to be the AntichriÅ¿t: I anÅ¿were: not becauÅ¿e I could not, but becauÅ¿e it was not my purpoÅ¿e at that time. But nowe I minde to doe it (God willing) after that I haue anÅ¿wered to your arguments. Your firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on is, The Iewes Å¿hall receaue the AntichriÅ¿t: but they neuer receaued the Pope: therefore the Pope is not the AntichriÅ¿t. I anÅ¿wer: Your PropoÅ¿ition I deny, that the Iewes Å¿hall receaue the AntichriÅ¿t. For firÅ¿t I will aske you, Are you of that opinion with Bellarmine, the RhemiÅ¿ts, and the reÅ¿t of your Cleargy, Bella 1. lib. 3. de Rom. Pont. cap. 12.. RhemiÅ¿t. annot. vpon 2 TheÅ¿. 2 The Iewes Å¿huld not receaue the antichriÅ¿t as their MeÅ¿sias. that they Å¿hall receaue him as their MeÅ¿sias, whilk they looke for? If you be not of their minde, then beÅ¿ide that you diÅ¿Å¿ent from the doctrine of your owne Kirk, it is not probable that the Iewes woulde receaue him, if they thought not hee were their MeÅ¿sias. And if ye be of their minde, then I Å¿ay, the Iewes will receaue none as their MeÅ¿sias, but theÅ¿e who are borne of the tribe of Iuda, and the family of Dauid in Bethlehem, and who Å¿hall reigne in IeruÅ¿alem. But the tribes are confounded, Å¿o that they cannot knowe it, and the family of Dauid deÅ¿troyed by Å¿undry Emperours: or at the leaÅ¿t, Å¿o coÌ founded that they cannot be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed: and Bethlehem is deÅ¿troyed, & the Temple in IeruÅ¿alem alluterly caÅ¿ten down: therefore the MeÅ¿sias whilk they looke for, will neuer come. And Å¿o (if this be true) the AntichriÅ¿t whilk ye imagine heir will neuer come, Å¿ince your AntichriÅ¿t and their MeÅ¿sias that they looke for, are both one, as your Kirk Å¿uppones. And I Å¿ay further, Sanderus and the RhemiÅ¿ts Å¿ayes, In 8. demonÅ¿t. RhemiÅ¿t. annot. vpon the 2, TheÅ¿Å¿a the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hall come of the tribe of Dan: if then he Å¿hall come of the tribe of Dan, (as they Å¿ay) the Iewes will neuer receaue him as their MeÅ¿sias, becauÅ¿e they know their MeÅ¿sias whilk they looke for, Å¿hall come of the tribe of Iuda. Therefore if Sanderus
and the RhemiÅ¿ts Å¿peake true, the Iewes Å¿hall neuer receaue the AntichriÅ¿t at all. Thirdlye, I lay this ground whilk you cannot deny, that the Iewes are to be planted in again in the naturall Oliue: that is, they are to be conuerted to ChriÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e their fall was but for a time, as the ApoÅ¿tle plainly foretelles, Rom. 11. RhemiÅ¿t annot. vpon that chapter and the RhemiÅ¿tes graunts it. Vpon the whilk I aske you, MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, whether Å¿hall they receaue the AntichriÅ¿t, before, or after their conuerÅ¿ion? If you Å¿ay, after: theÌ I Å¿ay, after they haue embraced the true MeÅ¿sias & the GoÅ¿pell, how can it be that they will looke for another MeÅ¿sias, and receaue the AntichriÅ¿t as their Sauiour. Next, we read of their conuerÅ¿ion in the Scripture, but nothing of their reiection of ChriÅ¿t after their conuerÅ¿ion. And thirdly, Å¿eeing (as your Kirk Å¿ayes) the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿halbe Å¿ent to them, and they Å¿hal receaue him, becauÅ¿e they receaued not ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us: of force then it cannot be after their conuerÅ¿ion. For the cauÅ¿e, to wit, their hardneÅ¿Å¿e of heart, and refuÅ¿all of the true MeÅ¿sias, being taken away: this puniÅ¿hment Å¿hould not bee Å¿ent vnto them after their embracing of ChriÅ¿t: Å¿o not after their conuerÅ¿ion. And if you Å¿ay before their conuerÅ¿ion; theÌ I Å¿ay, either muÅ¿t you make the reigne of your AntichriÅ¿t loÌ ger then three yeare and a halfe, (whilk your Kirk does) & put a greater Å¿pace betwixt the perdition of him, & the end of the world, then your Bellarmine puts but 45. daies betwene his perdition and the end of the world. lib. 3. de Rom. Pont. c. 17. Kirk does, and Å¿o ouerthrow your owne doctrine concerning the AntichriÅ¿t, that ye may eÅ¿tabliÅ¿he your imaginary AntichriÅ¿t. Or elÅ¿e what likelihoode is there that euer they Å¿hall be conuerted to ChriÅ¿t, whilk is againÅ¿t both the Scripture, & your owne doctrine? for Å¿eing the Iewes are to receiue him as their MeÅ¿sias, & Å¿eing he is to builde their TeÌple, reÅ¿tore their ceremonies, & obtain ye Monarchie of the whole world, eÅ¿pecially by their help (as your doctrine affirmes) Å¿hall not this driue them further from ChriÅ¿t, Bella 1. lib. 3. de Rom. Pont. cap. 12.16. &c. and harden their harts more then euer it was before? And Å¿eing he Å¿hall raigne but three yeares and a halfe, and they cannot embrace the true Sauiour, as long as he raignes (for they cannot embrace both the AntichriÅ¿t, and the true ChriÅ¿t together) and Å¿eeing after his death the day of iudgement
Å¿hall come immediatly, or at the leaÅ¿t 45. dayes after, (as Bellarmine Å¿ayes:) how can it be poÅ¿sible that they Å¿hal euer be turned to ChriÅ¿t before the end of the worlde, if this your doctrine be true? Therefore they cannot receaue the AntichriÅ¿t before their conuerÅ¿ion, and Å¿o they Å¿hall neuer receaue the AntichriÅ¿t. So then to conclude this point, as the MeÅ¿sias whilk the poore blinded Iewes lookes for, will neuer come, the true MeÅ¿sias being come already, whome they crucified: So the AntichriÅ¿t whilk ye imagine will neuer come, for the true AntichriÅ¿t (whilk either ye will not Å¿ee, or elÅ¿e if ye Å¿ee, ye will not confeÅ¿Å¿e him) lurkes within your owne boÅ¿ome, theÅ¿e many yeares, whome ye labour to couer, that he Å¿hould not be Å¿eene.

But how proue ye that the Iewes will receaue the AntichriÅ¿t? BecauÅ¿e our Sauiour Å¿ayes to the Iewes, If another Å¿hal come in his owne name, him ye will receaue. I graunt indeede our Sauiour Å¿o Å¿peakes. But firÅ¿te I Å¿ay, this other is not to be reÅ¿tricted to the AntichriÅ¿t only, IoÅ¿eph. de bello Iudaico, lib. 2. ca. 12. Pet. Gala. lib. 40. cap. 21. Bellarm lib. 3. de Rom. Pont. c. 12. but to be referred to all falÅ¿e Prophets, who Å¿hall come, not being Å¿ent of God, Å¿o Nonus, Å¿o Lyra expones it: and this was fulfilled long Å¿ince in receauing of Theudas and Cozban, and other deceauers whom they receaued. As for AuguÅ¿tine, it is true, he expones it of the AntichriÅ¿t. But if Bellarmine reiects AuguÅ¿tins opinion concerning the generation of the AntichriÅ¿t, that he Å¿hall come of the tribe of Dan, becauÅ¿e it cannot (Å¿aies he) bee prooued by the Scripture: Å¿hall it not alÅ¿o be lawfull for vs, not to be bound to the expoÅ¿ition of AuguÅ¿tine, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be certain by the Å¿cripture: Å¿o giue vs that libertye whilk yee take to your Å¿elues. Your firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on then hes no feete: for this place Å¿peakes of all falÅ¿e Prophets whatÅ¿omeuer, whilk the Iewes Å¿hould receaue: and it hes bene accompliÅ¿hed Å¿undry times amongÅ¿t them: therfore this yet remaines vnprooued that the Iewes Å¿hall receaue the AntichriÅ¿t. This for the firÅ¿t part of the argument. The Å¿econd part of your argument is, The Pope came neuer in his owne name, but in the name of ChriÅ¿t: therefore hee is not the AntichriÅ¿t. Your antecedent I deny. For if ye will credite FranciÅ¿cus Toledo if ye knowe him, writing vppon the
Å¿ame place, he Å¿ayes, He Å¿hall come in his owne name, who truely Å¿hall haue no diuine vertue, The Pope come not in the name of ChriÅ¿t in truth but in his owne name, becauÅ¿e ChriÅ¿t left him neuer in his Å¿tead or left na Å¿ik calling in his worde. but Å¿hall faine himÅ¿elf to be Å¿ent of God, as the falÅ¿e Prophets came in their owne name, becauÅ¿e they were not truly Å¿ent of God. And this is that, Å¿aies he, whilk is Å¿aid now (meaning in this place) if only Å¿hall come in his owne name: that he, is not truly Å¿ent of God, neither hes Gods power. So then a falÅ¿e Prophete is Å¿aide both to come in the name of God, and in his owne name: in the name of God falÅ¿lye vanting Å¿o: in his owne name, becauÅ¿e God Å¿ends him not, but he intrudes himÅ¿elfe without a lawfull calling. Nowe to anÅ¿were you then, I Å¿ay the Pope comes in the name of ChriÅ¿t, as his Vicare, I grant he and his Cleargie Å¿o vaunts: but falÅ¿ly. For the truth is, he hes come, and he commes in his owne name, and that truly, becauÅ¿e the Lord neuer Å¿ent him, but he hes intruded himÅ¿elfe without God his calling: therefore this can not free him but he may be the AntichriÅ¿t. But howe proue ye that hee commes in ChriÅ¿t his name, and not in his owne name? BecauÅ¿e (Å¿ay ye) he calles himÅ¿elf the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, and the Å¿eruand of the Å¿eruands of God. A pretty argument: hee Å¿o calles himÅ¿elf, Ergo he is Å¿o. Who will cr â¢ dite either you or him in your owne cauÅ¿e? Is this all ye can do for your Pope? He is called Å¿o, Ergo he is Å¿o. AuguÅ¿tine Å¿aies, Non attendamus ad linguam, Tract 3. in epiÅ¿t. Ioan. Å¿ed ad facta. Let vs not take tent to the tongue, but to the deedes. For if al be asked, & all with one mouth confeÅ¿Å¿e ChriÅ¿t, let the tongue ceaÅ¿e a little, and aske the life Interroga vitam? and againe, whoÅ¿oeuer denies ChriÅ¿t (factis) by his deedes, is AntichriÅ¿t. The idolaters of EpheÅ¿us might haue reaÅ¿oned Å¿o for their great goddeÅ¿Å¿e Diana: Act. 19. Å¿hee is called a great goddeÅ¿Å¿e, ergo Å¿he is Å¿o indeede. And what falÅ¿e Prophet yet euer came, but they Å¿aid they came in the name of God, and they called themÅ¿elues, & were called by theÅ¿e whome they deceaued, the Å¿eruandes and Prophetes of the Lord: and yet will you frame this argument for them, as you doe for your Pope. Ierem. 23.25 Ezech. 13 6.7. All the falÅ¿e Prophets Å¿aid they came in the name of God, and were called by theÅ¿e whome they deceaued, the Å¿eruands of God, therfore they came not in their owne name, but in the name of God. Did not the falÅ¿e ApoÅ¿tles
Reuel. 2, 2 in EpheÅ¿us Å¿ay they were the ApoÅ¿tles of ChriÅ¿t, & yet they were found liars: and did not the verÅ¿e 9. Synagogue of Satan call themÅ¿elues Iewes, and yet they blaÅ¿phemed in Å¿o Å¿peaking. Does not the harlot with whome the nations of the earth hes committed fornication, Reuel. 18.7 Å¿ay in her heart, Å¿he is a Queene, and yet Å¿hee is that great harlote. And is not her Reuel. 17 4 Cupe of golde, and yet the drinke therin is abhomination. And Å¿hould not the AntichriÅ¿t 2. TheÅ¿. 2.4 Å¿it in the temple of God, and yet he is the Å¿onne of perdition, and an aduerÅ¿ary to God, and to IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. And Matth 4.8.9. Å¿aid not the Diuell of himÅ¿elfe, that all the Kingdomes of the world were giuen to him, & he would giue them to whome he would, and yet he was a lyar? So if this argument of yours will follow, The Pope is called the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, & the Å¿eruand of the Å¿eruands of God, therfore hee came neuer in his owne name, and Å¿o hee is not the AntichriÅ¿t: you may with as good reaÅ¿on conclude, that the falÅ¿e Prophetes and falÅ¿e ApoÅ¿tles, came not in their owne name, but in the name of God, becauÅ¿e they are called the Å¿eruands of God, both by themÅ¿elues, and alÅ¿o by theÅ¿e who were deceaued by them. Yea, you may with as good reaÅ¿on conclude, that the AntichriÅ¿t is not the Å¿onne of perdition, & aduerÅ¿ary to God, and that all the kingdomes of the worlde are giuen to the Diuell, & that he hes the power in his hand of giuing them to whom he will: becauÅ¿e the Scripture foretolde of the one, that he Å¿hould haue hornes like the Lambe, 2. TheÅ¿Å¿al, 2. & Reuel. 17 Matth 4. and the other aÅ¿criues this right and power to himÅ¿elfe. It is good therefore that you cannot defend your Pope from being the AntichriÅ¿t, vnleÅ¿Å¿e with him alÅ¿o you defend all the falÅ¿e Prophets, falÅ¿e ApoÅ¿tles, falÅ¿e Kirks, the AntichriÅ¿t, and the Diuell himÅ¿elfe, from being the thing whilk they are indeede. But who will venter the Å¿aluation of their Å¿oule, vpoÌ this Å¿o Å¿illie, and fooliÅ¿he a reaÅ¿on? But I pray you (MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert) let mee aske you this. Is your Pope the Å¿eruand of the Å¿eruandes of God, and the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, as he calles himÅ¿elfe? Dare you avowe this in the preÅ¿ence of him, who Å¿hall iudge the quick and the dead, that he is Å¿o, as he calles himÅ¿elfe? Did euer ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us either tread vpon the necks of Kings, and Emperours with his feete? or was he euer lifted
vp and carried vpon the Å¿houlders of noble men? or did he euer giue his feete to Emperours to kiÅ¿Å¿e, as your Popes hes done, as your owne hiÅ¿tories does witneÅ¿Å¿e? And haue ye euer read what one of his owne ArchbiÅ¿hops of Coleine, one of his owne religion, writes to Pope Nicolaus the firÅ¿te, fiue hundreth yeares agoe, Auentinus lib. 4. annalium. Å¿peaking to him, he Å¿aies, Thou pretends the perÅ¿on of the Pope, but thou playes the tyrant: we feele vnder the habite of a PaÅ¿tor, a Wolfe, the Å¿tile belyes the Parent: thou vauÌtes thy Å¿elf to be Iouem. God by thy deedes, while as thou art the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands, thou contends to be Lord of Lords, according to the diÅ¿cipline of ChriÅ¿t our Sauiour, thou art the leaÅ¿t of all miniÅ¿ters of the Temple of God; but thou by the ambition of ruling goes to ruine: whatÅ¿umeuer lykes thee, Fucus factures ChriÅ¿tianis. is leeÅ¿ome. This was euill in thoÅ¿e daies, but there are worÅ¿e Å¿ince. And what now (reader) Å¿hal we Å¿ay of the Pope, Å¿ince his owne Arch-biÅ¿hop hes Å¿o written of him? You Å¿ay he is the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, but ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us in his latter TeÅ¿tament, did neuer leaue him to be in his Å¿tead. For in the 4. EpheÅ¿. 11. He gaue ApoÅ¿tles, Prophets, EuangeliÅ¿ts, PaÅ¿tors, & Doctors for the woorke of the miniÅ¿terye, and the building of the bodye of ChriÅ¿t. But that he euer left a Pope to be head of the Kirk in his Å¿tead, to be a Monarch in this earth, to raigne in Rome, and to be Lorde ouer the Å¿eruands of God, there is not a Å¿illabe in the whole book of God to proue it. And becauÅ¿e you Å¿ay he is the Å¿eruand or Å¿eruands: what Å¿eruice, I pray you, does he wherby he makes it manifeÅ¿t that he is a Å¿eruand in deede? For the principall Å¿eruice of the miniÅ¿try of the Kirk Å¿tands in preaching the word, whilk he neither does, neither thinks that it appertaines to him to doe. Yea, what is it that appertaines to ony Lord, King, or Monarch in the earth, that he aÅ¿criues not to himÅ¿elfe, and does not alÅ¿o practiÅ¿e? Yea, as though that were too little, what either Å¿tile or properties or workes, whilk are peculiar only to God his MaieÅ¿ty, that he aÅ¿criues not to himÅ¿elfe, as (God willing) Å¿halbe prooued afterward in the third mark of the AntichriÅ¿t. So that Auentinus Å¿aies of the Pope, Lib. 7. He who is the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands is the lord of Lords, and he deÅ¿ires to be as though he were God: hee Å¿peakes great things as if he were God: he changeth the lawes, eÅ¿tabliÅ¿heth his owne:
he reaues, he Å¿poiles, he deceaues, he Å¿layes: that man of perdition, whom men vÅ¿es to call AntichriÅ¿t, (Å¿peaking of the Pope) in whoÅ¿e forebead the name of blaÅ¿phemy is written: I am God I cannot erre. So what is this elÅ¿e, but a horrible mocking both of God & man to Å¿tile him the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands, Å¿eeing hee hes lifted vp himÅ¿elfe, Å¿o far aboue both God and man? So then to conclude this, as Goliah his owne Å¿worde Å¿lew himÅ¿elf, Å¿o the reaÅ¿on whilk ye bring to defend your Pope from being the AntichriÅ¿t, doth moÅ¿t euideÌtly conuict him to be the AntichriÅ¿t. He may iuÅ¿tly be called the AntichriÅ¿t, who vnder pretence of the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t, and the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands, is Monarch and lord ouer all: this you cannot deny. BecauÅ¿e the Scripture deÅ¿criues the AntichriÅ¿t to haue two hornes lyke the Lambe, to Å¿it in the Temple of God, Apoc. 13. & 17. 2. TheÅ¿Å¿al. 2. to haue a golden Cupe: and yet to Å¿peake like the Dragon, to be aduerÅ¿ary to God, and to lift himÅ¿elfe aboue all that is called God. But Å¿o hes the Popes of Rome done, as it hes, and Å¿halbe proued by their owne doctrine and practiÅ¿e, and whilk you cannot deny: Therefore he is in very deed that AntichriÅ¿t whilk was to come. And this for your firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on.

Secondly, Saint Paule in deÅ¿criuing of the AntichriÅ¿t, 2. TheÅ¿Å¿al. 2, 3. telles that he Å¿hal be but one, the Å¿onne of perdition. Now then, if there Å¿halbe but one chiefe AntichriÅ¿t, whether is this preÅ¿ent Pope he, or Å¿ome other before him. For euery man knowes that there hes bene moe then 230. Popes, as all the writers of their liues teÅ¿tifies. They cannot all be AntichriÅ¿tes, for that repugnes to Saint Paule, who hes put him in the Å¿ingular nomber. And if MaiÅ¿ter Iohn will followe the worde, as he Å¿ayes he does, where will he finde that there Å¿halbe many chiefe AntichriÅ¿ts, and not one only? For that place of Saint Iohn where he Å¿aies, That now there is becommed many AntichriÅ¿ts, can no waies be vnderÅ¿tood, but of the fore-runners of the great AntichriÅ¿t. 1. Iohn 2.18. For at that time MaiÅ¿ter Iohn will graunt himÅ¿elfe, that the great AntichriÅ¿t, the Å¿onne of perdition was not begun.

p.label: MaiÅ¿ter Iohn WelÅ¿che his Reply. The AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hould not be â¢ o Å¿ingular perÅ¿on, but a Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of many in one kingdome defection and tyrannie.

div.p:
Your Å¿econd reaÅ¿on is, the AntichriÅ¿t is but one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on. The Popes hes bene many: therefore they are not the AntichriÅ¿t. I deny your propoÅ¿ition, for there lyes all the
controuerÅ¿ie. We Å¿ay the AntichriÅ¿t is not this Pope, or that Pope an certaine perÅ¿on. But wee aÅ¿criue this name, to the whole Å¿eate and the Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of your Popes: we Å¿ay the bodie and the kingdome of your Romaine Kirk, whereof your Popes are the heades, is that AntichriÅ¿t whilk was to come. So if you proue that the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿hould be but a particular perÅ¿on, and not a body, a kingdome, a Å¿eate and Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of men that are aduerÅ¿aries to God and to IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, I will graunt you haue Å¿ufficientlie cleared your Pope from beeing AntichriÅ¿t. But content your Å¿elfe (MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert:) this ye will neuer proue by the Scripture: and therefore ye muÅ¿t let your Popes be accounted the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿till. And if this reaÅ¿on of yours be good, the AntichriÅ¿t is one certaine perÅ¿on. Therefore the Popes, becauÅ¿e they are many, are not the AntichriÅ¿t; wherefore (I pray you) Å¿hall not this alÅ¿o be good: the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t is one certaine man, but the Popes are many: therefore they are not ChriÅ¿t his Vicare? What difference (I pray you) is there beetwene the one and the other? And if ye will Å¿ay, the Vicare of ChriÅ¿t is not one Å¿ingular man, but a Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of many in one office: why will ye not alÅ¿o graunt, that the AntichriÅ¿t is not a Å¿ingular man, but the Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of many in the Å¿elfe Å¿ame impietie. So either chooÅ¿e you, whether will ye graunt that the AntichriÅ¿t is not one Å¿ingular man, but a Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of many; or elÅ¿e that the Popes are not ChriÅ¿t his Vicare: for the one ye muÅ¿t doe, if this reaÅ¿on of yours holde forth. But how doe ye proue that the AntichriÅ¿t is but one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on? You Å¿ay, that Saint Paule telles that he Å¿halbe but one. Howe woulde yee haue cried out, if I had fathered Å¿ik a falÅ¿et vpon the Å¿pirit of God as you do heir? but let Å¿ik be far from mee. You Å¿ay, Saint Paule calles him the Å¿onne of perdition, and puts him in the Å¿ingular nomber: therefore Å¿ay ye, the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿halbe but one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on. I feare ye take pleaÅ¿ure to deceaue the Å¿imple with Å¿ik Å¿illie reaÅ¿ons. Our Sauiour Matth 12.35. Å¿aies, that a good man o anthropos, out of the treaÅ¿ure of his heart bringes forth good things. And he Å¿ayes, Marc. 2.27 The Sabboth was made dia ton anthropon, for man, and not o anthropos dia ton Å¿abbaton, man
for the Sabboth. And alÅ¿o he Å¿aies, Luke 4 4 o anthropos man Å¿hal not liue of bread only. AlÅ¿o 2. Tim. 3.17 that o anthropos the man of God may be made perfite. And, 1. Timoth. 3.2. For it behooues ton episkopon a BiÅ¿hop or ouerÅ¿eer, &c. Heir are the Å¿ame phraÅ¿es of Å¿peach: they Å¿peak all of a man in the Å¿ingular nomber, with that Å¿ame greeke article o, as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peakes heir in deÅ¿criuing the AntichriÅ¿t, and yet I trow ye will not be Å¿o ignorant or impudent, as to Å¿ay, that our Sauiour and the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peakes of one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on in theÅ¿e places. So what warrand haue ye to gather that heir, whilk you dare not gather out of the like phraÅ¿es of the Scripture? If then in theÅ¿e places there is not a Å¿ingular man vnderÅ¿tood, Å¿uppoÅ¿e they Å¿peake of a maÌ in the Å¿ingular nomber; it will not follow that the AntichriÅ¿t muÅ¿t be one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peakes of him as of one man, in the Å¿ingular nomber, for the phraÅ¿es are all one: but the firÅ¿t ye muÅ¿t graunt: therefore the next will followe. Secondly, in the 16. of Matthew, our Sauiour Å¿aies, Epi taute te paetra, Vpon this rock I will builde my Kirk, he Å¿peakes heir in the Å¿ingular nomber with the Å¿ame article te, that the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peakes of, in deÅ¿criuing the AntichriÅ¿t. Nowe let mee vÅ¿e this Å¿ame argument againÅ¿t your Popes, that they are not this rock vppon the whilk the Kirk is builded, as you Å¿ay, as you haue vÅ¿ed heir to proue that he is not the AntichriÅ¿t. This rock vpon the whilk ChriÅ¿t promiÅ¿ed to builde his Kirk, is but one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e our Sauiour puts him in the Å¿ingular nomber (Epi taute te petra) Vpon this rocke: but your Popes of Rome are not one Å¿ingulare perÅ¿on, but many: Therefore your Popes of Rome are not this Rock vpon the whilk ChriÅ¿t promiÅ¿ed to builde his Kirk What difference is there betweene your argument for the Pope, and this argument againÅ¿t the Pope, Å¿eeing both are grounded vpon the like phraÅ¿e? ChooÅ¿e you then, MaiÅ¿ter Gilbert, whether will you haue the AntichriÅ¿t, not to be one Å¿ingular perÅ¿on, but a Å¿ucceÅ¿sion of many: or will you haue the Popes not to be the rockes where upon the Kirk is builded? for the one ye muÅ¿t. Thirdly, I Å¿ay, the ApoÅ¿tle Paule Å¿ayes Å¿peaking of the AntichriÅ¿t, that the myÅ¿terie of iniquity is
begun euen now to work.
â¢ . TheÅ¿Å¿al. 2.7. 1. Iohn 4.3. And Iohn Å¿aies, this is the Å¿pirit of that AntichriÅ¿t whilk ye hard was to come, and is euen now preÅ¿ent in the world: and the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿aies, the Lord 2. TheÅ¿. 2.8. Å¿hall deÅ¿troy him with his preÅ¿ence: and your doctrine is, that hee Å¿hall not come while the end of the worlde. Now what a monÅ¿trous man will yee make him, whoÅ¿e Å¿pirit was in the daies of the ApoÅ¿tles, and who muÅ¿t continue till the end of the world, if the Scripture be true, a man of fifteene hundreth yeare of age already. She gaue to her beloued friends droppes of her monÅ¿trous bloode, and made them beleeue it was the bloode of ChriÅ¿t, Å¿he was condemned as a witch by the inquiÅ¿itors of Spaine about the yeare of God 1540. The other of a Dominican Nun Priores de la Anunciada of LiÅ¿bon in Portugale, about the 1586. yeare of God, that Å¿hee had deÅ¿erued to haue ChriÅ¿t viÅ¿ible for her husband, that he appeared to her often times, & talked with her, as one friend would talke with another: that Å¿he had the impreÅ¿sion of ChriÅ¿ts 5. wounds vpon her. And the RhemiÅ¿ts Å¿ayes, that Å¿ome expones theÅ¿e ten Kings, of ten kingdomes, In their annotations vpon this place. into whilk the Romane empire Å¿hall be deuided, whilk Å¿hall all Å¿erue AntichriÅ¿t: therefore Rome as it is heir deÅ¿criued, muÅ¿t be the Å¿eate of the AntichriÅ¿t.

LaÅ¿t of all, the Reuelation Å¿peakes heir of that Rome that Å¿halbe brunt with fire, & be made deÅ¿olate by the ten kingdomes, whilk God Å¿hould Å¿tirre vp to hate her; & he Å¿peaks heir of that Rome whilk Å¿halbe caÅ¿ten in the middes of the
Å¿ea: after the whilk Å¿hall followe the day of iudgement: But this cannot be Rome as it was the Å¿eate of the Romane Empyre, The teÅ¿timonies of themÅ¿elues prouing the Popes to be the AntichriÅ¿t, and Rome to be that miÅ¿tical Babilon. but as it is the Å¿eate of the AntichriÅ¿tian kingdome: for it is more then a thouÅ¿and yeares, Å¿ince Rome left off her GentiliÅ¿me, & yet this prophecy is not accompliÅ¿hed in her. Vnto theÅ¿e I ioine the teÅ¿timonies of Å¿ome of their owne Monks, BiÅ¿hops, Poets, Friars, hiÅ¿toriographers, Emperours and Popes alÅ¿o, whereby it will be verefied, that this harlote is Rome, and the Popes thereof the AntichriÅ¿t. Bernarde a Monke of Cluniak, who liued about 400. yeare agoe, writing vnto Peter the Abbote of that MonaÅ¿terie, Å¿peaking of the tyrannous behauiour of the Cleargie and BiÅ¿hop of Rome, he accuÅ¿es them of Å¿acrilegious bryberie, of bying and Å¿elling of the BiÅ¿hops Pall, the Ring, and of all Lawes and equitie. And he Å¿ayes in another place, Roma nocens nocet, at
que viam docet ipÅ¿a nocendi, Iura relinquere, lucra requirere, pallida vendi: Non Deus eÅ¿t tibi IeÅ¿us Roma periÅ¿ti.

That is
This hurtfull Rome, does hurte, and teach to be wicked,
To leaue all lawe, and gaip for gaine, and Å¿ell a PopiÅ¿h Tippet.
A greedie gulfe, a griping graue, a filthie iakes,
Both bottomleÅ¿Å¿e, vnÅ¿atiate: and all alike Å¿he makes.
By drinking thou art dry, & louder thou does cry, come bring me more:
I pray thee cry hoe: but thou Å¿aies no: I hunger Å¿ore.
I thinke thou makes golde thy God, not IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t.
Rome what Å¿hall I Å¿ay? what Å¿hall I doe, or tell thee what is done?
Wealth weakeneth thee, wealth threatneth thee not to be Rome.
Then let me Å¿peake it, and let me write it, Rome once thou waÅ¿t.
Then let me Å¿peake it, and let me write it, Rome thou art gone.
And Iohn a Monke Å¿ayes, Curia vult marcas, burÅ¿as exhaurit, & arcas: &c.

That is,
The Court of Rome does aime at markes, it Å¿ouks the purÅ¿e, & Å¿oaks the arks:
If that you minde to Å¿pare your arkes, come not at Popes nor Patriarkes:
But if you frankly giue them markes, and with good gold Å¿tuf vp their arkest
I warrand then you Å¿hall be free, from any kinde of penaltie
Who is within? who is there? I. Why, what would ye? Come in.
Bring you ought? No. Stand Å¿till. But I doe. Go ye then in.

The Å¿ame Monke alÅ¿o Å¿aieth,
Roma manus rodit: quod rodere non valet, odit.
Dantes exaudit, non dantibus oÅ¿tia claudit.
Curid curarum genitrix, nutrix
que malorum.
Ignotos notis, inho neÅ¿tos aequat honeÅ¿tis.

That is,
Rome is a raker, and Å¿pitefull hater of the emptie hand:
She heareth the giuer, but others neuer, but letteth them Å¿tand.
Her Courte a cage of cares: of miÅ¿chiefes eke the mother:
She vÅ¿eth knaues like honeÅ¿t men, and Å¿trangers like a brother.

The ArchbiÅ¿hop of Colon and TraverÅ¿e Å¿ayes to Pope Nicolaus the firÅ¿t, Thou pretends the perÅ¿on of he Pope, but thou playes the tyrant. We feill a Wolfe vnder the weed of a PaÅ¿tor: the Å¿tile belies the parent. Thou by thy deedes makes Å¿how as if thou were God: while as thou art the Å¿eruand of Å¿eruands, thou contendes to be Lord of Lords. According to the diÅ¿cipline of our Sauiour, thou art the leaÅ¿t of all the miniÅ¿ters of the Temple of God. Thou through the deÅ¿ire of ruling, goes to perdition. WhatÅ¿omeuer thing pleaÅ¿eth thee, is leeÅ¿ome to thee. Fucus factus e â¢ ChriÅ¿tianis And Gregory a Pope Å¿ayes, I affirme this boldly vpon good aÅ¿Å¿urance, that whoÅ¿oeuer he be that calles himÅ¿elf, or is deÅ¿irous to be called vniuerÅ¿al PrieÅ¿t, in that hautines of his, is a fore-runner of AntichriÅ¿t, in that by Å¿welling pride he preferreth himÅ¿elfe before others. Arnulphus AurelaenÅ¿is vnto the councell of Rhemes, teÅ¿tifies this of the Pope, Whome (Å¿aies he) reuerend Fathers thinke ye this man so be? who Å¿itting in a high throne, Å¿hynes in his purple and golden attyre? to wit, if he want loue, & be puffed vp by knowl dge, he is the AntichriÅ¿t Å¿itting in the Temple of God, Å¿hewing himÅ¿elfe as though he were God. Bernard 400. yeare agoe, writing to Eugenius Pope of Rome, 2, Book to Eugen in concluÅ¿ion he breaketh forth in theÅ¿e words. Thou hes more neede (Å¿aies he) to haue a rake in thy hand, 4. book to Eugen nor a Å¿cepter to performe the office of a Prophete. And in another place, after he hes deÅ¿criued and deteÅ¿ted the pride of the BiÅ¿hops of Rome, at laÅ¿t he concludeth the matter in theÅ¿e wordes, Å¿aying to the Pope, Heirein (Å¿aies he) thou Å¿howes thy Å¿elfe to haue Å¿ucceeded not to Peter, but to ConÅ¿tantine. Peter is he who neuer knewe what belonged to Å¿ik Å¿olemne Å¿hewing himÅ¿elfe abroade, in braueries of precious Å¿tones, or Å¿ilkes, or â¢ old, or ryding vpon a white Palfray, or being garded with a troope of tall fellowes, or enuironed wich a c â¢ mpany of ruffling Å¿eruing-men. AlÅ¿o in another place, In his epiÅ¿tle 230 Å¿peaking of the tiranny of the BiÅ¿hop of Rome, he maketh an exclamation in this Å¿ort. At the firÅ¿t indeed (Å¿aies he) ye began to play the Lords but ouer the Cleargie, contrary to the counÅ¿ell of Peter: 1. Pet, 5.3. 2. Cor. 1.24. and within a while contrary to the aduiÅ¿e of Paule (Peters ftllowe ApoÅ¿tle) you will haue dominion ouer the faith of all men. But ye Å¿tay not there: ye haue taken vpon you
more: namelie, to haue a peremptory power in Religion it Å¿elfe. Nowe what remayneth whereon ye might further incroache, except ye will go about to bring the very Angels vnder your Å¿ubiection. And in another place, Vpon the Cantic Å¿erm. 33 Å¿peaking of the behauiours of the romiÅ¿h Prelats, Hence commeth (Å¿aies he) that whooriÅ¿h tricking, that Å¿tage-like attire, that prince-like pompe, whilk dayly we Å¿ee in them: Hence proceids the golde that they vÅ¿e in their brydles, Å¿adles, and Å¿purres: in Å¿o much that their Å¿purres are more glittering then their altars. Hence came their Å¿tately Tables, their variety of diÅ¿hes, and quaffing cups: hence iÅ¿Å¿ued their ionketting, banketting, their drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿urfets: hence followed their Viols, harpes, and Å¿halmes: hence flowed their Å¿ellers and pantries Å¿o Å¿tuffed with wines and viands of all Å¿orts: hence gote they their lee-pots, and painting boxes: and hence had they their purÅ¿es Å¿o well lyned with coine. Fy vpon it. Sik men they will needs be, & yet they are our great maiÅ¿ters in IÅ¿rael, as Deanes, arch-deanes, BiÅ¿hops, and arch-biÅ¿hops. TheÅ¿e works of theirs are little inferiour vnto that filthineÅ¿Å¿e whilk they committed in darkeneÅ¿Å¿e. And laÅ¿tly he addes theÅ¿e words, For he is the very AntichriÅ¿t. Frederick the Å¿econde, foretolde the ruine of Rome, more then 300. yeares Å¿ince in theÅ¿e wyrds, writing to Innocentius 4. Pope:
Roma diu titubans, long is erroribus acta
Corruet, & mundi deÅ¿inet eÅ¿Å¿e caput.

q.l: Rome rowling long about in errours, bound, & thrall,
Shall fall at laÅ¿t, and ceaÅ¿e to be the lofty head of all.

div.p:
And in his verÅ¿e written againÅ¿t the Pope, hee affirmes plainely that he was that Å¿onne of perdition & that head of the wicked foreÅ¿poken by Paule. And in his letters to the prelates of the world, he calles the Pope that greate dragon, that hes deceaued the whole world, that AntichriÅ¿t, and that counterfite Vicare of ChriÅ¿t. Eberharbus BiÅ¿hop of SalÅ¿burgh, Aboue 380. yeares agoe. Auentinus lib. 7 Å¿peaking of the BiÅ¿hops of Rome hee Å¿ayes: they onely deÅ¿ire to reigne, they can not abide peace: They will not ceaÅ¿e till they haue Å¿tamped all vnder their feete, that they may Å¿it in the Temple of God, & be lifted vp aboue all that is called God, or that is worÅ¿hipped. He who is the Å¿eruaÌd of Å¿eruaÌds, is the Lord of Lords, and deÅ¿ires to be thought of, as if he were God: And hee Å¿ayes, that man whome they vÅ¿e to call AntichriÅ¿t, bee Å¿peaketh greate things as though he were God, in whoÅ¿e fore-heade that name of blaÅ¿phemie
is written: I am God I can not erre. FranciÅ¿cus Petrarcha a light of that age for his manifolde learning, calles the courte of Rome Babylon, and that harlote of Babell that Å¿itteth vpon manye waters, the mother of Idolatrie & whoordoÌe, the refuge of hereÅ¿ies & errors. And Petrus Iohannes pronouÌced the Pope to be the AntichriÅ¿t and the Å¿inagogue of Rome to be that greate Babylon. And Matthias PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is Å¿ayes, that AntichriÅ¿t hes Å¿educed al the vniuerÅ¿ities and colledges of the learned, Å¿o that they teach nothing Å¿oundly now: & the edict of the empire, vnder Lodouick the fourth, Å¿peaking of Pope Iohn the 22. Å¿ayes, ChriÅ¿tians can not keepe the peace whilk is giuen them of God, for this AntichriÅ¿t (meaning the Pope) And in another edict it is written, as he is a diÅ¿aguiÅ¿ed PaÅ¿tour, Å¿o is he a myÅ¿ticall AntichriÅ¿t: and we declare him being the author of that AntichriÅ¿tian Empire, to be damned of hereÅ¿ie, & depoÅ¿ed by our right by the councell, Å¿entence, and common conÅ¿ent of the princes and prelats of Germanie, the PrieÅ¿ts of Italie, and people of Rome Å¿o deÅ¿iring. And Auentinus in the hiÅ¿torie of Hildebrand writes, that almoÅ¿t all the plaine, iuÅ¿t, Å¿imple, & vpright hes written, that then (to wit when he was Pope) the Empyre of the AntichriÅ¿t began, becauÅ¿e they Å¿awe that come to paÅ¿Å¿e at that time, whilk our Sauiour fore-tolde Å¿o manye yeares before. And to conclude this: Hadrian the 6. Pope, in his inÅ¿tructions of his legats to the conuention at Noremberge, he Å¿ayes: Thou Å¿halt Å¿aye, that wee grant freely that God hes Å¿uffered this perÅ¿ecution to come vpon the Kirk for the Å¿innes of men, and eÅ¿pecially of the prieÅ¿ts and prelats of the Kirk. And againe hee Å¿ayes, we know that in this Å¿eate (Å¿peaking of that Pontificall Å¿eate in Rome) many abhominable things hes beene for Å¿ome yeares, as abuÅ¿e in Å¿pirituall things, exceÅ¿Å¿e in commandements, and laÅ¿t of all, all things changed in worÅ¿e. And the Popes Cardinals (Å¿peaking to Paule the third) Å¿ayes. From this fountaine (holy Father) as from the Troyan horÅ¿e, Å¿o many abuÅ¿es hes ruÅ¿hed into the Kirk, and Å¿o heauie diÅ¿eaÅ¿es wherewith (as we may Å¿e) Å¿he is brought into a deÅ¿perate eÅ¿tate, I omit the reÅ¿t: Yee may Å¿e the trueth is Å¿trong that hes made their owne mouths to fyle themÅ¿elues. To conclude this then: Hee muÅ¿t be the vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, and his kingdome AntichriÅ¿tian, vnto whome the whole markes of the AntichriÅ¿t, as he is deÅ¿criued in the Å¿cripture by the ApoÅ¿tle Paule, & Iohn in
the Reuelation doth aggree: But they all aggree vnto the Popes of Rome and his kingdome, as hes beene proued. Therefore they muÅ¿te bee that vndoubted AntichriÅ¿te who was to come. Secondly, he muÅ¿te bee that vndoubted AntichriÅ¿t, whome his owne Friars, BiÅ¿hops, Cardinals, and Å¿ome of themÅ¿elues doth call AntichriÅ¿t, and aÅ¿criue theÅ¿e things vnto him that belongs properly to the AntithriÅ¿t: But his owne Friars, BiÅ¿hops, Cardinals, & Å¿ome of themÅ¿elues hes Å¿o teÅ¿tified, as hes beene proued alÅ¿o: Therefore out of their owne mouths they are condemned to be that AntichriÅ¿t, & their kingdome AntichriÅ¿tian.

Now to put an end to this my reply, that religion is falÅ¿e whilk hes neither vnitie, Å¿ucceÅ¿sion, nor antiquitie: this you can not deny, becauÅ¿e you make them the markes of your Kirk: But your religion hes neither vnitie, for that is broken by your manifolde contradictions and diÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿ions amongÅ¿t your Å¿elues, whereof I haue marked Å¿ome, and the diligent reader of your workes may gather many moe: Chrachtouius in his booke called Bellum IeÅ¿uiticum, hes gathered of two heads to wit the MaÅ¿Å¿e and AntichriÅ¿t 205. contradictions, let the ChriÅ¿tian Reader iudge then what maye be gathered of the reÅ¿t, no Å¿ucceÅ¿sion, neither perÅ¿onal, broken by their Popes who was AtheiÅ¿ts, SchiÅ¿matickes, heretickes, and by a vvoman Pope: neither in doctrine, being direct contrarye to the doctrine of ChriÅ¿t: no antiquitie, for the authors and origen of Å¿undrie maine poynts of your religion is Å¿et downe heere, and al your Romane Cleargie, hes not Å¿atisfied MaiÅ¿ter Iewels challenge this 30. yeare agoe, concerning the noueltie of 27. of your opinions. Therefore Å¿ince it hes neither vnitie, Å¿ucceÅ¿sioÌ, nor antiquitie, it is a falÅ¿e religion by your own doctrine. Secondly, that religion whilk is contrarye the Scripture, contrary the practiÅ¿e of the primitiue Kirk whilk opens a dore to all licenciouÅ¿nes, whilk can bring no true peace & conÅ¿olation vnto the conÅ¿ciences of men, whilk bluÅ¿heth to be knowen and made manifeÅ¿t, whilk maintaineth manye greate abÅ¿urdities, horrible blaÅ¿phemies, abhominable idolatry that is the doctrine of AntichriÅ¿te, & the doctrine of diuels,
whilk by their own mouthes is condemned, muÅ¿t be erroneous and falÅ¿e: But the religion of the Kirk of Rome is Å¿uch as hes beene euidently proued before, therefore it muÅ¿t be falÅ¿e. Woe therefore belonges to their Å¿oules that profeÅ¿Å¿es it openly or Å¿ecrectly.

q.p: And another Angel followed Å¿aying, Babylon that great citty, Å¿he hes fallen, Å¿he hes fallen: for Å¿he hes made all nations to drinke of the wyne of the wrath of her fornication. Ver. 9. And the third Angell followed them, Å¿aying with a loude voice, If any Å¿hall worÅ¿hip the beaÅ¿t and his image, and receaue the marke vpon his foreheade, or vpon his hand, he alÅ¿o Å¿hal drinke of the wine of the wrath of God yea of the pure wine, whilk is powred in the Cupe of his wrath, and he Å¿halbe tormented in fire and brimÅ¿tone before the holy Angels, and before the Lambe, and the Å¿moake of their torment Å¿hall aÅ¿cend for euermore: and they Å¿hall haue no reÅ¿t, day nor night, whilk worÅ¿hip the beaÅ¿t and his image: and whoÅ¿oeuer receaueth the printe of his name.

Å¿ome. pag. 341. l, 37, for PapiÅ¿tes, r, Popes. And in the epiÅ¿t, to the Reader, and to M, Gilb. Browne. for this country read that country of NiddiÅ¿daill and Galloway, euery where.

Good Reader, if thou Å¿halt finde any more faultes, then theÅ¿e aboue corrected, eitherr in the matter, or marginall quotations, excuÅ¿e the authour by reaÅ¿on of his far abÅ¿ence, in the time of the imprinting of this worke
